fields.raw_text:
Summer Research Early Identification Program (SR-EIP) Fully Funded Internship for Undergraduates: Apply Now!

Are you an undergraduate student with a strong interest in research and long-term plans to pursue a PhD or MD-PhD? The SR-EIP (Summer Research Early Identification Program), organized by The Leadership Alliance, is now open for applications for the 2026 cohort, with a deadline of February 3, 2026. This prestigious and fully funded summer research opportunity is designed to identify, train, and mentor promising undergraduatesΓÇöparticularly those who may not yet have had access to intensive research experiencesΓÇöand prepare them for competitive doctoral programs.

About the Summer Research Early Identification Program (SR-EIP)
SR-EIP is a fully paid summer internship program that offers undergraduate students hands-on, closely mentored research experiences across a wide range of disciplines. The program focuses on building a strong foundation in research methodology, critical thinking, and academic inquiry while exposing participants to the realities and expectations of graduate-level research.
Participants spend 8 to 10 weeks during the summer at one of 20+ leading research institutions in the United States. During this period, students work directly with faculty members or senior researchers who provide individualized mentorship and guidance. Research areas span:

Life and physical sciences
Social and behavioral sciences
Humanities

The goal of SR-EIP is not only to introduce students to research but to prepare them strategically for future PhD or MD-PhD applications, positioning them for long-term success in academia and research-driven careers.

What the Program Offers
The SR-EIP stands out as one of the most comprehensive undergraduate research programs available. Selected participants benefit from:

A fully funded experience, including a stipend, housing, and travel support provided by the host institution
Hands-on research training, combining theoretical knowledge with practical laboratory, field, or archival work
One-on-one mentorship from faculty or research professionals in the studentΓÇÖs chosen field
Professional development support, including guidance on graduate school applications and academic career pathways
Opportunities to present research, through oral or poster presentations at the Leadership Alliance National Symposium
Long-term access to mentoring and professional networks as part of The Leadership Alliance alumni community

Notably, 45% of SR-EIP participants have never taken part in a summer research program before, making this initiative especially valuable for students who are early in their research journey.

Who Is Eligible to Apply?
To be eligible for the 2026 Summer Research Early Identification Program, applicants must meet the following criteria:

Be a U.S. citizen, U.S. non-citizen national, or permanent resident with valid documentation at the time of application
International students on F-1 visas, as well as asylum seekers and refugees, are not eligible
Be enrolled full-time in an accredited public or private college or university in the United States or its territories
Be in good academic standing, with a minimum GPA of 3.0
Have completed at least two semesters of undergraduate study and have at least one semester remaining before graduation by the start of the program
Demonstrate a clear and committed interest in pursuing graduate study toward a PhD or MD-PhD

Important note: SR-EIP is not intended for students pursuing professional degrees in law, business administration, clinical medicine, or allied health professions.

How to Apply
Applications for the 2026 SR-EIP cycle open on November 1, 2025 and must be submitted online through The Leadership Alliance application portal.
Applicants are advised to carefully review the Application Instructions and ┬áFrequently Asked Questions┬á(FAQs) before applying.
A complete application includes:

The online application form
Two letters of recommendation
Official academic transcript(s)

It is the applicantΓÇÖs responsibility to ensure that all materials are received by the February 3, 2026 deadline. Late or incomplete applications will not be considered.

Research Sites and Institutions
With one application, students may apply to up to three different research sites. Participating institutions include some of the most respected universities and research organizations in the U.S., such as:

Harvard University
Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)
Stanford University
Yale University
Princeton University
Columbia University
Johns Hopkins University
University of Pennsylvania
Vanderbilt University
Brown University
Caltech
Cornell University
Howard University
Emory University
Weill Cornell Medical College
Regeneron
AbbVie
And many more

Each institution offers unique research areas and program structures, so applicants are encouraged to review individual site requirements carefully.

Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion
The Leadership Alliance is deeply committed to diversity, equity, and inclusion. Its programs are designed to prepare scholars from underrepresented and underserved backgrounds for advanced graduate training. Applications are reviewed without discrimination based on race, color, sex, age, religion, national or ethnic origin, disability, veteran status, socioeconomic background, sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.

Why SR-EIP Matters
SR-EIP alumni include doctoral scholars and researchers who credit the program with clarifying their academic goals, strengthening their research skills, and opening doors to elite graduate programs. Through mentorship, exposure, and sustained support, SR-EIP continues to play a critical role in shaping the next generation of scholars across STEM, social sciences, and the humanities.
If you are serious about a future in research and graduate study, the Summer Research Early Identification Program is an opportunity you should not miss.

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like thisΓÇª
The post Summer Research Early Identification Program (SR-EIP) Fully Funded Internship for Undergraduates: Apply Now! appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Enterprising Futures Scholarship 2026: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs Supports Young Impact Entrepreneurs

The Enterprising Futures Scholarship 2026, powered by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs in partnership with One Young World, is now open for applications. This prestigious scholarship is designed for young entrepreneurs and business leaders who are leading or contributing to scalable start-ups and SMEs with social or environmental impact, particularly across Africa and the Middle East.
As young people increasingly shape the future of global economies, entrepreneurship has become a powerful force for sustainable development. Yet, many promising entrepreneurs face barriers such as limited access to international networks, resources, and global exposure. The Enterprising Futures Scholarship addresses these gaps by connecting high-impact entrepreneurs to a global leadership platform.
About the Scholarship
The scholarship enables selected entrepreneurs to attend the One Young World Summit 2026 in Cape Town, where over 2,000 young leaders from more than 190 countries will convene to exchange ideas, learn from world-class experts, and collaborate on solutions to pressing global challenges.
Beyond the Summit, scholars become part of a broader ecosystem supported by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, offering long-term opportunities for engagement, visibility, and collaboration.
What Scholars Receive
Selected scholars will benefit from:


Full participation in the One Young World Summit 2026


Access to a global network of young leaders, entrepreneurs, and policymakers


Opportunities to strengthen entrepreneurial and leadership skills


International exposure for their ventures and impact work


Engagement in pre- and post-programme activities led by the Dutch MFA and partners


Previous scholars have contributed to ecosystem mapping, advised on development initiatives, and participated in events organised by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs and its partners.
Who Can Apply
Applicants must:


Be 18ΓÇô35 years old by November 2026


Be leading or part of a scalable start-up or SME with demonstrable social and/or environmental impact


Be a national and resident of one of the eligible countries, including: Ethiopia, Jordan, Lebanon, Mozambique, Uganda, Tunisia, Palestine, Egypt, C├┤te dΓÇÖIvoire, Kenya, Morocco, Nigeria, Senegal, Benin, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, South Africa, Burundi, Iraq (including Kurdistan region of Iraq), Sudan, Mali, and Algeria.

Have a working proficiency in English

Be available to participate fully in the programme between 30 October ΓÇô 7 November 2026, including pre- and post-programme activities


The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs strongly encourages applications from entrepreneurs of all backgrounds and identities, including those from underserved and rural communities.
Key Dates


Applications Open: 19 January 2026


Application Deadline: 9 March 2026


How to Apply
Eligible candidates must apply through the official application portal.
Apply Here
For more opportunities,┬áclick here.
The post Enterprising Futures Scholarship 2026: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs Supports Young Impact Entrepreneurs appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
AsiaGlobal Fellows Program 2026 ΓÇô A Premier Leadership Fellowship for Global Changemakers

The AsiaGlobal Fellows Program, hosted by the Asia Global Institute (AGI) at The University of Hong Kong, is now accepting applications for its 2026 cohort. Launched in 2017, the program is dedicated to cultivating a new generation of global leaders who are equipped to understand and address complex challenges from an Asian perspective.
To date, the fellowship has supported 104 Fellows from over 55 countries, bringing together diverse mid-career professionals committed to public policy, global governance, economic development, sustainability, and social impact.
About the Program
The AsiaGlobal Fellows Program is an interdisciplinary, fully immersive leadership development experience based in Hong Kong. Through:

A rigorous curriculum
Experiential learning
Dialogue with world-class experts
Engagement with scholars, policymakers, and business leaders

Fellows gain deep insights into geopolitics, economics, sustainability, technology, and governance, with a strong focus on understanding global issues through Asian lenses.
The fellowship is directed by Asia Global Institute (AGI), a multidisciplinary institute that provides a platform to explore timely global challenges and fosters informed, solutions-oriented dialogue.

Application Deadline
March 31, 2026

Who Should Apply?
The program welcomes candidates from any country, background, or sector. To be eligible, applicants must:

Be mid-career professionals with 8ΓÇô25 years of experience
Be active in public policy, politics, civil society, academia, or business
Demonstrate a strong interest in the Asia-Pacific region
Show a proven capacity to create positive impact in their organization and society

AGI values diversity and particularly encourages applicants with varied professional experiences and cultural perspectives.

Language Requirement
All program activities and materials are in English. High proficiency in reading, writing, speaking, and listening is required.

Application Components
Online Application Only
All submissions must be completed through the online portal. No emailed applications will be processed.
Three Recommendation Letters
Referees (non-relatives who know your work) must submit letters directly in English.
Applications with missing letters will be marked incomplete.
Supporting Documents
Applicants may submit resumes, awards, citations, publications, or other materials to strengthen their application.
Interview (If Shortlisted)
Shortlisted candidates will be invited to an online or in-person interview during the evaluation period.

Why Join the AsiaGlobal Fellows Program?
Fellows benefit from:

Direct engagement with global thinkers, academics, and policymakers
A strong, diverse global alumni network
Deep exposure to emerging issues shaping Asia and the world
Opportunities to expand leadership capacity and policy influence

The program is ideal for professionals seeking to broaden their global mindset and contribute meaningfully to public policy and global governance.
Applications for the 2026 cohort are open until March 31. Apply now.

The post AsiaGlobal Fellows Program 2026 ΓÇô A Premier Leadership Fellowship for Global Changemakers appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
EU Women Leaders 2026: Accelerating Women into Executive and Board Roles

A Free EU Co-Funded Programme for Senior Women Professionals
Women across Europe remain underrepresented in executive management and board-level positions, despite their qualifications, leadership experience, and proven capabilities. With the new EU Directive on gender balance on boards set to come into force in June 2026, the conversation has shifted. The question is no longer whether women should be at the decision-making table, but whether they are fully supported, visible, and prepared to access these roles. To address this challenge, EU Women Leaders 2026 has been launched as a free, selective, and EU co-financed leadership programme. The initiative is designed to accelerate senior women into executive and board-level positions across corporate, academic, and non-profit sectors.

Programme Overview
EU Women Leaders 2026 is a hybrid leadership development programme running from February to June 2026. It combines online expert-led sessions with hands-on workshops and culminates in an in-person networking event in Luxembourg.
Key features include:

Free EU co-financed training delivered over several months.
Weekly online sessions led by experts in leadership, governance, and executive communication.
Hands-on workshops focused on strategic positioning and board readiness.
Advanced training modules covering governance, leadership, and executive communication.
Certificate of completion awarded to all participants.
In-person networking event in Luxembourg, included as part of the programme.

This structure ensures that participants not only gain knowledge but also practical skills and visibility, positioning them for the next level of leadership.

Eligibility and Selection
The programme is open to senior women professionals in the European Union who are ready to step into executive management and board positions. Applicants may come from corporate, academic, or non-profit sectors.
Selection process:

Applications are open now and will close on January 27, 2026, just before midnight.
A two-phase process will be used: written application followed by a short interview.
Only 20 women will be selected to join the programme.
Results will be shared prior to the programmeΓÇÖs start in the second week of February 2026.

This selective approach ensures that participants are highly motivated and positioned to benefit fully from the training and networking opportunities.

Why This Programme Matters
The EU Women Leaders 2026 initiative is a strategic intervention aimed at reshaping leadership in Europe. By preparing women for executive and board-level roles, the programme directly supports the implementation of the EU Directive on gender balance.
The initiative acknowledges that capability alone is not enough. Visibility, readiness, and systemic support are equally critical. As Carol Constant, one of the programmeΓÇÖs leaders and 2025 Most Influential HR CEO in Central Europe, emphasized, ΓÇ£This is not just a training programme; itΓÇÖs an opportunity to position yourself for the next level of leadership and shape the future of decision-making in Europe.ΓÇ¥

Organizers and Partners
EU Women Leaders 2026 is spearheaded by Lucia de Luca at DeLucaStrategy and WhomLab, an HR technology company focused on quality hiring and team management. The programme is co-funded by the European Union, ensuring accessibility and credibility.
The initiative builds on existing EU projects such as the Erasmus+ Board Readiness Project, reinforcing the broader European commitment to gender balance in leadership.

Application Details

Deadline: January 27, 2026 (just before midnight).
Programme dates: February ΓÇô June 2026.
Format: Hybrid (online weekly sessions + in-person event in Luxembourg).
Cost: Free, co-financed by the EU.
Selection: 20 participants through application and interview.
Outcome: Certificate of completion and enhanced readiness for executive and board roles.

Interested candidates are encouraged to apply promptly and to tag other women leaders who could benefit from this opportunity.

EU Women Leaders 2026 represents a timely and impactful initiative to accelerate women into executive and board-level positions across Europe. With the EU Directive on gender balance set to take effect in June 2026, this programme provides senior women professionals with the tools, training, and visibility they need to step confidently into leadership roles. Apply now.

LEAP Emerge Fellowship 2026ΓÇô2027: Leadership Development Program for Rising Young Professionals

The LEAP Emerge Fellowship is a year-long leadership development program created to empower rising young leaders as they prepare for their transition into the professional world. Designed for college students entering their final undergraduate year, the fellowship combines mentorship, skills-based training, community impact work, and personalized support. For the 2026ΓÇô2027 academic cycle, the program remains fully virtual, ensuring nationwide accessibility for students across the United States.
LEAP Emerge Fellowship Overview
LEAP Emerge is structured as an academic-year fellowship that provides participants with tangible leadership skills and exposure to diverse career industries. Fellows receive targeted guidance intended to strengthen their job-readiness and amplify their potential for post-graduation success. The program includes a $3,000 stipend, distributed across the fellowship year, supporting students as they engage in workshops, mentorship sessions, and hands-on project work.
The application window runs from January 16 to March 13, 2026, giving rising seniors and graduating students time to prepare their materials and secure letters of recommendation. This fellowship is intentionally designed to uplift and support students driven by purpose, curiosity, and a commitment to community impact.
Program Structure
Throughout the academic year, Emerge Fellows participate in monthly virtual leadership development trainings led by LEAP staff and partner organizations. Each session lasts between one and two hours and is scheduled around the cohortΓÇÖs academic commitments. These workshops equip students with essential professional and interpersonal skills, including communication, teamwork, problem-solving, and navigating culturally relevant workplace challenges often experienced within Asian and Pacific Islander (API) communities.
Mentorship is a defining component of the program. Fellows are paired with multiple mentors across LEAPΓÇÖs extensive network of more than 1,000 alumni representing corporate, nonprofit, and higher education sectors. These mentors provide one-on-one guidance on r├⌐sum├⌐ development, interviewing strategies, workplace norms, and career exploration. Fellows must connect with their mentors at least once per month, building consistent and supportive professional relationships.
In addition to workshops and mentorship, each participant must complete a Community Impact Project. Working collaboratively, fellows research issues affecting API communities and develop a project that addresses a challenge they identify. This capstone element deepens fellowsΓÇÖ understanding of community-rooted leadership and encourages them to apply their learning to real-world issues.
Fellows are also required to spend 30 hours completing a professional development course to earn a certificate, further strengthening their preparation for the workforce.
Eligibility and Application Requirements
Students eligible for the 2026ΓÇô2027 cohort must be entering their final year of undergraduate studies during the 2025ΓÇô2026 school year. Juniors and fifth-year students who are approaching graduation may also apply. LEAP welcomes applicants from all backgrounds and regions, with no preference based on location or race. While API studies coursework is not required, applicants should possess a thoughtful understanding of API issues and history, as these themes are central to the fellowshipΓÇÖs work.
A complete application includes:


A current r├⌐sum├⌐


Two letters of recommendation


A personal statement


Five short-answer essay responses


A general outline of the applicantΓÇÖs fall academic schedule and extracurricular commitments


Applicants invited to the next stage will participate in a video-conference interview with LEAP staff.
What LEAP Looks for in a Fellow
The ideal Emerge Fellow is a motivated, community-minded individual eager to learn and prepared to grow throughout the program. Applicants do not need to have a defined career path but should show self-awareness, strong values, and a genuine desire to contribute to their communities. LEAP especially values curiosity, leadership experience, collaboration, and a commitment to lifting others as one advances.
A Fellowship Rooted in Community Impact
As an organization dedicated to leadership development for Asian and Pacific Islanders, LEAP created the Emerge Fellowship to address gaps in access, mentorship, and professional guidance. Through alumni connections, skill-based instruction, and culturally responsive support, Emerge empowers young leaders to enter the workforce with confidence, clarity, and community-driven purpose.

Junior Policy Advisor at GIZ: Support the 2026 Co-Presidency of the PractitionersΓÇÖ Network

The Deutsche Gesellschaft f├╝r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) is recruiting two Junior Policy Advisors to support its upcoming co-Presidency of the PractitionersΓÇÖ Network for European Development Cooperation (PN). Based in Brussels, these full-time positions offer an opportunity to work at the centre of European development policy, engaging with EU institutions, Member State agencies, and a broad network of international partners. The roles are expected to begin in February 2026, ahead of the co-Presidency period starting in late May.

About the Role
GIZ will share the PN co-Presidency with CzechAid for a 12-month term. The Junior Policy Advisors will play a pivotal role in the strategic coordination, agenda-setting, and operational leadership of the co-Presidency. Working within the GIZ Representation in Brussels, the selected candidates will engage with senior management, PN members, and the PN Coordination team to support the NetworkΓÇÖs governance and strategic direction.
These roles involve working in a highly political, multi-stakeholder environment and require the ability to manage complex processes, analyse institutional priorities, and communicate effectively across diverse European actors.

Key Responsibilities
The Junior Policy Advisors will contribute to the coordination, planning, and implementation of all activities linked to the PN co-Presidency. Core responsibilities include:
Strategic and Operational Coordination


Supporting the PN Focal Points in implementing the co-Presidency agenda, including major thematic priorities such as financial and technical cooperation, joint implementation practices, and the operationalisation of the Network.


Contributing to the definition and monitoring of the PNΓÇÖs strategic priorities in coordination with co-Presidents, network members, and PN Coordination.


Governance and Network Engagement


Participating in governance bodies, working groups, task forces, and high-level meetings.


Supporting the co-Presidency in decision-making spaces and technical fora.


Helping to develop partnerships with prospective PN members and external partners.


Policy Development and Analysis


Drafting strategic notes, concept papers, and analytical inputs to inform senior management decisions.


Identifying political and institutional opportunities and risks, and formulating relevant recommendations.


Events, Communication, and Visibility


Assisting in organising major events such as international missions, General Assembly sessions, and joint meetings.


Contributing to internal and external communication, including visibility activities across the PN and GIZ networks.


Internal Coordination


Supporting alignment between the GIZ Representation in Brussels, GIZ Headquarters, and other relevant teams involved in the co-Presidency.



Candidate Profile
Essential Qualifications


A MasterΓÇÖs degree in European Affairs, Political Science, International Relations, International Cooperation, or a related field.


At least one year of professional experience in development or international cooperation, ideally within EU-focused institutional environments.


One year of experience in project management, event organisation, or communication.


Strong understanding of European cooperation, EU external action policies, and the German international cooperation system.


Professional experience in Brussels linked to EU external action.


Excellent written and spoken English; good command of German.


A valid work permit for Belgium.


Core Competencies
Candidates should demonstrate excellent teamwork, coordination, analytical thinking, and communication skills. Strong political judgement, diplomatic ability, and the capacity to synthesise complex policy content are essential. Flexibility, autonomy, problem-solving skills, and a proactive approach to responsibilities are also key.
Additional Assets
Experience with the PractitionersΓÇÖ Network or with GIZ is an advantage, as is proficiency in additional EU languages.

What GIZ Offers
The position is based in BrusselsΓÇÖ European Quarter under a 30-month contract. The compensation package includes a competitive salary determined by experience, five additional holidays per year, lunch vouchers, complementary hospitalisation insurance, transport subsidies, and a home-office policy.

How to Apply
Applicants must submit an updated CV and a one-page cover letter explaining their motivation, salary expectations, and availability. Only complete applications that meet all requirements will be considered.

Geneva Global Senior Program Manager: Lead High-Impact Education Initiatives in Ethiopia

Geneva Global (GGI)ΓÇöa Certified B Corporation and part of Global Impact VenturesΓÇöis inviting applications for the role of Senior Program Manager. This is a unique opportunity for professionals who want to make an impact in global education, working within a mission-driven organization committed to improving lives through effective philanthropy.
GGI serves as a strategic advisor, thought partner, and implementing organization for philanthropists, NGOs, development agencies, and corporations worldwide. With a strong reputation for delivering customized strategies and impactful programs, the organization supports initiatives across sectors, including a growing portfolio of education programs in East Africa.

About the Role at Geneva Global
The Senior Program Manager will play a central role in managing a new, high-visibility secondary education and skills program in Ethiopia. This program aims to enhance the relevance and quality of secondary education, helping students transition successfully to tertiary studies or the workforce. The initiative strengthens implementation of the competency-based curriculum, equipping students with essential knowledge, skills, and attitudes.
The ideal candidate brings extensive experience in education programming, program management, and cross-cultural collaboration. As part of the broader education portfolio, the Senior Program Manager will also support additional programs in Ethiopia, Uganda, and potentially other countries.
This position reports to GGIΓÇÖs Director of Programs/Education Team Lead in the US and collaborates closely with both headquarters and the in-country team.

Key Responsibilities
Program Support and Management (70%)
The bulk of your responsibility will involve supporting and overseeing the implementation of the secondary education and skills program in Ethiopia. This includes:


Providing continuous operational support to country teams across regions of implementation.


Supporting strategic planning of project activities, budgeting, financial management, and grantmaking activities to ensure alignment with agreement terms.


Overseeing monitoring and evaluation, reporting, program operations, and partner coordination.


Mobilizing and coordinating technical expertise, guidance, and solutions for program design, planning, implementation, and assessment.


Managing collaboration with HR, Accounting, Operations teams, and in-country legal counsel to ensure effective financial management, reporting, personnel processes, and grant disbursement.


Supervising HQ-based interns working on program management and related tasks.


Donor Support (10%)


Assisting country teams in preparing reports for funders and consortium partners, particularly regarding program implementation and impact.


Supporting GGI leadership in maintaining strong client relationships.


Business Development & Marketing (10%)


Identifying new funding sources and supporting proposal development for existing and new education initiatives.


Producing case studies, blogs, and articles to highlight GGIΓÇÖs work and elevate organizational visibility.


Participating in conferences and professional forums to support business development and institutional outreach.


Organizational & Technical Support (10%)


Providing cross-departmental support to other GGI and GIV teams.


Contributing to onboarding processes for new staff.


Participating in internal committees on business development, employee experience, strategy, and organizational systems.



Qualifications
Candidates should embody GGIΓÇÖs culture of collaboration, human kindness, creativity, and commitment to high impact. Required qualifications include:


Minimum seven years of international development program management experience.


Strong background in secondary education and skills programming.


Expertise in program design, planning, monitoring, and evaluation in international education.


Budgeting and financial management skills, including strong Excel proficiency.


Experience working with international donors, foundations, corporations, and NGOs.


Grants and project management experience.


Advanced degree in international education or a related field, or equivalent experience.


Experience working in developing-country contexts.


Knowledge of a second language.


Strong proficiency in Microsoft Office and ideally other publishing, grants management, or data analysis tools.


Willingness to travel internationally up to 25% annually.



Working at Geneva Global
Geneva Global fosters a workplace that values inclusivity, collaboration, and community. Employees benefit from:


A salary range of $93,000ΓÇô$103,000, depending on experience.


16 paid holidays, 25 paid days off, and a comprehensive benefits package.


Parental leave, medical, dental, disability coverage, and a robust 401K program.


Flexibility for fully remote work or a hybrid model for those near Philadelphia.


A complete application includes a cover letter, r├⌐sum├⌐, and a writing sample demonstrating your ability to present information clearly and persuasively.

Nkabom Collaborative Short Course Programme in Livestock Production for Young People in Ghana

The Fully Funded Nkabom Collaborative Short Course Programme is a practical, in-person training opportunity designed to equip young people with hands-on skills to build sustainable livelihoods through agriculture, nutrition, and innovation. This short course programme focuses on real-world agricultural practices, with a strong emphasis on livestock production, and aims to empower participants to transform their lives and communities using practical, employable skills.
This Fully Funded Short Course Programme will be delivered as a two-week intensive training and will take place in selected locations across Greater Accra, Central, and Eastern Regions of Ghana. Training sessions are scheduled between February and May 2026, with exact dates and venues communicated directly to successful applicants.

Introduction and Background of the Fully Funded Short Course Programme
The Fully Funded Short Course Programme was developed to address the growing need for practical, skills-based training for young people interested in agriculture and sustainable livelihoods. Rather than focusing on theory alone, the programme prioritises hands-on learning, innovation, and entrepreneurship within the agricultural value chain.
This short course programme is particularly suited for young people seeking practical agricultural skills that can lead to self-employment, agribusiness opportunities, or community-based impact. The programme also places strong emphasis on nutrition, health-related practices, and innovation, ensuring that participants gain holistic knowledge applicable to real-world agricultural challenges.
All information submitted during the application process is treated with strict confidentiality, and applicants are assessed to ensure proper placement and effective planning of logistics and learning outcomes.

Eligibility Criteria for the Fully Funded Short Course Programme
To apply for the Fully Funded Short Course Programme, applicants must meet the following eligibility requirements:


Applicants must be 34 years old or below at the time of application


The programme is open to young people interested in agriculture, nutrition, and innovation


Women, persons with disabilities, internally displaced persons, and other underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged to apply


Applicants must be available to attend a two-week, in-person training programme


Training locations are within Greater Accra, Central, and Eastern Regions of Ghana, and applicants should be willing to attend sessions in these regions



Programme Details: Structure, Location, Duration, and Funding
The Fully Funded Short Course Programme is structured as an intensive two-week in-person training. The programme is designed to combine classroom learning with practical, hands-on sessions to ensure participants gain applicable skills.
Programme Duration


Two weeks (intensive format)


Training Period


February ΓÇô May 2026


Training Locations


Greater Accra Region


Central Region


Eastern Region


Specific training venues and dates will be communicated to successful applicants after selection, based on the course chosen and programme placement.
Funding


The programme is fully funded, meaning participants do not pay training fees



Short Course Areas
The current short course offering under this programme focuses on:
Livestock Production


Poultry Production


Small Ruminants Production


These areas are selected to provide participants with market-relevant agricultural skills that can support income generation, food security, and community development.

Training Outcomes of the Fully Funded Short Course Programme
Participants in the Fully Funded Short Course Programme will gain:


Hands-on, practical skills in modern agriculture, nutrition, and health-related practices


Entrepreneurial skills for agribusiness development


Employable skills applicable to agriculture and community-based projects


The ability to apply digital and innovative tools to improve productivity and livelihoods


Knowledge that supports sustainable agriculture and income generation


The programme is designed not only to build technical skills but also to strengthen participantsΓÇÖ capacity to create impact within their communities.

How to Apply for the Fully Funded Short Course Programme
Applications for the Fully Funded Short Course Programme are submitted through an online application form. The form serves as the official application and is used to assess eligibility, plan logistics, and tailor the training to participant needs.
Applicants are required to complete all relevant sections of the form accurately. The information provided will be used solely for programme purposes and handled confidentially.

Important Dates and Application Deadline


Application Deadline: 31st January 2026


Training Period: February ΓÇô May 2026


Applicants are encouraged to apply early to ensure consideration and effective placement within the programme.

Application Portal

Why Apply for the Fully Funded Short Course Programme?
The Fully Funded Short Course Programme offers a unique opportunity for young people to gain practical agricultural skills, develop entrepreneurial capacity, and build sustainable livelihoods through livestock production. With its hands-on approach, fully funded structure, and focus on inclusive participation, this short course programme provides a strong foundation for youth interested in agriculture, innovation, and community transformation.
By participating in this programme, young people can acquire real-world skills that support productivity, employment, and long-term impact within GhanaΓÇÖs agricultural sector.

Alexander von Humboldt Foundation ΓÇô International Climate Protection Fellowship 2026

The International Climate Protection Fellowship, offered by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, supports future leaders and postdoctoral researchers from non-European developing and transition countries who are committed to advancing climate protection and climate-related resource conservation. This prestigious fellowship enables selected applicants to conduct a 12ΓÇô24-month research project in Germany, collaborating with leading institutions, experts, and practitioners.
Applications for the 2026 intake close on 10 February 2026.

About the Fellowship
The program supports:

Prospective leaders working practically in climate action (12-month stay)
Postdoctoral researchers with climate-related expertise (12ΓÇô24 months)

Research proposals must address:

Climate change mitigation or adaptation
Preservation of ecosystems and biodiversity
Sustainable ocean and marine resource use
Sustainability topics (natural resources, resource efficiency, urban development)

The fellowship is funded by the International Climate Initiative (IKI) of GermanyΓÇÖs Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK), in collaboration with BMUV and the Federal Foreign Office.
The program awards:

Up to 15 fellowships for prospective leaders
Up to 5 fellowships for postdocs each year

The Foundation strongly encourages applications from women and underrepresented groups, and welcomes applicants of any social, cultural, or educational background.

Program Benefits
Fellows receive a comprehensive support package, including:
Monthly Fellowship

Γé¼2,500 / Γé¼2,800 / Γé¼3,000 (prospective leaders, depending on experience)
Γé¼3,000 (postdocs)

Additional Support

Mobility allowance
Travel expenses
Subsidy for private health and liability insurance
Family allowances for accompanying partners and children
Optional 1ΓÇô2 month intensive German language course in Bonn
Funding for hosts: Γé¼800/month (STEM fields) or Γé¼500/month (social sciences & humanities)

Exclusive Program Components

3-week introductory seminar across Germany
Annual meeting and official reception
Two-week study tour
Closing seminar in Berlin
Long-term alumni support to strengthen collaboration with German partners


Eligibility Requirements
General Criteria
Applicants must:

Be citizens of a non-European developing or transition country
Have lived and worked in one of these countries for the last 18 months (not abroad more than 90 days)
Demonstrate leadership experience
Have strong English and/or German proficiency

Prospective Leaders (Practitioners)

First university degree completed within the last 12 years (by 10 Feb 2026)
At least 24 months of practical professional experience in climate-related fields
OR
A MasterΓÇÖs degree + at least 12 months of relevant experience

Postdoctoral Researchers

First university degree completed within the last 12 years
Doctorate completed within the last 4 years (or completed by Aug 31, 2026)
Academic publications in internationally reviewed outlets

Proposal & Host Requirements

A research-based project aligned with climate protection or resource conservation
A confirmed host in Germany, including a mentoring agreement
Two recent letters of recommendation


Selection Process
Timeline

Application Deadline: 10 February 2026
Selection Meeting: September 2026
Fellowship Start: January/February 2027 (German language course)
Research Stay: April 2027 ΓÇô February 2028

Selection Criteria

Academic/professional achievements
Proven leadership skills
Quality and innovation of the research proposal
Relevance of topic to climate protection
Long-term potential to create impact


How to Apply
Applications must be submitted online via the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation portal.
Required documents:

Online application form + letter of motivation
Research project proposal & communication strategy
Two letters of recommendation
HostΓÇÖs statement & mentoring agreement
Relevant certificates and supporting documents

Applicants are encouraged to apply early to allow referees and hosts adequate time to submit their materials.

Why Apply?
This fellowship offers an unparalleled opportunity to:

Work with leading global experts in climate protection
Build international networks and long-term collaborations
Gain professional recognition and leadership experience
Contribute to climate solutions with global impact
Access post-fellowship alumni funding to continue your work


For more information about Program: Click Here
The post Alexander von Humboldt Foundation ΓÇô International Climate Protection Fellowship 2026 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
GETFund Postgraduate Local Scholarships 2025/2026: Applications Now Open

The Ghana Education Trust Fund (GETFund) has officially opened applications for the 2025/26 Postgraduate Local Scholarship Programme, offering funding support for MasterΓÇÖs and PhD studies within Ghana. This flagship initiative forms part of GETFundΓÇÖs commitment to developing 21st-century human capital by investing in high-level professional education for Ghanaians.
Application Timeline

Opening date: Tuesday, 20th January 2026
Closing date: Friday, 20th February 2026

Applications are accepted exclusively online through the GETFund Scholarship Portal. No emailed, posted, or hand-delivered applications will be processed.

About the Scholarship Programme
Education is key to national development, and GETFund continues to strengthen GhanaΓÇÖs human resource capacity through targeted investments in postgraduate education. The scholarship programme provides financial, academic, and social support, including tuition, accommodation, and learning materials for selected scholars.
The 2025/26 academic call supports local postgraduate studiesΓÇöMasterΓÇÖs and PhD programmesΓÇöat accredited Ghanaian tertiary institutions.

Eligibility Criteria
To qualify, applicants must:
General Requirements

Be a Ghanaian citizen.
Have gained admission into a MasterΓÇÖs or PhD programme for the 2025/26 academic year.
Hold a first degree with at least a Second Class (for MasterΓÇÖs applicants).
Be ready to begin academic studies at the start of the academic year.
Not be currently pursuing a MasterΓÇÖs or PhD degree at the time of applying.
Not be a previous GETFund foreign scholarship beneficiary applying for the same category.

NOT Eligible

All PWDs in public tertiary institutions (however, PWDs may apply under the Students Loan Trust Fund Government PWD Support Initiative).


Required Documents
Academic Documents

Admission letter (Unconditional or Financial Condition only)
Official fee schedule
Previous academic certificates
Transcripts
Research or project proposal (max. 5 pages ΓÇô for MasterΓÇÖs/PhD applicants)

Supporting Documents

Curriculum Vitae (CV)
Academic refereesΓÇÖ letters
Occupational recommendation letter
Employer release letter (if applicable)
Ghana Card
Passport bio-data page
National Service certificate (where applicable)


Special Consideration
Priority may be given to applicants studying in:

STEM disciplines
TVET programmes
Special needs education
National priority program areas
Tuition-free universities
Lecturers under GTEC
Persons with disabilities


Application Procedure
Step 1: Apply Online
Visit the official GETFund Scholarship Portal:
Step 2: Create and Verify Your Profile
Register, verify your account, and log in.
Step 3: Complete the Online Form
Fill in personal and academic details and upload all required documentation.
Step 4: Review and Submit
Ensure your application is accurate and complete before submitting.
Step 5: Await Feedback
All communicationΓÇöincluding vetting status, shortlisting, and instructionsΓÇöwill be sent via email and SMS.
Note: All correspondence is strictly between GETFund and the applicant. GETFund has not appointed any agents; report intermediaries to the nearest police station.

Important Reminder
Applications submitted only through the portal will be processed. Ensure all uploaded documents are clear, accurate, and complete.

For more information: Click Here
The post GETFund Postgraduate Local Scholarships 2025/2026: Applications Now Open appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

Journalism Science Alliance Investigative Journalism Grants 2026 | European Union-Funded Journalism Grants for JournalistΓÇôScientist Teams

The Journalism Science Alliance Investigative Journalism Grants 2026 are now open, offering a major funding opportunity for journalists and scientists across Europe to collaborate on investigative journalism projects backed by scientific evidence. Co-funded by the European Union, this grant programme supports high-quality investigative journalism that addresses issues of public interest and produces meaningful local, regional, and transnational impact.
The Journalism Science Alliance grants are designed to strengthen collaboration between media outlets and research institutions, ensuring that investigative reporting is grounded in credible scientific research. Following a successful first call in 2025, the 2026 call will award an additional Γé¼1 million in grants to selected journalistΓÇôscientist teams.

Introduction and Background of the Journalism Science Alliance Grants
The Journalism Science Alliance (JSA) was established to bridge the gap between journalism and science by funding investigative projects that rely on rigorous scientific evidence. In an era of misinformation, declining media freedom, and complex global challenges, the Alliance aims to reinforce public-interest journalism through cross-sector collaboration.
The 2026 Journalism Science Alliance grants build on the success of the 2025 call, which supported 24 investigative projects from 15 countries, distributing nearly Γé¼1 million in funding. With a continued focus on transparency, independence, and merit-based selection, the programme offers journalists and scientists the opportunity to work together over an eight-month period to produce impactful investigations.

Eligibility Criteria for the Journalism Science Alliance Grants 2026
The Journalism Science Alliance grants are open to journalistΓÇôscientist teams that meet the following eligibility requirements:
Who Can Apply

Journalists working in any media format, including:

Print journalism
Broadcast journalism
Digital journalism
Multimedia projects
Documentary journalism


Scientists and researchers from any relevant discipline may participate as co-investigators.

Team Composition Requirements
Each application must include:

At least one media outlet as the lead applicant
At least one research or academic institution as the co-lead applicant

Freelancers and additional partners may join the team but cannot apply independently.
Definition of Eligible Institutions

A media outlet is a legally registered organisation or platform that distributes news or information to the public, including newspapers, television stations, radio stations, and digital news platforms.
A research institution is a legally registered public or private organisation engaged in systematic research, such as universities, government laboratories, independent research centres, or nonprofit research organisations.

Eligible Countries
Applicants must be based in a country participating in the Creative Europe Programme. Eligible countries include:

All 27 European Union (EU) member states
Non-EU countries: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Norway, Serbia, and Ukraine


Journalism Science Alliance Grant Programme Details
Funding Amount and Duration

Total budget for the 2026 call: Γé¼1,000,000
Grant duration: 8 months

Grant Tiers
Applicants may request funding under one of three tiers, depending on project scope and complexity:

Γé¼10,000 ΓÇô Tier 1
Γé¼20,000 ΓÇô Tier 2
Γé¼50,000 ΓÇô Tier 3

The grant amount should reflect the complexity of the investigation, number of partners involved, proposed tasks, and project timeline.
Project Scope and Focus
Funded projects must:

Be investigative journalism projects backed by scientific evidence
Address topics of public interest
Demonstrate local, regional, or transnational impact
Be relevant to European audiences, even when addressing global issues


Additional Benefits for Selected Teams
Beyond financial support, successful applicants to the Journalism Science Alliance grants will receive:

Tailored mentorship throughout the project period
Access to training sessions
Opportunities to participate in networking events with other funded teams

All grants are awarded through a transparent and independent jury process, free from donor influence and based solely on the merit of each proposal.

How to Apply for the Journalism Science Alliance Grants 2026
Applications must be:

Submitted in English
Completed and submitted through the European Journalism Center (EJC) Platform

Applicants are required to provide detailed information about their investigative project, team structure, proposed methodology, and expected impact. Teams should ensure that their proposal clearly demonstrates collaboration between journalism and scientific research.

Important Dates and Deadlines

Opening Date: 19 January 2026
Application Deadline: 23 March 2026 at 17:00 CET

Late applications will not be considered.

Why Apply for the Journalism Science Alliance Grants
The Journalism Science Alliance Investigative Journalism Grants 2026 offer a unique opportunity for journalists and scientists to collaborate on evidence-based investigative reporting. With substantial funding, professional mentorship, and a strong emphasis on public-interest journalism, the programme supports impactful investigations that contribute to informed public discourse across Europe.
By fostering partnerships between media and research institutions, the Journalism Science Alliance continues to strengthen the quality, credibility, and reach of investigative journalism grounded in science.

Application Portal

For more opportunities visit Opportunities for youth
The post Journalism Science Alliance Investigative Journalism Grants 2026 | European Union-Funded Journalism Grants for JournalistΓÇôScientist Teams appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Erasmus+ Call for Proposals 2026 Opens: Γé¼4.47 Billion Funding for Education, Youth, Training, and Sport

The European Commission has officially launched the Erasmus+ Call for Proposals 2026 (EAC/A12/2025) under the Erasmus+ Programme 2021ΓÇô2027. With a total estimated budget of Γé¼4.47 billion, the 2026 call supports education, training, youth, and sport initiatives through learning mobility, cooperation partnerships, innovation, and policy development.
This call is open to public and private organisations, universities, NGOs, youth organisations, informal youth groups, and international partners across eligible countries.
Erasmus+ Actions Covered in the 2026 Call
Key Action 1 (KA1): Learning Mobility of Individuals
KA1 supports international learning mobility for students, staff, and young people.
Submission Deadlines (Brussels Time):


Mobility of individuals in higher education19 February 2026 at 12:00


Mobility of individuals in VET, school education, and adult education19 February 2026 at 12:00


International mobility involving third countries not associated with the programme19 February 2026 at 12:00


Mobility of staff in the field of sport12 February 2026 at 12:00


Mobility of individuals in the field of youth12 February 2026 at 12:00associated call:1 October 2026 at 12:00


DiscoverEU Inclusion Action12 February 2026 at 12:00


Erasmus+ Virtual Exchanges26 March 2026 at 17:00


Erasmus Accreditations in VET, school education, and adult education29 September 2026 at 12:00


Erasmus Accreditations in the field of youth29 September 2026 at 12:00


Key Action 2 (KA2): Cooperation Among Organisations and Institutions
KA2 supports partnerships, innovation, and capacity-building initiatives.
Submission Deadlines (Brussels Time):


Cooperation Partnerships (education, training & youth ΓÇô non-European NGOs)5 March 2026 at 12:00


Cooperation Partnerships (education, training & youth ΓÇô European NGOs)5 March 2026 at 17:00


Cooperation Partnerships in the field of sport5 March 2026 at 17:00

Erasmus+ Call for Proposals 2026 Opens: Γé¼4.47 Billion Funding for Education, Youth, Training, and Sport

The European Commission has officially launched the Erasmus+ Call for Proposals 2026 (EAC/A12/2025) under the Erasmus+ Programme 2021ΓÇô2027. With a total estimated budget of Γé¼4.47 billion, the 2026 call supports education, training, youth, and sport initiatives through learning mobility, cooperation partnerships, innovation, and policy development.
This call is open to public and private organisations, universities, NGOs, youth organisations, informal youth groups, and international partners across eligible countries.
Erasmus+ Actions Covered in the 2026 Call
Key Action 1 (KA1): Learning Mobility of Individuals
KA1 supports international learning mobility for students, staff, and young people.

Global Affairs Canada (GAC) Opportunity: International Policy Ideas Challenge (IPIC) 2026 ΓÇô Call for Proposals

Global Affairs Canada (GAC), in partnership with the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC), has launched the ninth edition of the International Policy Ideas Challenge (IPIC). This annual initiative invites emerging Canadian researchers to propose innovative, evidence-based solutions to pressing international policy issues affecting Canada.
The program is designed to help graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early-career civil society researchers translate academic expertise into practical policy insights for the Government of Canada.

About the Challenge
The IPIC program seeks concrete, forward-looking policy ideas addressing CanadaΓÇÖs foreign policy, international trade, and international assistance priorities. Applicants are invited to submit short proposals; GAC will select 5ΓÇô10 winning submissions, each receiving:

$5,000 financial award
Coaching and mentorship from subject-matter experts
Training in policy analysis, briefing, and presentation
The opportunity to present a full policy brief to Government of Canada officials in December 2026

Winning proposals will be refined into complete policy briefs with actionable recommendations, supported by four structured coaching sessions delivered online throughout 2026.

Who Can Apply
The Challenge is open to:
Eligible applicants

Canadian citizens or permanent residents
Current MasterΓÇÖs or PhD students, or postdoctoral fellows at recognized Canadian or international universities
Researchers at Canadian non-profit organizations, within six years of completing a graduate degree

Not eligible

Indeterminate or term employees of the Government of Canada
Employees, students, or casual workers at Global Affairs Canada
Teams without a designated lead researcher

Team applications
Teams of up to three members may apply. All members must meet eligibility criteria.

Financial Award
Each of the 5ΓÇô10 selected proposals will receive:
≡ƒÆ░ $5,000 (awarded to the lead researcher upon submission and presentation of the final brief)

Coaching & Professional Development
Winners will participate in four mandatory coaching/mentoring sessions (online, JuneΓÇôSeptember 2026):

Two-day group session ΓÇô Introduction to Canadian foreign policy and GAC priorities
Individual session (1ΓÇô2 hrs) ΓÇô Feedback on early brief concepts
Follow-up individual session (1ΓÇô2 hrs) ΓÇô Review of draft brief
Half-day group session ΓÇô Presentation practice

Winners will also receive guidance materials, including resources on preparing policy briefs and effective presentations.

Research Themes
Proposals must address at least one of the following four policy themes:
1. Protecting Canadian sovereignty and security in a changing world
Areas may include CanadaΓÇôU.S. relations, Arctic sovereignty, emerging tech security (AI, quantum), NORAD modernization, and critical infrastructure protection.
2. Ensuring prosperity and economic resilience through trade and investment
Topics may explore trade diversification, strengthening partnerships with trusted allies, and leveraging trade and development finance for inclusive growth.
3. CanadaΓÇÖs role in multilateral engagement and global governance
Possible issues include UN/WTO reform, cooperation with middle powers, or participation in issue-based coalitions on climate, digital governance, or humanitarian response.
4. Innovating international assistance and future aid architecture
Proposals may explore aligning aid with foreign policy goals, reforming global aid systems, or strengthening CanadaΓÇÖs contributions to development cooperation.

Proposal Requirements
Proposal submissions must:

Not exceed 750 words
Clearly indicate the selected theme(s)
Explain the issueΓÇÖs relevance to CanadaΓÇÖs foreign policy, security, and prosperity
Outline methodology and evidence-gathering approaches
Provide preliminary policy recommendations
Identify relevant actors (organizations, regions, partners)
Demonstrate originality and feasibility

Final policy briefs (due Fall 2026) must be max 3,500 words, with a one-page executive summary.

Application Process
Submit the following documents as PDF attachments to
IPIC-CIPI.OIH-POA@international.gc.ca
Required materials

Proposal (max 750 words), signed, with name in upper-right corner
Curriculum Vitae (with contact information)
Proof of enrolment or most recent graduate degree
One confidential reference letter, emailed directly by referee
Short biography of lead researcher and collaborators

Only complete applications will be reviewed.

Timeline



Stage
Date




Call for proposals launch
January 19, 2026


Application deadline
March 2, 2026


Assessment period
MarchΓÇôApril 2026


Selection of 5ΓÇô10 winners
April 2026


Announcement of winners
May 2026


Coaching sessions
JuneΓÇôSeptember 2026


Final policy briefs due
Early Fall 2026


Presentation to Government of Canada
December 2026




Additional Notes

Proposals must be original work; applicants must disclose any use of generative AI.
Primary research is optional; strong secondary research is acceptable given timelines.
Applicants may submit multiple proposals, but may win only one award.
Previous winning projects are available on the International Policy Ideas Challenge website for inspiration.


For more information: Click Here

Global Youth Action Fund by International Baccalaureate (IB) ΓÇô Global Grant Funding Opportunity for Young Changemakers Worldwide

The Global Youth Action Fund is a global grant opportunity designed to empower young people to take meaningful action on some of the worldΓÇÖs most pressing challenges. Launched in 2023 by the International Baccalaureate (IB), the Global Youth Action Fund provides financial support and capacity-building opportunities to youth-led projects that are driving positive social, environmental, and economic change across communities worldwide.
The Global Youth Action Fund is built on the belief that young people are not just future leaders, but active change-makers today. By supporting youth aged 12 to 19, the fund enables students to transform innovative ideas into tangible impact, while fostering leadership, collaboration, and global citizenship. Since its launch, the Global Youth Action Fundhas already supported over 290 projects led by more than 440 young people across different regions of the world.

Introduction and Background of the Global Youth Action Fund
The Global Youth Action Fund was created to provide young people with the resources, mentorship, and global platform needed to turn purpose-driven ideas into action. Coordinated by the International Baccalaureate, the fund supports youth initiatives that align with one or more of the 17 United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
Projects supported by the Global Youth Action Fund span diverse themes such as climate action, gender equality, education access, health, digital inclusion, and community development. Whether a student is addressing environmental sustainability in Asia, social justice in Africa, or digital literacy in Latin America, the Global Youth Action Fund serves as a catalyst for youth-led solutions with both local relevance and global significance.
Each application is evaluated by an international panel of experts, including educators, youth leaders, and professionals, ensuring a transparent and merit-based selection process.

Benefits of the Global Youth Action Fund
Students selected under the Global Youth Action Fund receive both financial and non-financial support aimed at strengthening their projects and leadership capacity. Key benefits include:

Grant funding of up to USD 3,000, depending on project needs and committee decisions
Mentorship and guidance from leaders in social entrepreneurship and youth development
Global networking opportunities with other youth awardees from around the world
Capacity-building programming focused on leadership, sustainability, and project management

The Global Youth Action Fund focuses not only on funding but also on long-term learning and impact, ensuring that supported projects are sustainable and scalable.

Eligibility Criteria for the Global Youth Action Fund
To be eligible for the Global Youth Action Fund, applicants must meet the following criteria:

Be between 12 and 19 years old at the time of application
Be enrolled in a secondary school at the application deadline
Applicants do not need to attend an IB World School
Open to students worldwide, regardless of nationality or country of residence
Applications may be submitted by individual students or groups, although collaboration is strongly encouraged

The Global Youth Action Fund is inclusive and welcomes applications from students both within and outside the IB community.

Program Details: Structure, Duration, and Scope
The Global Youth Action Fund 2026 cycle follows a structured timeline designed to support students throughout their project journey.

Type of opportunity: Grant funding and youth leadership programme
Funding amount: Up to USD 3,000 per project
Program duration: January 2026 ΓÇô December 2026
Project focus: Must align with at least one UN SDG

Selected projects receive funding in May 2026, followed by structured programming, mentorship, and reflection sessions until the end of the year.

Application Requirements and Process
Applications for the Global Youth Action Fund must be submitted online and include the following components:

Completed Application Form submitted through the Submittable platform
Pitch Deck (maximum 8 slides) outlining:

Applicant(s) introduction
Problem being addressed
Proposed solution
Use of funds and sustainability plan


Recorded Video Pitch (maximum 3 minutes) explaining the project and motivation
School Support Recommendation, completed by a school staff member

Applications without all required components or submitted after the deadline will not be considered.

Important Dates and Deadlines
The Global Youth Action Fund 2026 application timeline is as follows:

Application Opens: 12 January 2026
Application Closes: 30 January 2026 (23:59 CET)
Deadline for School Sponsor Letters: 30 January 2026
Awardees Announced: 10 April 2026
Grant Released: May 2026
Student Programming Begins: June 2026
Programming Ends: December 2026

Applicants are encouraged to submit early, as late applications will not be accepted.

Why Apply to the Global Youth Action Fund
The Global Youth Action Fund is more than a grantΓÇöit is a global movement supporting youth leadership, innovation, and impact. By participating, students gain funding, mentorship, and international exposure while contributing to solutions that advance the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The program empowers young people to transform ideas into action and become active global citizens.

Apply for the Global Youth Action Fund
Application Portal

The Global Youth Action Fund by the International Baccalaureate is a unique global grant opportunity for secondary school students aged 12 to 19 who are ready to lead change. By providing funding, mentorship, and global connections, the Global Youth Action Fund enables young people worldwide to create sustainable impact and turn hope into action.

For more opportunities visit Opportunities for youth

fields.raw_text:
Cummins Cederberg Paid Summer Environmental Internships & Seasonal Associate Scientist Positions (Florida)

Cummins Cederberg, a leading coastal and marine engineering and environmental consulting firm, is now accepting applications for Paid Summer Environmental Interns and Seasonal Associate Scientists for the 2026 summer season. These roles offer immersive, hands-on experience in coastal and marine environmental work across multiple locations in Florida.
Application Deadline: January 31, 2026

About the Roles
Summer Environmental Intern
A paid learning-focused role designed for early-career marine science students seeking exposure to:

Benthic habitat assessments
Coral and seagrass monitoring
Environmental permitting and compliance
Fieldwork shadowing and office-based research
Data management and environmental reporting

Interns work under close supervision and receive mentorship in applied coastal and marine science.

Seasonal Associate Scientist
A field-focused seasonal position ideal for candidates with in-water survey experience. Responsibilities include:

Conducting benthic and coral habitat surveys
Participating in coral relocation and environmental compliance monitoring
Fieldwork in dynamic outdoor marine environments
Supporting technical reporting and resource documentation

This position requires stronger field experience and biological identification skills.

Locations
Positions are available across Florida:

Miami
Fort Lauderdale
Jupiter
St. Petersburg

Duration: May 1 ΓÇô October 31 (flexible)
Schedule: Full-time and part-time options

Key Responsibilities (Both Roles)

Conduct marine resource surveys (benthic mapping, coral relocation)
Assist with field equipment inventory and maintenance
Support environmental permitting research
Draft monitoring and technical reports
Perform data entry and project coordination tasks


Qualifications
Required for All Candidates

B.S. in Marine Biology or related field
Experience with in-water surveys (snorkel)
Knowledge of Florida benthic ecology (corals, seagrass)
Strong writing, communication, and organizational skills
Ability to work in challenging field conditions
Ability to lift 50 lbs & reliable transportation
CPR/First Aid & Oxygen Administration certification (or ability to obtain)
Team-oriented mindset


Additional Requirements for Seasonal Associate Scientists

Enrollment in or completion of a graduate program in marine biology or related field
SCUBA experience; scientific diving preferred
Dive log documenting dives from 2024ΓÇôpresent
Proficiency in identifying FloridaΓÇÖs protected resources
Ability to pass a dive physical


What YouΓÇÖll Gain

Paid hands-on field experience in applied marine and coastal science
Exposure to environmental permitting and regulatory processes
Mentorship from marine science professionals
Development of survey, writing, and project management skills
Opportunities for personal and professional growth


About the Culture at Cummins Cederberg
Cummins Cederberg places people first, prioritizing:

Trust
Innovation
Community
Collaboration
Integrity
Excellence

Employees enjoy:

Competitive pay
100% employer-paid health coverage
401(k) retirement plans
Flexible work environment
Career growth opportunities
Flexible time off (exempt employees)
Paid service days
Strong team culture


How to Apply
Interested candidates should submit their applications before:
Deadline: January 31, 2026
For more information and application instructions, visit the Cummins Cederberg careers page (search: Cummins Cederberg environmental internships).

ACT Foundation 2026 Grant Application | ACT Foundation Funding for High-Impact Community Development Projects in Africa

The ACT Foundation 2026 Grant Application is now open, offering a major funding opportunity for organizations working to deliver sustainable, high-impact solutions to AfricaΓÇÖs most pressing social, economic, and environmental challenges. In the first year of the 2026 grant cycle, the ACT Foundation continues its mission of strengthening communities across the continent through strategic grant funding, partnerships, and capacity-building support.
The ACT Foundation 2026 Grant focuses on empowering organizations whose work aligns with priority areas such as health, entrepreneurship, climate action, and sustainable livelihoods. Through this funding opportunity, the Foundation seeks to support scalable interventions that can reverse negative development trends and create long-term, systems-level change across African communities.

About the ACT Foundation 2026 Grant Opportunity
The ACT Foundation is committed to promoting broad-based participation and collaboration with civil society organizations, institutions, and donor partners. Through its annual grant cycles, the Foundation provides funding and hands-on guidance to ensure that grantees are not isolated during implementation.
The 2026 ACT Foundation Grant is designed to support organizations delivering innovative, community-driven solutions that address critical development gaps. A strong emphasis is placed on sustainability, scalability, and inclusion, particularly for marginalized and vulnerable populations such as women, rural youth, children, and persons with disabilities.
Rather than one-off interventions, the ACT Foundation prioritizes programs that leverage technology, partnerships, and community mobilization to drive long-term impact and measurable outcomes.

Focus Areas of the ACT Foundation 2026 Grant
1. Health
Africa continues to face a dual burden of disease, combining persistent maternal and child health challenges with a rising prevalence of non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Under the 2026 grant cycle, the ACT Foundation will support health interventions that improve access to care and strengthen health literacy among underserved populations.
Supported interventions include:

Community Health Screenings: Large-scale screening and referral programs for hypertension, diabetes, hepatitis, cancers, eye health, and other NCDs, implemented in partnership with health institutions.
Maternal and Child Health Initiatives: Community education campaigns, provision of safe delivery kits, malaria prevention during pregnancy, and interventions addressing pregnancy-induced conditions.

These programs should demonstrate potential for scale and community ownership.

2. Entrepreneurship and Youth Empowerment
With AfricaΓÇÖs youth population rapidly growing, unemployment remains a major challenge. The ACT Foundation 2026 Grant aims to foster entrepreneurship, innovation, and financial inclusion, particularly among youth-led and female-led enterprises.
Priority interventions include:

Support for Young and Female Entrepreneurs: Digital and vocational skills training linked to entrepreneurship pathways, seed funding for social enterprises, and access-to-finance initiatives combined with capacity building.
Financial Literacy Campaigns: Programs leveraging radio, digital platforms, and social media to improve financial awareness and responsible money management.
Climate and Renewable Energy Enterprises: Training youth and women to operate recycling businesses, waste-to-wealth initiatives, and climate-focused enterprises.
Micro-Farming and Sustainable Agriculture: Community-based interventions promoting sustainable agriculture and food security.

These entrepreneurship-focused programs should demonstrate clear economic impact, community benefit, and sustainability.

Eligibility Criteria: Who Can Apply for the ACT Foundation 2026 Grant?
The ACT Foundation 2026 Grant is open to organizations whose work aligns with the FoundationΓÇÖs priority areas. While the Foundation does not restrict applications by country in the provided information, the focus remains on Africa-based or Africa-focused initiatives.
Key eligibility considerations include:

Applicants must be organizations or institutions capable of implementing community-based development programs.
Proposed projects must align with one or more of the ACT FoundationΓÇÖs focus areas (Health or Entrepreneurship).
Programs must demonstrate scalability, sustainability, and inclusion of marginalized groups such as women, rural youth, children, and persons with disabilities.
Collaboration with partners and use of technology to achieve scale are strongly encouraged.

Applicants are advised to be intentional about designing interventions that address systemic challenges rather than short-term outcomes.

Program Details: Structure, Duration, and Funding

Grant Cycle: 2026
Application Window: 19 January 2026 ΓÇô 30 January 2026
Closing Time: 11:59 pm (WAT)
Funding Type: Grant funding for program implementation
Support Structure: Financial grants combined with guidance and partnership support throughout implementation

The ACT Foundation emphasizes partnership-based implementation, ensuring that grantees receive not only funding but also strategic support during the grant lifecycle.

How to Apply for the ACT Foundation 2026 Grant
Organizations interested in the ACT Foundation 2026 Grant must complete their application within the stated deadline. Applicants are encouraged to carefully review the FoundationΓÇÖs priorities and design proposals that clearly demonstrate impact, sustainability, and inclusion.
Applications are submitted online via the ACT FoundationΓÇÖs official platform.

Important Dates and Deadline

Application Opens: 19 January 2026
Application Closes: 30 January 2026
Deadline Time: 11:59 pm (WAT)

Late applications will not be considered.

Application Portal

┬áACT Foundation 2026 Grant for Sustainable African Development
The ACT Foundation 2026 Grant represents a significant opportunity for organizations committed to health improvement, entrepreneurship, and sustainable community development in Africa. By prioritizing scalable, inclusive, and innovative programs, the ACT Foundation continues to play a critical role in supporting interventions that can transform lives and strengthen systems across the continent.
Organizations with bold ideas, strong partnerships, and a commitment to long-term impact are encouraged to apply and become part of a growing network of change-makers driving AfricaΓÇÖs development forward.

For more opportunities visit Opportunities for youth.
