fields.raw_text:
LLCU University: Senior Front-End Wordpress Developer ΓÇô Tailwind Specialist

Headquarters: Florida
    URL: https://www.llcuniversity.com/


About the Role:
We're looking for a senior front-end developer who cares about clean code, loves solving complex puzzles, and has a great eye for design. This role is for a full redesign of our website ΓÇö not client work, not multiple sites.
YouΓÇÖll turn our Figma design into a custom WordPress site ΓÇö no page builders, just a thoughtful, performant, hand-coded theme. We'll launch the new design component-by-component to the live site, so youΓÇÖll work closely with our team to build and ship each part with care.
We use GitHub for version control. You should be confident in CSS, Tailwind CSS, PHP, JavaScript, and HTML. If you have an eye for detail and care about helping people through your work, weΓÇÖd love to meet you.
(Note: We don't need/use JS frameworks like React, Vue.js, etc.)
What does the work look like?
WeΓÇÖre looking for a front-end developer to work in between our design & tech teams. Our current project is a major redesign, which still has a lot of logic to code. After that, you could be working on any number of projects, from interactive tools built from scratch (ex: an Operating Agreement generator) to internal tools for the content team.┬á
As a first step, youΓÇÖll get a full walkthrough of whatΓÇÖs been built so far. You might review or audit the code, and youΓÇÖll be part of the brainstorming and problem-solving process. YouΓÇÖll also help us figure out exactly what work still needs to be done.
Key Responsibilities:


Turn detailed Figma designs into a responsive, accessible, and fully functional WordPress site


Write clean, efficient, and maintainable code using CSS, PHP, JavaScript and HTML.


Make sure everything works across browsers and runs fast


Work closely with our designer, back-end developer, founder, and SEO strategist to get every detail right ΓÇö we care deeply about doing great work


Help improve how we build things by refining our process and sharing ideas


Required Skills & Qualifications:


10+ years of front-end WordPress experience


Expert at turning Figma designs into custom WordPress themes


Strong in CSS, PHP, JavaScript and HTML.


Vast experience using Tailwind CSS in real-world projects


Strong proficiency in CSS and modern layout techniques (Flexbox, Grid, etc.)


Deep understanding of responsive and adaptive design


3+ years using Git for version control


Clear and thoughtful communication in English ΓÇö written and spoken


Willing to have honest, open, even though conversations when needed ΓÇö we care about trust and doing great work together


A strong culture fit ΓÇö we're a kind, friendly team that cares about details, good communication, and helping each other do our best work


Personal Traits:


You have a growth mindset and love learning new things to keep improving your craft


You bring a positive attitude, take initiative, and enjoy solving tough problems


YouΓÇÖre comfortable working as part of a team and independently ΓÇö we work on the Eastern Time zone.


Note: We do lots of video calls and screensharing for brainstorming and troubleshooting.


Why Join Us?


Collaborate on high-impact projects with a passionate, supportive team.


Embrace a culture that values positivity, growth, and professional excellence.


Enjoy flexibility, autonomy, and opportunities to grow your skillset.



To apply: https://weworkremotely.com/remote-jobs/llcu-university-senior-front-end-wordpress-developer-tailwind-specialist

fields.raw_text:
Work with Children and Screens: Build a Healthier Digital Future for Children-2026

Children and Screens: Institute of Digital Media and Child Development is a globally respected nonprofit organization dedicated to helping children thrive in todayΓÇÖs digital world. As digital media becomes an increasingly powerful force in childrenΓÇÖs lives, the Institute works at the intersection of research, policy, education, and public awareness to ensure that technology supportsΓÇörather than harmsΓÇöchild development.
If you are passionate about child health, education, psychology, media, or public policy, working with Children and Screens offers a meaningful opportunity to make a real-world impact while collaborating with leading experts across disciplines.

A Mission-Driven Organization
Children and Screens is an independent 501(c)(3) organization committed to evidence-based, interdisciplinary, and nonpartisan work. The Institute is uniquely positioned as a trusted voice in conversations about children and digital media because it operates without funding from the technology industry. This independence allows the organization to produce unbiased research, practical tools, and policy-neutral insights that prioritize childrenΓÇÖs well-being above all else.
The organizationΓÇÖs mission is simple but powerful: to help children lead healthy lives in a digital world. Every initiativeΓÇöwhether research, public education, or professional trainingΓÇöis designed to translate scientific evidence into action that benefits families, educators, clinicians, and policymakers worldwide.

Careers at Children and Screens
Staff members at Children and Screens are united by a shared commitment to improving childrenΓÇÖs health, learning, and development in an increasingly digital environment. The organization offers a fully remote work environment, making it accessible to professionals from diverse geographic and professional backgrounds. Collaboration, intellectual rigor, and subject-matter expertise define the work culture.
Opportunities at Children and Screens may span research coordination, communications, program management, policy engagement, development, and administrative support. Team members work closely with researchers, clinicians, educators, and advocates to advance the InstituteΓÇÖs mission.

Important note for applicants:
Children and Screens accepts job applications exclusively via email at careers@childrenandscreens.org.
Any request to submit application materials through a different address should be treated as fraudulent.

Impact Fellowship and Professional Growth
In addition to staff roles, Children and Screens offers structured opportunities such as the Impact Fellowship, designed to engage motivated individuals who want hands-on experience in mission-driven work related to digital media and child development. These opportunities allow participants to contribute meaningfully while building professional skills in research translation, public engagement, and nonprofit operations.
Working or fellowshipping with Children and Screens means being part of an organization that values learning, ethical practice, and real-world impact.

Learn More and Stay Connected
Those interested in the organizationΓÇÖs work can explore a range of resources through its website, including pages on About, Learn and Explore, Events, and ongoing research initiatives. Children and Screens regularly hosts webinars, publishes expert insights, and shares practical tools to help families and professionals navigate childrenΓÇÖs digital media use.
To stay informed, individuals can sign up for email updates to receive the latest research findings, expert commentary, and actionable guidance on how digital media affects child development.

Make an Impact Beyond Employment
Even beyond career opportunities, supporters can contribute to the InstituteΓÇÖs mission by donating to support its work. Contributions help fund research, expand access to free educational resources, and strengthen evidence-based advocacy that improves childrenΓÇÖs health and well-being globally.
Apply and find more information from HERE

Organizational Details
Children and Screens is headquartered in New York, with offices at 276 5th Avenue, Suite 704, Box #900, New York, NY 10001. As a remote-friendly organization, its reach and impact extend far beyond physical boundaries.

Subscribe to OFY for more opportunities like thisΓÇª
The post Work with Children and Screens: Build a Healthier Digital Future for Children-2026 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Call for Expressions of Interest: Join the ECoWYERT Youth Advisory Group (2026ΓÇô2030)

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has opened a Call for Expressions of Interest for young leaders to join the Youth Advisory Group (YAG) of the Enhancing Capacities of Young Women and Youth-Led Enterprises for Regional Trade (ECoWYERT) project.
ECoWYERT is a five-year, multi-country initiative (2026ΓÇô2030) designed to strengthen the participation of youth- and women-led micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in cross-border trade under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA). The project is implemented by UNDP in partnership with the Mastercard Foundation, COMESA Federation for Women in Business (COMFWB), Trade and Development Fund (TDF), International Trade Centre (ITC), and the Better Than Cash Alliance (BTCA).
About the Youth Advisory Group (YAG)
The Youth Advisory Group will consist of eight dynamic young leaders aged 18ΓÇô35 who will work closely with the Project Steering Committee to provide strategic guidance, amplify youth voices, and ensure youth-inclusive approaches throughout the project lifecycle.
YAG members will contribute to:


Strategic input and advisory on project design, priorities, and outcomes


Co-creation and implementation of youth-focused tools, interventions, and campaigns


Representation and advocacy in national, regional, and continental AfCFTA-related platforms


Knowledge sharing and accountability, including monitoring, evaluation, and learning


Who Can Apply?
Applications are open to young people who:


Are 18ΓÇô35 years old


Are citizens of and resident in Africa, specifically from Botswana, DR Congo, Malawi, South Africa, Zambia, or Zimbabwe


Are actively involved in enterprise development, innovation, policy, advocacy, trade, or community development


Have experience or interest in AfCFTA, MSME development, cross-border trade, digital or financial inclusion, or womenΓÇÖs economic empowerment


Belong to or represent youth groups, associations, or networks


Come from diverse and marginalised backgrounds, including young women, persons with disabilities, refugees, and displaced youth


Benefits of Joining the Youth Advisory Group
Although this is not a salaried position, selected members will receive:


Full coverage of project-related travel, accommodation, and participation costs


Regional leadership exposure and visibility in AfCFTA policy and innovation spaces

fields.text_en:
Call for Expressions of Interest: Join the ECoWYERT Youth Advisory Group (2026ΓÇô2030)

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has opened a Call for Expressions of Interest for young leaders to join the Youth Advisory Group (YAG) of the Enhancing Capacities of Young Women and Youth-Led Enterprises for Regional Trade (ECoWYERT) project.
ECoWYERT is a five-year, multi-country initiative (2026ΓÇô2030) designed to strengthen the participation of youth- and women-led micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in cross-border trade under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA). The project is implemented by UNDP in partnership with the Mastercard Foundation, COMESA Federation for Women in Business (COMFWB), Trade and Development Fund (TDF), International Trade Centre (ITC), and the Better Than Cash Alliance (BTCA).
About the Youth Advisory Group (YAG)
The Youth Advisory Group will consist of eight dynamic young leaders aged 18ΓÇô35 who will work closely with the Project Steering Committee to provide strategic guidance, amplify youth voices, and ensure youth-inclusive approaches throughout the project lifecycle.
YAG members will contribute to:


Strategic input and advisory on project design, priorities, and outcomes


Co-creation and implementation of youth-focused tools, interventions, and campaigns


Representation and advocacy in national, regional, and continental AfCFTA-related platforms


Knowledge sharing and accountability, including monitoring, evaluation, and learning


Who Can Apply?
Applications are open to young people who:


Are 18ΓÇô35 years old


Are citizens of and resident in Africa, specifically from Botswana, DR Congo, Malawi, South Africa, Zambia, or Zimbabwe


Are actively involved in enterprise development, innovation, policy, advocacy, trade, or community development


Have experience or interest in AfCFTA, MSME development, cross-border trade, digital or financial inclusion, or womenΓÇÖs economic empowerment


Belong to or represent youth groups, associations, or networks


Come from diverse and marginalised backgrounds, including young women, persons with disabilities, refugees, and displaced youth


Benefits of Joining the Youth Advisory Group
Although this is not a salaried position, selected members will receive:


Full coverage of project-related travel, accommodation, and participation costs


Regional leadership exposure and visibility in AfCFTA policy and innovation spaces


High-level networking with trade institutions, policymakers, and technical experts


Capacity-building and skills development


Opportunities to influence youth-focused trade and entrepreneurship interventions


A chance to contribute meaningfully to youth-centred regional development impact


Application Process and Deadline
Eligible candidates must submit an Expression of Interest (EOI) outlining their background, experience, and motivation for joining the Youth Advisory Group.
Application deadline: 25 January to 3rd February, 2026Apply here
For more other fellowship opportunities, click here.
[contact-form]

fields.raw_text:
KB Fellowship at NIAS ΓÇô Call for Applications (2026ΓÇô2027)

The KB Fellowship at NIAS, established in 2025 through a collaboration between the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study (NIAS) and the KB National Library of the Netherlands, offers an exceptional opportunity for researchers and creative practitioners to conduct independent, innovative research at the intersection of library studies, cultural heritage, and public knowledge institutions. This fellowship is designed for projects that explore the future-oriented functionality of libraries and their role as pillars of liberal democracy, or that advance the sustainability of library services in society.
Application Deadline: 16 March 2026, 12:00 CETFellowship Duration: 5 months (September 2026 ΓÇô January 2027)Location: NIAS, Amsterdam, The Netherlands

About the Fellowship
The KB Fellowship provides:


Focused Research Time: 5 months of full-time residency to pursue your individual project, free from other professional obligations.


Multidisciplinary Environment: Engage with a diverse international cohort of fellows in the humanities and social sciences, fostering collaboration, interdisciplinary dialogue, and peer feedback.


Access to KB Resources: Fellows are encouraged to actively make use of the KB collections, archives, and expertise, gaining insights and materials relevant to their projects.


Support and Facilities: Includes office space at NIAS, library services, participation in academic and community programs, and practical assistance for relocation, banking, insurance, child care, schooling, and psychological support.


Financial Support: Fellows receive a personal stipend, or for Dutch-affiliated scholars, a Dutch University Grant. Subsidized housing or reimbursed local public transportation is available where eligible.


Fellows are also encouraged to publish any resulting research under a Creative Commons CC-BY 4.0 license, supporting open access and broad dissemination.

Who Can Apply
The fellowship is open to scholars and creative practitioners who meet the following criteria:


Scholars: Minimum of 3 years of research experience after obtaining a PhD.


Creative Practitioners/Artists: Minimum of 3 years of independent artistic practice post-graduation or equivalent.


Institutional Affiliation: Applicants may be affiliated with an academic or artistic institution, or independent.


Language Requirements: Working language is English, and applicants must demonstrate a strong command to participate effectively in the fellowsΓÇÖ community.


Note: The fellowship is a full-time commitment. Fellows are expected to be present at NIAS four workdays per week to ensure full participation in the community.

Research Focus
Applicants may propose projects that:


Address societal, practical, or international challenges relevant to libraries and cultural heritage institutions.


Explore (digital) collections, public library services, cultural policy, or community engagement.


Advance the understanding of the library as a public institution and democratic pillar.


Contribute new dimensions or perspectives to the KB research agenda, including comparative and international approaches.



Benefits of the KB Fellowship
Fellows enjoy a comprehensive package designed to support their research and personal well-being:


Stipend or Grant: Competitive financial support according to NIAS and KB standards.


Accommodation & Transportation: Subsidized housing or reimbursed local travel costs where applicable.


Research Infrastructure: Private office at NIAS, access to library collections, and research facilities.


Community Engagement: Inclusion in academic and outreach programs, multidisciplinary seminars, and opportunities for collaboration.


Professional Development: Access to mentorship, workshops, and a supportive international scholarly network.


Open Access: Encouragement to publish research under CC-BY 4.0 for wide visibility.



Application Process
Required Documents
Applications must be submitted online and include:


Project Proposal: Maximum 1,500 words (excluding bibliography) detailing the research question, methodology, and relevance to the KB and broader society.


Academic/Artistic CV: Maximum 4 pages, including international collaborations and key publications.


Motivation Statement: Maximum 300 words addressing:


How the project relates to your current academic or artistic trajectory


Why this fellowship is timely for your work




Timeline


Call Opens: 15 January 2026


Application Deadline: 16 March 2026, 12:00 CET


Selection Notification: Candidates will be informed after a multi-stage review process (eligibility check, KB ranking committee evaluation, NIAS Academic Advisory Board review).


Selection Criteria
Applications will be evaluated based on:


Originality and Quality: Scholarly or artistic merit of the proposal.


Track Record: Academic/artistic performance and achievements.


Community Contribution: Expected participation in the NIAS fellowsΓÇÖ group.


Relevance to KB: Significance for library policies, practices, and the role of libraries in liberal democracy.


The final decision rests with the NIAS Director, ensuring a balanced cohort in terms of discipline, geographic affiliation, career stage, and gender.

About the KB National Library
Founded in 1798, the KB ΓÇô National Library of the Netherlands is a leading knowledge institution dedicated to preserving, curating, and providing access to the NetherlandsΓÇÖ cultural and scholarly heritage. KB serves as:


A resource for academic and non-academic research


A hub for public information and cultural engagement


A repository for national and digital collections


A collaborator with technology and library development initiatives



Contact
Robert Raub, Partnership Officerpartners@nias.knaw.nl
APPLY HERE
FOR MORE OPPORTUNITIES CLICK HERE
The post KB Fellowship at NIAS ΓÇô Call for Applications (2026ΓÇô2027) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Theirworld Small Grants Programme

The Theirworld Small Grants Programme is designed to help registered charities and non-profits create meaningful change for children and young people, particularly those who are disadvantaged or overlooked. Since 2004, Theirworld has provided nearly ┬ú1 million in small grants to support initiatives that improve access to education, skills development, health, and wellbeing, both in the UK and internationally.
The programme is intended to empower local organisations with a passion for supporting youth but limited access to resources. By offering smaller, more flexible grants, the programme allows organisations to pilot innovative projects, scale impactful initiatives, or test new approaches without the lengthy process of larger funding applications.
Supporting Projects that Improve Education, Skills, and Wellbeing for Children and Young People
Deadline: 16 February 2026, 17:00 GMTGrant Amount: ┬ú1,000 ΓÇô ┬ú10,000

Programme Focus
Theirworld supports projects that:


Improve access to quality education for children and young people.


Promote health, wellbeing, and emotional development, particularly in vulnerable groups.


Develop skills for the future, including literacy, numeracy, vocational training, and life skills.


Support girls, young women, and other marginalised groups to overcome barriers to learning.


Enhance community-based initiatives, including mentorship, peer-support, or early intervention programmes.


Small grants are designed to make a practical and immediate impact, whether by providing essential learning resources, hiring specialist staff, or funding extracurricular programmes.

Impact of Theirworld Small Grants
Over the years, the programme has supported dozens of organisations worldwide, improving the lives of thousands of children. Examples of past grantees include:


Girls Out Loud (UK): Mentorship programme matching female role models with Year 8 girls in inner-city Manchester, helping improve confidence, self-esteem, and aspirations.


Sibling Support (UK): Produces booklets, memory boxes, and animated films for children grieving the loss of a sibling.


Chance UK (UK): RISE programme for girls aged 8ΓÇô12, focusing on emotional wellbeing and mental health support through mentoring.


Ashanti Development (Ghana): Constructed housing for teachers in a rural farming community, enabling improved retention and support for 200 students.


The Butterfly Tree (Zambia): Supported five young women from rural communities to attend college, live near campus, and complete work placements.


Action for Education (Greece): Delivered workshops and learning activities for young refugee women, promoting skills, confidence, and educational engagement.


Misty Meadows School (South Africa): Funded a teacher for literacy, numeracy, and social-emotional development for first and second graders where English is not the first language.


Youth and Women for Opportunities Uganda: Enabled 68 children to access school or vocational training, particularly targeting orphans, children with disabilities, and vulnerable families.



Who Can Apply
Eligible applicants include:


Registered charities or non-profit organisations working in education, youth development, or health.


Projects supporting children and young people aged 0ΓÇô18, particularly those facing disadvantage or marginalisation.


Organisations able to demonstrate clear, achievable impact with the proposed grant.


Small grants typically range from ┬ú1,000 to ┬ú10,000, allowing for flexible project design, pilot programmes, or expansion of existing initiatives.

Application Process


Check Eligibility: Review the full programme guidelines to ensure your project meets criteria.


Attend a Webinar: Ask questions and clarify requirements:


2 February 2026, 10:00 GMT ΓåÆ [Register here]


3 February 2026, 15:00 GMT ΓåÆ [Register here]




Prepare Your Application: Clearly outline:


Project objectives and activities


Expected outcomes and impact


Budget and resource allocation


How the grant will be used to support children or youth




Submit Your Application Online: Ensure submission by 16 February 2026, 17:00 GMT.



Why Apply
The Theirworld Small Grants Programme is ideal for organisations that want to:


Make a direct and tangible impact on the lives of children and young people.


Receive funding for innovative or pilot projects that may be too small for larger grants.


Join a network of local and international organisations committed to improving education and youth development.


Contribute to TheirworldΓÇÖs mission of ending the global learning crisis and ensuring every child has a safe place to learn, the best start in life, and skills for the future.

APPLY HERE



Theirworld is a global childrenΓÇÖs charity dedicated to ending the global education crisis and unleashing the potential of the next generation.
FOR MORE OPPORTUNITIES CLICK HERE

fields.raw_text:
RePIM Doctoral Network 12 Fully Funded PhD Positions in Europe

The RePIM Doctoral Network (Revisioning Public Interest Media) is now recruiting 12 fully funded PhD candidates to join a unique international research and training programme across leading European universities.
Funded by the Marie Sk┼éodowska-Curie Actions (MSCA) Doctoral Networks under Horizon Europe, RePIM brings together academic institutions, public interest media organisations, and industry partners to reimagine how Public Interest Media can remain relevant, sustainable, and impactful in a rapidly evolving, data-driven and platform-dominated media ecosystem.

About the RePIM Project
Public Interest Media are facing profound transformations driven by digital platforms, datafication, artificial intelligence, and shifting audience behaviours. RePIM addresses these challenges through interdisciplinary, comparative, and practice-oriented research.
The network focuses on five interconnected thematic clusters:


Content Production and Distribution


Media Infrastructures


Organisational Transformation


Policy and Regulation


Audiences and Public Engagement


Doctoral Candidates will contribute original research on topics such as AI-assisted content creation, emerging storytelling formats, recommender systems, organisational restructuring, sustainability models, audience inclusion, and media regulation in the platform era.

PhD Positions Available (12 Doctoral Candidates)
RePIM is recruiting 12 Doctoral Candidates (DCs), each working on a clearly defined PhD project hosted at a European university.
Host Countries
Austria, Belgium, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Norway, Poland, and Switzerland.
List of PhD Projects


DC1: Coping with the challenges of automated content in Public Interest MediaUniversity of Zurich (UZH), Switzerland


DC2: Reinventing content for online-first public mediaCharles University Prague (CU), Czechia


DC3: Quality news bots for public service mediaAalborg University (AAU), Denmark


DC4: Object-oriented edge-casting using semantic encodingAalborg University (AAU), Denmark


DC5: Digital infrastructures in the public interestUniversity of Stavanger (UiS), Norway


DC6: Global logics in local contexts: Reinventing partnership strategies for Public Interest MediaVrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB), Belgium


DC7: Reconfiguring organisational structures for delivering platformised public valueVrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB), Belgium


DC8: Developing and transforming sustainability requirements for Public Interest MediaParis Lodron University of Salzburg (PLUS), Austria


DC9: Regulating Public Interest Media in a platform worldParis Lodron University of Salzburg (PLUS), Austria


DC10: Public support for non-public service media organisationsUniversity of Warsaw (UW), Poland


DC11: Reaching the unreachableVrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB), Belgium


DC12: Audience data management and performance measurement in the cross-media landscapeTallinn University (TLU), Estonia


Applicants may apply for up to three positions, clearly indicating their first choice.

What RePIM Offers
All Doctoral Candidates will receive:


A 36- or 48-month full-time PhD employment contract (depending on host institution)


A competitive MSCA salary, including:


Living allowance


Mobility allowance


Family allowance (if applicable)




Full social security coverage


International secondments with partner universities


Fully paid internships with Public Interest Media organisations


Advanced interdisciplinary training in:


Research methods


Data management & ethics


Policy, governance, and regulation


Leadership, management, and entrepreneurship




Participation in:


Three Summer Schools (Brussels, Copenhagen, Salzburg)


Three Winter Seminars (online)


Scenario-building workshops


Final RePIM Symposium & Career Days in Brussels




Close supervision by leading academics and media professionals


Membership in a vibrant, international research community



Eligibility Criteria (MSCA Doctoral Network Rules)
Applicants must:


Not hold a doctoral degree at the time of recruitment


Comply with the MSCA mobility rule:


Must not have lived or worked in the host country for more than 12 months in the 36 months prior to recruitment




Hold a MasterΓÇÖs degree in a relevant discipline


Demonstrate strong academic potential and motivation for doctoral research


Be willing to relocate internationally


Have excellent written and spoken English


Applicants from all academic disciplines are welcome, particularly those with interests in media studies, communication, digital transformation, organisational studies, policy, data-driven media, or public interest communication.

Application Deadlines
Deadlines vary by project:


31 January 2026, 23:59 CET (some positions)


8 February 2026, 23:59 CET (extended deadline for selected positions)


┬áPlease check the deadline for your first-choice project carefully, as this determines your application timeline.

How to Apply
Full details for each PhD positionΓÇöincluding project descriptions, supervisors, secondments, eligibility requirements, and application instructionsΓÇöare available on the RePIM Recruitment page.
APPLY HERE

About RePIM
RePIM (Revisioning Public Interest Media) is a four-year Marie Sk┼éodowska-Curie Doctoral Network uniting universities, media organisations, and industry partners across Europe. The project is committed to training the next generation of researchers capable of shaping the future of Public Interest Media in the digital age.
FOR MORE OPPORTUNITIES CLICK HERE

fields.raw_text:
NIAS Individual Fellowship

The Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study (NIAS) invites applications for its prestigious Individual Fellowships for the academic year 2027ΓÇô2028. These fellowships offer scholars the time, space, and intellectual freedom to pursue independent research in the humanities and social sciences within an inspiring interdisciplinary environment.
Each year, NIAS welcomes around 30 fellows from across the world to join its vibrant academic community in Amsterdam.
Application Deadline: 16 March 2026, 12:00 (CET)

About the NIAS Individual Fellowship
The NIAS Individual Fellowship is designed for experienced scholars who wish to focus fully on their own research project. Fellows are relieved of teaching and administrative duties, allowing them to dedicate themselves to deep, innovative scholarship.
Key Features


Fellowship duration: 5 or 10 months


Research topic: ApplicantΓÇÖs own choice


Disciplines: Humanities and Social Sciences


Working language: English


Location: Amsterdam, the Netherlands


Format: Full-time, residential fellowship


Fellows become part of a diverse and international community, benefiting from interdisciplinary exchange, seminars, and informal discussions with peers from different academic backgrounds.

Who Can Apply?
NIAS Individual Fellowships are open to scholars from the Netherlands and abroad.
Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must:


Hold a PhD and have at least three years of academic experience after obtaining it


Propose a research project within the humanities or social sciences


Have a strong command of English


Be able to participate actively in an interdisciplinary academic environment


Applicants do not need to hold a permanent academic position. Independent scholars and those on temporary contracts are welcome to apply.
NIAS aims to assemble a balanced and diverse cohort, reflecting differences in academic cultures, gender, career stage, and disciplinary backgrounds.
┬áFor a complete overview of formal requirements, please consult the official guidelines.

Commitment & Residency Expectations
A NIAS Fellowship is a full-time commitment, comparable to a research residency abroad.


Fellows are expected to be present at NIAS at least four days per week


The fellowship requires withdrawal from most other professional obligations


This applies equally to Dutch and international fellows


Special Note for Dutch Applicants
NIAS reserves part of its fellowships for scholars, artists, journalists, and authors based in the Netherlands. Dutch applicants are strongly encouraged to discuss the fellowshipΓÇÖs requirements with their home institution in advance, as freeing oneself from teaching and administrative duties for 5ΓÇô10 months can be challenging.

Equal Opportunity & Eligibility Restrictions
NIAS is committed to academic freedom, inclusivity, and equal rights. Researchers are not excluded based on nationality, ethnicity, religion, or institutional background.
Important NoticeDue to EU sanctions introduced in March 2022, NIAS cannot accept applications from scholars affiliated with Russian or Belarusian universities or research institutes.Applicants of Russian or Belarusian nationality who are independent or affiliated with institutions outside these countries remain eligible.

Application Process: At a Glance
The NIAS Individual Fellowship is awarded through a project-based open call. Selection is based primarily on the quality and originality of the research proposal, with CV and publication record playing a secondary role.
Application Caps (Numerus Clausus)
A maximum of 216 eligible applications will be assessed:


72 applications from Dutch-affiliated or Dutch-based applicants


72 applications from applicants based in:


EU countries and selected associated countries (including the UK, US, Canada, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand)




72 applications from applicants based in all other countries


NIAS will announce when any category reaches its limit. If one category is undersubscribed, remaining places will be redistributed.
Note: This numerus clausus does not apply to Theme Group Fellowship applications.

How to Apply
Applicants must complete the online application form and submit the following materials:


A full research proposal (maximum 1,500 words) outlining:


The research topic


Academic and societal relevance


The added value of NIASΓÇÖs interdisciplinary environment




A curriculum vitae


A publication list


Names and contact details of three international experts who may act as reviewers (with no conflict of interest)


Please note: Applicants are explicitly requested not to use AI tools to write their application texts.
For full application details and formal requirements, consult the official application guidelines.
APPLY HERE

Application Timeline


Call opens: 15 January 2026


Call closes: 16 March 2026, 12:00 (CET)


Formal eligibility check completed: before 1 May 2026


Notification for non-reviewed applications: before 15 May 2026


Final decision communicated: no later than 15 December 2026


A complete overview of the selection procedure is available on the NIAS website.

Contact Information
For questions regarding the fellowship or application process, please contact:
Anja de Haas
selection@nias.knaw.nl+31 (0)20 224 67 05

About NIAS
The Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study (NIAS) is part of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW). NIAS provides an international platform for advanced research, intellectual exchange, and interdisciplinary collaboration.
Korte Spinhuissteeg 3, 1012 CG Amsterdam┬áPO Box 10855, 1001 EW Amsterdam┬á+31 (0)20 224 67 00info@nias.knaw.nl
FOR MORE OPPORTUNITIES CLICK HERE

fields.raw_text:
CYMG Open Call for Global Steering Committee & Task Forces (2025ΓÇô2026)

The Children and Youth Major Group to the UN Environment Programme (CYMG) is inviting committed and passionate young leaders to apply for its Global Steering Committee and Task Forces for the 2025ΓÇô2026 mandate.
CYMG is a globally recognised umbrella mechanism representing youth networks, organisations, and individuals working to address the triple planetary crisisΓÇöclimate change, biodiversity loss, and pollution. As the formal youth engagement mechanism to UNEP, CYMG plays a critical role in advocating for the inclusion, empowerment, and meaningful participation of young people in global environmental governance and the environmental dimension of the sustainable development agenda.
Today, CYMG brings together over 2,000 youth organisations and 12,000 individual members worldwide, creating a powerful collective voice for youth-led environmental action.
Before You Apply
Applicants must be registered members of CYMG.
If you are not yet a member, please join via: www.cymgenv.net/join
ΓÜá∩╕Å Applications from non-members cannot be processed.
┬á
About the Roles
Global Steering Committee (GSC)
The Steering Committee serves as CYMGΓÇÖs core coordination and decision-making body, providing strategic direction and oversight for its programmatic, policy, and substantive work.
As a Focal Point, responsibilities include:

Coordinating with relevant UNEP offices and units
Facilitating youth engagement with the UN system at regional or thematic levels
Working closely with youth networks in assigned regions or themes
Supporting key processes such as the Youth Environment Assembly (YEA) and UNEA-7

Time commitment: ~4 hours per week
Task Forces
Task Forces are small, active volunteer teams that support focal points in their ongoing work. While these are volunteer roles, they require strong commitment and are designed to prepare members for future Steering Committee positions.
Time commitment: ~2ΓÇô3 hours per week
Open Positions
Global Steering Committee (GSC)

Science Policy & Knowledge Lead (x2)
Coordinate CYMGΓÇÖs science-policy engagement, including inputs to UNEP-hosted or co-hosted science-policy panels, and lead capacity-building and knowledge activities.
Communications Lead (x1)
Lead CYMGΓÇÖs overall communications strategy, oversee internal and external messaging, manage official materials, social media, web, design, and community engagement teams.
Social Media Lead (x1)
Manage CYMGΓÇÖs social media platforms, develop campaigns aligned with the communications strategy, coordinate content creation, and track outreach performance.

Thematic & Regional Focal Points

Thematic Focal Point ΓÇô Environmental Health (x1)
Lead CYMGΓÇÖs agenda at the intersection of environment, health, and equity, applying a One Health approach.
Regional Focal Point ΓÇô Africa (x1)
Regional Focal Point ΓÇô North America (x1)
Regional Focal Point ΓÇô Europe (x1)

Regional Focal Points engage youth in their regions, ensure inclusive representation, coordinate CYMGΓÇÖs involvement in regional environmental processes, and organise regional youth forums and capacity-building activities.
CYMG Task Forces

Chemicals, Waste & Pollution
Support preparations for global chemicals and waste processes (e.g. BRS, Minamata Conventions) and deliver capacity-building under the #YouthtoBEATPOLLUTION campaign.
Eco-Faith
Support youth of faith initiatives across traditions and regions, including implementation of the Youth of Faith Roadmap, advocacy, interfaith dialogue, and coordination.
Policy Coordination & UNEP Affairs
Support engagement in Committee of Permanent Representatives (CPR) meetings, capacity-building sessions, consultations, and strengthening UNEP Headquarters engagement.
Africa Regional Task Force
Support African youth programmes, outreach, advocacy, and coordination within CYMG.
Latin America & the Caribbean (LAC) Task Force
Support youth engagement, communication, advocacy, and programme coordination in the LAC region.

Mandate & Conditions

Mandate duration: One (1) year
Start date: On or before 1 February 2025
Compensation: All roles are voluntary with no financial benefits

Detailed Terms of Reference for all positions are here
Application Deadline
≡ƒùô 24 January 2026
ΓÅ░ 23:59 UTC
If you are ready to contribute your time, skills, and passion to shaping global youth engagement in environmental governance, we encourage you to APPLY NOW.
APPLY NOW
The post CYMG Open Call for Global Steering Committee & Task Forces (2025ΓÇô2026) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Fully Funded UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit 2026 in Berlin: Apply by 25 January

Are you a young person in the UK who is passionate about democracy, civic engagement, and shaping a resilient future? Do you want to connect with like-minded youth across borders, gain new perspectives, and experience a fully funded international programme in Europe? Then the UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit 2026: ΓÇ£Resilient Democracies ΓÇô Youth Shaping the FutureΓÇ¥ is an opportunity you should not miss.
Organised under the landmark UKΓÇôGermany Kensington Treaty, this prestigious youth summit brings together young people from the United Kingdom and Germany to strengthen intercultural dialogue, democratic values, and youth participation in society. The application deadline is 25 January 2026.

About the UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit
The UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit is a flagship initiative designed to deepen cooperation between the UK and Germany in key areas such as education, youth exchange, and democratic engagement. It provides a safe and inspiring space for young people to explore how democracy functions in everyday life and how youth can actively contribute to building inclusive, resilient societies.
Through interactive workshops, peer discussions, and creative group activities, participants will engage with critical topics including disinformation, diversity, civic participation, and democratic resilience. The programme encourages participants to reflect on their own experiences, exchange ideas with peers from different cultural backgrounds, and imagine practical solutions for the challenges facing democracies today.
By the end of the summit, participants will not only gain a deeper understanding of democratic values but also develop the confidence and skills needed to apply these insights within their own communities.

Who Can Participate?
The summit will host 70 young people from the United Kingdom and Germany, aged 18 to 25 years.
This application process is strictly for young people based in the UK. Applicants living in Germany should apply through IJABΓÇÖs website.
To be eligible, applicants must:

Be between 18 and 25 years old at the time of the summit
Currently live in the UK and have done so for the past two years
Have completed at least two years of formal education in the UK (secondary, further, or higher education)
Have a good understanding of English, as the entire programme will be conducted in English
Be able to participate fully in the summit in Berlin from 19 to 22 March 2026
Be available for a 2ΓÇô3 hour online preparatory seminar in early March 2026

Applicants should also demonstrate:

A genuine interest in democracy, civic engagement, disinformation, and resilience
Openness, respect, and curiosity toward different cultures, opinions, and lived experiences

When and Where Will the Summit Take Place?
Main Event: Thursday 19 March ΓÇô Sunday 22 March 2026
Online Preparatory Seminar: 2ΓÇô3 hours in early March 2026
Location: Berlin, Germany (venue to be confirmed)

What Costs Are Covered?
This is a fully funded programme. Selected participants will not be required to make any financial contribution.
The organisers will cover:

International and local travel costs
Accommodation for the entire duration of the summit
Meals during the programme

Please note that pocket money is not included, so participants may wish to plan for personal expenses.

Why You Should Apply
Participating in the UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit offers both personal and professional benefits, including:

Building meaningful international friendships with peers from the UK and Germany
Developing critical thinking, communication, and resilience skills
Exploring how democracy affects your daily life and how you can help sustain it
Gaining confidence through speaking up, collaboration, and idea-sharing
Bringing fresh perspectives and practical ideas back to your school, workplace, or community
Receiving guidance and support from an experienced intercultural facilitation team
Enjoying a memorable cultural and learning experience in Berlin


How to Apply
Interested candidates should complete the online application form by 25 January 2026.
Successful applicants will be notified by early February 2026 and will receive further details about the programme schedule, preparatory activities, and travel arrangements.
APPLY HERE
For questions or additional information, applicants can contact the organisers via Youth.Summit@britishcouncil.org.

Who Is Organising the Summit?
The UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit is jointly organised by:

The German Federal Ministry of Education, Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth (BMBFSFJ)
The UK Department for Education (DfE)
The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS)

The programme is delivered by IJAB ΓÇô the International Youth Service of the Federal Republic of Germany ΓÇô and the British Council, the UKΓÇÖs international organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities.

Deadline reminder: Applications close on 25 January 2026.
If you are passionate about democracy and youth leadership, this fully funded summit in Berlin could be a defining experience for you.

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like thisΓÇª
The post Fully Funded UKΓÇôGermany Youth Summit 2026 in Berlin: Apply by 25 January appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
UNESCO Participation Grant Programme 2026ΓÇô2027: Funding Opportunities for Education, Science, Culture, and Development

The UNESCO Participation Grant Programme 2026ΓÇô2027 is a prestigious biennial funding opportunity designed to support impactful projects that advance UNESCOΓÇÖs global priorities. Implemented under the UNESCO Participation Programme, this grant provides financial assistance to projects proposed by UNESCO Member States and Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) that are in official partnership with UNESCO.
The programme plays a critical role in complementing UNESCOΓÇÖs regular budget by empowering Member States and partner organizations to implement initiatives that promote inclusive development, capacity building, cultural preservation, scientific advancement, and knowledge sharing at national, sub-regional, regional, and inter-regional levels.
For organizations and institutions seeking international recognition, collaboration, and funding support, the UNESCO Participation Grant Programme presents a valuable opportunity to contribute meaningfully to global development agendas during the 2026ΓÇô2027 biennium.

About the UNESCO Participation Grant Programme
The UNESCO Participation Grant Programme is a long-standing funding mechanism established to encourage cooperation between UNESCO and its Member States. It supports projects and activities that align directly with UNESCOΓÇÖs fields of competence, including:

Education
Natural Sciences
Social and Human Sciences
Culture
Communication and Information

Through this programme, UNESCO supports initiatives that strengthen national capacities, encourage regional cooperation, preserve cultural heritage, promote scientific research, improve access to education, and enhance freedom of expression and information.
The programme operates on a biennial cycle, with funding levels and project categories approved by the UNESCO General Conference. For the 2026ΓÇô2027 cycle, specific maximum funding ceilings apply depending on whether the project is national, sub-regional, regional, or inter-regional in scope.

Key Benefits of the Programme
The UNESCO Participation Grant Programme offers a wide range of benefits to approved applicants and participating institutions, including:

Financial support for national, sub-regional, regional, and inter-regional projects aligned with UNESCO priorities.
Funding for activities in education, science, culture, and communication and information.
Support for regional and international cooperation, encouraging knowledge exchange and shared solutions.
Strengthened partnerships between Member States, National Commissions for UNESCO, and NGOs.
Funding for fellowships, study grants, and specialist training opportunities.
Support for organizing conferences, seminars, workshops, training courses, and capacity-building programmes.
Financial assistance for specialist services, documentation, research dissemination, and publications.

Increased visibility, credibility, and institutional capacity for participating organizations.
These benefits make the programme particularly attractive to government institutions, educational bodies, research institutions, and internationally recognized NGOs.

Eligibility Criteria
Eligibility for the UNESCO Participation Grant Programme is institution-based, not individual-based.
Eligible Applicants
UNESCO Member States

Applications are submitted through the countryΓÇÖs National Commission for UNESCO or an equivalent government body.
Each Member State may submit up to seven (7) project proposals per biennium.
Projects must be prioritized (ranked from 1 to 7).

Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)

Must be in official partnership with UNESCO.
May submit up to two (2) project proposals.
Projects must have sub-regional, regional, or inter-regional impact.
Each proposal must be supported by at least one UNESCO Member StateΓÇÖs National Commission.

Important Notes

Projects must align with UNESCOΓÇÖs programme priorities and strategic objectives.
Proposals must be directly related to the applicant organizationΓÇÖs mandate.
Individuals cannot apply independently; all applications must be channelled through Member States or eligible NGOs.


Application Process and Key Steps
The application process for the UNESCO Participation Grant Programme is structured and coordinated at the national level.
1. Circular Letter Announcement
After the UNESCO General Conference approves the biennial programme and budget, UNESCO issues an official Circular Letter announcing the call for Participation Programme proposals. This letter outlines eligibility requirements, funding limits, and submission deadlines.
2. Coordination Through National Commissions
Member States work closely with their National Commission for UNESCO (or a designated government channel) to identify priority projects and prepare submissions.
3. Project Prioritisation
Each Member State ranks its proposed projects (e.g., Priority 1ΓÇô7), ensuring alignment with UNESCOΓÇÖs strategic areas such as education, culture, science, and communication.
4. Proposal Development
Applicants prepare a comprehensive project proposal that includes:

Clear objectives and justification
Expected outcomes and impact
Implementation timeline
Detailed and compliant budget

5. Online Submission
All proposals are submitted through UNESCOΓÇÖs e-submission system by the specified deadline. For the 2026ΓÇô2027 cycle, the expected deadline is 27 February 2026.
6. NGO Submissions
Eligible NGOs submit proposals in accordance with the Circular Letter, ensuring formal support from at least one Member StateΓÇÖs National Commission.
7. Evaluation and Approval
UNESCO evaluates proposals based on relevance, feasibility, impact, and alignment with Participation Programme objectives.
8. Funding Allocation
Approved projects receive funding up to the maximum allowed per category, for example:

Up to US$26,000 for national projects
Up to US$28,000 for sub-regional or inter-regional projects
Up to US$38,000 for regional projects

9. Implementation and Reporting
Successful applicants implement approved projects and submit narrative and financial reports as required by UNESCO.
Apply and submit your application HERE
Deadline: 10th Feb, 2026

The UNESCO Participation Grant Programme 2026ΓÇô2027 is an excellent opportunity for Member States and UNESCO-partnered NGOs to secure funding for high-impact initiatives that contribute to education, science, culture, and sustainable development worldwide. Organizations interested in this programme are encouraged to begin early coordination with their National Commissions to ensure strong, well-prioritized submissions.
If you work with a government institution, NGO, or organization aligned with UNESCOΓÇÖs mission, this grant could be a strategic pathway to expanding your impact at national and international levels.

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like thisΓÇª
The post UNESCO Participation Grant Programme 2026ΓÇô2027: Funding Opportunities for Education, Science, Culture, and Development appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Kids in Museums Youth Panel Recruitment Pack 2026

Kids in Museums is excited to announce the recruitment of six new members for its Youth Panel 2026. This opportunity is open to young people aged 16ΓÇô25 from across the UK. No formal qualifications are required, and we particularly welcome applications from individuals from global majority and working-class backgrounds, as well as D/deaf, disabled, and neurodivergent young people.
We are also keen to expand our geographical reach, so applications from Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales are strongly encouraged.

What is the Youth Panel?
The Youth Panel is a group of around ten young people aged 16ΓÇô25 who meet monthly via Zoom. Members bring diverse perspectives to Kids in Museums projects and help address barriers that prevent young people from visiting museums.

What Does the Youth Panel Do?
Youth Panel members contribute to existing initiatives and develop their own projects. Their work includes:

Supporting the Family Friendly Museum Award.
Sharing views with the Kids in Museums Board via Young Trustees.
Participating in Board Committees.
Developing independent projects with an annual budget.

Past Projects

Heritage Hideaway ΓÇô a Discord channel for young people interested in museums and heritage.
The Future is Now: Museum Youth Summit.
Life at the Museum ΓÇô a podcast series exploring youth provision in museums.
Craft Under the Mast ΓÇô a pilot programme tackling loneliness and social isolation among young people.

Other Contributions

Creating online resources about museum careers and employability.
Presenting at Kids in Museums conferences.
Speaking at major sector events such as the Museum + Heritage Show, GEM Conference, and the Fair Museum Jobs Summit.


Why Join the Youth Panel?
As a member, you will:

Learn new skills in event planning, social media marketing, interviewing, public speaking, and budgeting.
Build networks with fellow Youth Panel members, Young Trustees, and museum professionals.
Gain confidence and enjoy new experiences.
Hear career journeys from Kids in Museums staff and Trustees.


Support for Members
Kids in Museums provides free training to ensure Youth Panel members feel confident in their roles. Training has included:

Presentation skills.
Youth voice and decolonisation workshops.
Podcasting, fundraising, and charity governance.

New members are paired with a mentor (an experienced or former Youth Panel member) for the first three months.

Practical Information
Time Commitment

Around four hours per month for meetings and preparation.
Meetings are usually held on Tuesday evenings via Zoom (two hours each).
Additional time may be required for projects.
Members are expected to attend at least eight meetings per year (75% attendance).

Role Duration

Up to three years or until your 26th birthday (whichever comes first).
Applicants turning 26 before 31 March 2027 are not eligible.

Salary and Expenses

The role is voluntary.
Expenses for travel, accommodation, and subsistence are covered.
Additional paid opportunities are available for conferences, training, and projects requiring extra time.
Payment is at the London Living Wage (┬ú14.80 per hour).

Location

All meetings are online via Zoom.
Applicants must be based in the UK at the time of application.

Digital Tools
Members should have access to a phone, laptop, or tablet with internet connectivity and be confident using:

Email
Zoom
Google Docs and Sheets
Microsoft Office


Who Can Apply?
We are looking for applicants who are:

Aged 16ΓÇô25 (proof of age required).
Passionate about heritage and culture.
Committed to enabling young people to participate in culture and heritage.
Enthusiastic about learning new skills.
Confident working in groups.
Reliable and able to commit time each month.
Dedicated to promoting equality, diversity, and inclusion.


Information Session
An online information session will be held on:

Wednesday 4 February 2026
6pm ΓÇô 7pm
On Zoom

At the session, you can:

Learn more about Kids in Museums.
Discover the Youth PanelΓÇÖs work.
Meet current members and staff.

┬á
Deadlines

Closing date: Friday 13 February 2026, 5pm.
Candidates will be contacted by Friday 27 February 2026.
Informal Zoom interviews will take place between 9ΓÇô20 March 2026.
Interview questions will be shared one week in advance.
Feedback will be provided to all interviewees.

┬á
Joining the Kids in Museums Youth Panel 2026 is a chance to shape the future of museums and ensure that young voices are heard at every level. With training, mentorship, and opportunities to lead projects, members gain valuable skills while making a real impact on the cultural sector. If youΓÇÖre passionate about heritage, eager to learn, and ready to contribute, this is your opportunity to step forward and help create museums that truly welcome everyone. Learn more and apply here.
The post Kids in Museums Youth Panel Recruitment Pack 2026 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.
fields.text_en:
Kids in Museums Youth Panel Recruitment Pack 2026

Kids in Museums is excited to announce the recruitment of six new members for its Youth Panel 2026. This opportunity is open to young people aged 16ΓÇô25 from across the UK. No formal qualifications are required, and we particularly welcome applications from individuals from global majority and working-class backgrounds, as well as D/deaf, disabled, and neurodivergent young people.
We are also keen to expand our geographical reach, so applications from Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales are strongly encouraged.

What is the Youth Panel?
The Youth Panel is a group of around ten young people aged 16ΓÇô25 who meet monthly via Zoom. Members bring diverse perspectives to Kids in Museums projects and help address barriers that prevent young people from visiting museums.

What Does the Youth Panel Do?
Youth Panel members contribute to existing initiatives and develop their own projects. Their work includes:

Supporting the Family Friendly Museum Award.
Sharing views with the Kids in Museums Board via Young Trustees.
Participating in Board Committees.
Developing independent projects with an annual budget.

Past Projects

Heritage Hideaway ΓÇô a Discord channel for young people interested in museums and heritage.
The Future is Now: Museum Youth Summit.
Life at the Museum ΓÇô a podcast series exploring youth provision in museums.
Craft Under the Mast ΓÇô a pilot programme tackling loneliness and social isolation among young people.

Other Contributions

Creating online resources about museum careers and employability.
Presenting at Kids in Museums conferences.
Speaking at major sector events such as the Museum + Heritage Show, GEM Conference, and the Fair Museum Jobs Summit.


Why Join the Youth Panel?
As a member, you will:

Learn new skills in event planning, social media marketing, interviewing, public speaking, and budgeting.
Build networks with fellow Youth Panel members, Young Trustees, and museum professionals.
Gain confidence and enjoy new experiences.
Hear career journeys from Kids in Museums staff and Trustees.


Support for Members
Kids in Museums provides free training to ensure Youth Panel members feel confident in their roles. Training has included:

Presentation skills.
Youth voice and decolonisation workshops.
Podcasting, fundraising, and charity governance.

New members are paired with a mentor (an experienced or former Youth Panel member) for the first three months.

Practical Information
Time Commitment

Around four hours per month for meetings and preparation.
Meetings are usually held on Tuesday evenings via Zoom (two hours each).
Additional time may be required for projects.
Members are expected to attend at least eight meetings per year (75% attendance).

Role Duration

Up to three years or until your 26th birthday (whichever comes first).
Applicants turning 26 before 31 March 2027 are not eligible.

Salary and Expenses

The role is voluntary.
Expenses for travel, accommodation, and subsistence are covered.
Additional paid opportunities are available for conferences, training, and projects requiring extra time.
Payment is at the London Living Wage (┬ú14.80 per hour).

Location

All meetings are online via Zoom.
Applicants must be based in the UK at the time of application.

Digital Tools
Members should have access to a phone, laptop, or tablet with internet connectivity and be confident using:

Email
Zoom
Google Docs and Sheets
Microsoft Office


Who Can Apply?
We are looking for applicants who are:

Aged 16ΓÇô25 (proof of age required).
Passionate about heritage and culture.
Committed to enabling young people to participate in culture and heritage.
Enthusiastic about learning new skills.
Confident working in groups.
Reliable and able to commit time each month.
Dedicated to promoting equality, diversity, and inclusion.


Information Session
An online information session will be held on:

Wednesday 4 February 2026
6pm ΓÇô 7pm
On Zoom

At the session, you can:

Learn more about Kids in Museums.
Discover the Youth PanelΓÇÖs work.
Meet current members and staff.

┬á
Deadlines

Closing date: Friday 13 February 2026, 5pm.
Candidates will be contacted by Friday 27 February 2026.
Informal Zoom interviews will take place between 9ΓÇô20 March 2026.
Interview questions will be shared one week in advance.
Feedback will be provided to all interviewees.

┬á
Joining the Kids in Museums Youth Panel 2026 is a chance to shape the future of museums and ensure that young voices are heard at every level. With training, mentorship, and opportunities to lead projects, members gain valuable skills while making a real impact on the cultural sector. If youΓÇÖre passionate about heritage, eager to learn, and ready to contribute, this is your opportunity to step forward and help create museums that truly welcome everyone. Learn more and apply here.
The post Kids in Museums Youth Panel Recruitment Pack 2026 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
APC -Association for Progressive Communications- call for Narratives

The Association for Progressive Communications (APC), through its LocNet initiative, has launched an open call for narratives exploring the intersection of community-centred connectivity initiatives (CCCIs) and environmental justice. This call seeks to gather reflections, case studies, and creative contributions that highlight how community networks can support not only digital inclusion but also social, cultural, political, and environmental rights.
With climate change accelerating and environmental disasters becoming more frequent, APC emphasizes the importance of weaving networks that are not only digital but also social and ecological. This initiative invites individuals, collectives, and organizations to share their experiences and insights on how CCCIs can contribute to environmental justice.

Key Themes and Areas of Interest
Contributors are encouraged to submit narratives or case studies that address one or more of the following themes:

Environmental Monitoring and Protection

Use of sensors and automation technologies to track environmental violations.
Building evidence for environmental protection through community-driven data collection.


Circular Economy and Local Resilience

Promotion of recycling, resource efficiency, and sustainable practices.
Preservation of cultural heritage through community-led initiatives.


Renewable Energy Solutions

Adoption of off-grid power supply systems such as solar, biogas, and hydro.
Exploration of innovative storage solutions to support local infrastructure.


Green Construction Practices

Use of bamboo or other organic materials for towers and public access facilities.
Encouraging eco-friendly design in connectivity infrastructure.


Digital Tools for Climate Action

Measurement of carbon footprints using accessible digital platforms.
Leveraging climate change mitigation funding to invest in local digital infrastructure.


E-Waste Management

Strategies for safe disposal and recycling of electronic waste.
Community-led approaches to reduce socio-environmental impacts of technology.


Support for Environmental Activism

Using CCCIs to amplify the work of local activists and land defenders.
Strengthening emergency telecommunications during climate crises.




Submission Guidelines
Interested contributors should prepare a pitch that includes:

A short introduction about yourself or your collective.
The story or case study you wish to narrate.
Any relevant online links (if available).
Your preferred format of contribution.
A timeline for preparing your first draft (ideally before 15 March 2026).

Deadline for pitch submission: 31 January 2026

Formats for Final Contributions
Selected contributors will have the opportunity to present their work in diverse formats, including:

Short-form essays (1,000 ΓÇô 1,500 words)
Long-form essays (2,500 ΓÇô 3,000 words)
Poems
Illustrations (six frames)
Videos (up to 10 minutes)
Photo narratives
Graphic stories or comic books

This flexibility allows participants to choose the medium that best conveys their narrative and engages audiences effectively.

Honorarium
Contributors whose work is selected will receive an honorarium ranging between USD 300 and USD 500 upon submission of their final draft. This recognition underscores APCΓÇÖs commitment to valuing the time, effort, and creativity of participants.

Why This Matters
Community-centred connectivity initiatives are more than just technical solutions. They represent:

Empowerment of local communities to take ownership of their digital and environmental futures.
Integration of social and ecological justice into digital inclusion efforts.
Resilience-building in the face of climate emergencies and environmental degradation.
Innovation at the grassroots level, where communities experiment with sustainable technologies and practices.

By linking connectivity with environmental justice, APC highlights the transformative potential of CCCIs in shaping a more equitable and sustainable world.

This open call is an invitation to reimagine connectivity as a tool for environmental justice. By sharing stories, case studies, and creative works, contributors can help demonstrate how local networks are not only about internet access but also about safeguarding communities, cultures, and ecosystems.
The APC and LocNet initiative encourage diverse voices to participate, ensuring that the narratives reflect the richness of global experiences. Whether through essays, art, or multimedia, this call provides a platform to showcase how connectivity can be a force for ecological resilience and justice.
Deadline Reminder: Submit your pitch here by 31 January 2026 and prepare your first draft by 15 March 2026.

The post APC -Association for Progressive Communications- call for Narratives appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Apply Now: AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship

The International AIDS Society (IAS) is inviting applications for the AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship, a unique opportunity for passionate individuals dedicated to advancing HIV prevention knowledge and outreach. The fellowship offers a platform to engage with cutting-edge HIV science, influence policy, and connect with global leaders in the fight against HIV.

About the International AIDS Society
Founded by scientists committed to responding to the HIV and AIDS epidemic, the IAS brings together experts, policymakers, and activists worldwide to strengthen HIV prevention and care. IAS organizes the most prestigious HIV conferences globally, including the International AIDS Conference, the IAS Conference on HIV Science, and the HIV Research for Prevention Conference. Learn more at www.iasociety.org.

Fellowship Overview
The AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship will support participants to create and share digital content on HIV prevention, engage with the latest prevention research, and expand their professional networks. Fellowship activities include:

Designing a pre-conference digital content project aligned with the IAS ΓÇ£Rethink. Rebuild. Rise.ΓÇ¥ campaign (support of up to USD 500 for project costs).
Creating conference-focused content during AIDS 2026, translating the latest HIV prevention science and policy for diverse audiences (support of up to USD 500).
Attending AIDS 2026 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, from 26ΓÇô31 July 2026, with support for travel, accommodation, per diem, ground transport, and visa costs.
Networking with researchers, policymakers, activists, and peers to enhance professional development in HIV prevention.

Apply HERE

Fellowship Duration
Selected fellows will be notified in March 2026, with the fellowship beginning shortly after and concluding on 14 August 2026.

Who Should Apply?
Ideal candidates will:

Have a proven track record in HIV prevention initiatives, including PrEP/PEP, harm reduction, combination prevention, U=U messaging, long-acting prevention, or HIV policy work.
Demonstrate content creation experience on digital platforms, with at least 5,000 total followers/subscribers across TikTok, Instagram, LinkedIn, YouTube, podcasts, blogs, or community radio. Applicants without these metrics may qualify through other documented community engagement.
Use ethical, evidence-based, non-stigmatizing, and rights-based language consistent with IAS communications guidelines.
Be proficient in English (multilingual applicants encouraged) and able to participate in pre-event onboarding and the full conference.
Be aged 18 or older at the time of application.

Priority will be given to applicants who:

Represent or closely work with key and priority populations, including people living with HIV, men who have sex with men, trans people, sex workers, people who inject drugs, adolescent girls, young women, migrants, and other underserved communities.
Are based in low- and middle-income countries or produce content for underserved audiences.
Have experience collaborating with community-led organizations, clinics, or advocacy coalitions.


How to Apply
Interested candidates must download and complete the application form. Applications require:

Demographic information and work history.
Motivation statement.
Descriptions of two digital prevention projects: one pre-AIDS 2026 and one during the conference, including objectives, themes, target audiences, platforms, and sample posts.
CV with a portfolio or links to recent HIV prevention content (last 6ΓÇô12 months) and proof of reach, such as engagement screenshots.
Letter of support from your organization (if employed) or letter of reference (if self-employed).

The IAS will treat all applications confidentially, contacting only selected candidates. Questions can be submitted to hivprevention@iasociety.org.
This fellowship is distinct from the AIDS 2026 Media Scholarship, though eligible candidates may apply to both opportunities.
DonΓÇÖt miss the chance to be part of a global movement advancing HIV prevention. Apply now and help shape the future of HIV response at AIDS 2026 in Rio de Janeiro!
Deadline: 15th February, 2026
Find more information here

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like thisΓÇª
The post Apply Now: AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.
