fields.raw_text:
Graduate Professional Opportunities at UNIDIR: Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament

The United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research (UNIDIR) is inviting applications for its Graduate Professional Programme (GPP), offering two positions within the Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament programme. These positions present a unique opportunity for early-career professionals and recent graduates to contribute to international peace and security while gaining hands-on experience in a leading United Nations research institution.

About UNIDIR
UNIDIR is an autonomous research institute within the United Nations that specializes in disarmament and international security issues. Its mission is to foster a safer and more secure world by supporting Member States, the UN, and the research community in advancing actionable ideas for a peaceful global environment. The institute is headquartered in the Palais des Nations in Geneva, Switzerland, and conducts independent research that informs policy and practice in the field of disarmament.
The Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament programme focuses on generating policy-relevant knowledge, providing practical tools for multilateral practitioners, and promoting the integration of a gender perspective into arms control and disarmament work. The programme also emphasizes youth engagement, encouraging new voices to contribute to global security debates.

Position Details
UNIDIR is offering two Graduate Professional positions, one based in Geneva and the other remote. The appointments are temporary for six months, with the possibility of extension. The selected candidates will start in March 2026 and will work full-time (100% occupational rate).
Remuneration for the Geneva-based position includes a stipend of USD 1,331 per month, intended as a contribution to living expenses. Remote candidates will receive a reduced stipend, with adjustments if they already receive financial support from other sources. Travel, visa, accommodation, and other living expenses are the responsibility of the Graduate Professional or their sponsoring institution.

Key Responsibilities
Under the supervision of the Head of Programme, Graduate Professionals will:

Conduct background research on gender, youth, and disarmament issues.
Assist in planning and implementing programme activities, such as meetings, workshops, conferences, and field missions.
Support day-to-day tasks, including communications, coordination, and administrative work.
Perform additional tasks as required by programme staff.

This is a unique opportunity to gain exposure to the inner workings of a UN programme while contributing to practical and policy-oriented outputs.

Required Skills and Competencies
Candidates should demonstrate the following skills:

Research and presentation abilities, with the capacity to synthesize information into concise briefs.
Strong organizational skills and the ability to manage multiple tasks simultaneously.
Excellent interpersonal, teamwork, and communication skills (both written and oral).
Proficiency in Microsoft Office tools (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) and graphic design software such as InDesign.
A genuine interest in international peace and security, gender, youth engagement, and UN activities.

Core competencies expected include professionalism, integrity, and respect for diversity, as well as creativity, client orientation, and planning and organizing skills.

Qualifications
Applicants must meet one of the following educational requirements:

Be enrolled in a graduate programme (second university degree or higher), or
Have recently graduated with a relevant degree and be able to commence the Graduate Professional Programme within one year of graduation.

Preferred fields of study include international relations, political science, international law, and gender studies. Professional experience is not required, though interest or experience in conventional arms control will be considered an asset. Fluency in English is mandatory, and knowledge of additional UN languages is a plus.

Application Process
Interested candidates should submit:

A cover letter
The Inspira Personal History Form (PHP)
Brief responses (up to 30 words each) to screening questions addressing qualifications, language skills, software proficiency, organizational abilities, and any relevant publications

Applications must be submitted in PDF format titled SURNAME_Name_CV-CL to unidir.recruitment@un.org. The email subject line should indicate whether you are applying for ΓÇ£UNIDIR GPP ΓÇô RemoteΓÇ¥ or ΓÇ£UNIDIR GPP ΓÇô Geneva-based.ΓÇ¥
The deadline for applications is 31 January 2026, midnight Geneva time. Please note that incomplete, late, or AI-generated applications will not be considered. Only shortlisted candidates will be contacted.
Visit HERE for more information on any of the positions
Important: Applicants must provide proof of valid medical insurance coverage for the full programme duration and a medical certificate of good health prior to commencement.

Why Apply?
This is more than a temporary roleΓÇöit is a gateway into the UN system, offering a unique blend of research, policy development, and practical programme experience. Participants will engage directly with key disarmament and gender-related initiatives, contributing to global efforts for sustainable peace. The programme also offers professional mentorship and networking opportunities with international experts, which can be invaluable for future career development in international organizations.

Other Opportunities at UNIDIR

Associate Administrative Officer (P2) ΓÇô Geneva, closing 25 January 2026
Research Fellow (Space Security) ΓÇô 10 positions ΓÇô Remote, closing 31 January 2026

Stay updated on UNIDIRΓÇÖs latest programmes, publications, and events by subscribing to their newsletter.

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like this..
The post Graduate Professional Opportunities at UNIDIR: Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.
fields.text_en:
Graduate Professional Opportunities at UNIDIR: Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament

The United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research (UNIDIR) is inviting applications for its Graduate Professional Programme (GPP), offering two positions within the Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament programme. These positions present a unique opportunity for early-career professionals and recent graduates to contribute to international peace and security while gaining hands-on experience in a leading United Nations research institution.

About UNIDIR
UNIDIR is an autonomous research institute within the United Nations that specializes in disarmament and international security issues. Its mission is to foster a safer and more secure world by supporting Member States, the UN, and the research community in advancing actionable ideas for a peaceful global environment. The institute is headquartered in the Palais des Nations in Geneva, Switzerland, and conducts independent research that informs policy and practice in the field of disarmament.
The Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament programme focuses on generating policy-relevant knowledge, providing practical tools for multilateral practitioners, and promoting the integration of a gender perspective into arms control and disarmament work. The programme also emphasizes youth engagement, encouraging new voices to contribute to global security debates.

Position Details
UNIDIR is offering two Graduate Professional positions, one based in Geneva and the other remote. The appointments are temporary for six months, with the possibility of extension. The selected candidates will start in March 2026 and will work full-time (100% occupational rate).
Remuneration for the Geneva-based position includes a stipend of USD 1,331 per month, intended as a contribution to living expenses. Remote candidates will receive a reduced stipend, with adjustments if they already receive financial support from other sources. Travel, visa, accommodation, and other living expenses are the responsibility of the Graduate Professional or their sponsoring institution.

Key Responsibilities
Under the supervision of the Head of Programme, Graduate Professionals will:

Conduct background research on gender, youth, and disarmament issues.
Assist in planning and implementing programme activities, such as meetings, workshops, conferences, and field missions.
Support day-to-day tasks, including communications, coordination, and administrative work.
Perform additional tasks as required by programme staff.

This is a unique opportunity to gain exposure to the inner workings of a UN programme while contributing to practical and policy-oriented outputs.

Required Skills and Competencies
Candidates should demonstrate the following skills:

Research and presentation abilities, with the capacity to synthesize information into concise briefs.
Strong organizational skills and the ability to manage multiple tasks simultaneously.
Excellent interpersonal, teamwork, and communication skills (both written and oral).
Proficiency in Microsoft Office tools (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) and graphic design software such as InDesign.
A genuine interest in international peace and security, gender, youth engagement, and UN activities.

Core competencies expected include professionalism, integrity, and respect for diversity, as well as creativity, client orientation, and planning and organizing skills.

Qualifications
Applicants must meet one of the following educational requirements:

Be enrolled in a graduate programme (second university degree or higher), or
Have recently graduated with a relevant degree and be able to commence the Graduate Professional Programme within one year of graduation.

Preferred fields of study include international relations, political science, international law, and gender studies. Professional experience is not required, though interest or experience in conventional arms control will be considered an asset. Fluency in English is mandatory, and knowledge of additional UN languages is a plus.

Application Process
Interested candidates should submit:

A cover letter
The Inspira Personal History Form (PHP)
Brief responses (up to 30 words each) to screening questions addressing qualifications, language skills, software proficiency, organizational abilities, and any relevant publications

Applications must be submitted in PDF format titled SURNAME_Name_CV-CL to unidir.recruitment@un.org. The email subject line should indicate whether you are applying for ΓÇ£UNIDIR GPP ΓÇô RemoteΓÇ¥ or ΓÇ£UNIDIR GPP ΓÇô Geneva-based.ΓÇ¥
The deadline for applications is 31 January 2026, midnight Geneva time. Please note that incomplete, late, or AI-generated applications will not be considered. Only shortlisted candidates will be contacted.
Visit HERE for more information on any of the positions
Important: Applicants must provide proof of valid medical insurance coverage for the full programme duration and a medical certificate of good health prior to commencement.

Why Apply?
This is more than a temporary roleΓÇöit is a gateway into the UN system, offering a unique blend of research, policy development, and practical programme experience. Participants will engage directly with key disarmament and gender-related initiatives, contributing to global efforts for sustainable peace. The programme also offers professional mentorship and networking opportunities with international experts, which can be invaluable for future career development in international organizations.

Other Opportunities at UNIDIR

Associate Administrative Officer (P2) ΓÇô Geneva, closing 25 January 2026
Research Fellow (Space Security) ΓÇô 10 positions ΓÇô Remote, closing 31 January 2026

Stay updated on UNIDIRΓÇÖs latest programmes, publications, and events by subscribing to their newsletter.

Subscribe to OFY┬áfor more opportunities like this..
The post Graduate Professional Opportunities at UNIDIR: Integrated Approaches ΓÇô Gender and Disarmament appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

SuperPlane Inc.: Lead Frontend Engineer

Headquarters: USA
    URL: https://superplane.com/


About SuperPlane
SuperPlane is an AI-native DevOps control plane. Our mission is to build the platform teams use to ship and manage software in the AI era.
Agents are helping us write an order of magnitude more code, while systems have become too complex for human-driven ops alone. We're rethinking DevOps from first principles for the AI era: a single control layer where engineers and agents safely collaborate.
We move fast. We aim high. If that sounds like the kind of problem you want to work on, weΓÇÖd love to talk.
About the Role
At SuperPlane, youΓÇÖll shape the future of DevOps, creating features that bring intelligence, automation, and simplicity to complex infrastructure workflows.
You'll build interfaces that load instantly, feel flawless, and scale effortlessly. Every tooling choice, every pattern, every optimization decision is yours to make, and you'll be held accountable for the results.
What YouΓÇÖll Do


Own frontend features from conception to deployment: UI, state management, performance, polish.


Build responsive, performant interfaces that integrate seamlessly with backend APIs and services.


Collaborate with AI and Product teams to implement intelligent, user-facing automation features.


Review peers' work and set the standard for frontend engineering excellence.


Requirements


Expert-level React and modern frontend (TypeScript, performance optimization, build systems, testing)


Full-stack capable: you write backend code when needed without waiting on others. We expect you to learn Go when you join the team.


You are proficient with AI-assisted development (e.g., Claude Code)


You've built production systems that scale and stay fast




You push systems and yourself to world-class standards.


Communicate clearly and collaborate well across teams.


Why YouΓÇÖll Love Working at SuperPlane


Work on an open-source platform shaping the future of DevOps worldwide.


See your work used and relied on by engineers across the globe.


Competitive compensation & meaningful equity in a high-growth startup.


Fully remote and flexible environment that lets you focus and create.



To apply: https://weworkremotely.com/remote-jobs/superplane-inc-lead-frontend-engineer

The Business Analyst serves as a liaison between project teams, and vendors ensuring that everyone is aligned with the project goals and requirements.
Review the Triage defect that gets raised from the Production environment, prioritize, and groom the backlog
Review and validate deliverables submitted by the vendors
Data analysis and create the metrics for all the CSL tickets raised by the end customers
Quality Control of all the technical workstreams
Define and maintain the end-to-end process for functional Batch executions
Documentation and Governance by maintaining comprehensive documentation for project transparency, compliance, and knowledge management.
Draft Standard Operating Procedures
Prepare technical team presentations
As a Business Analyst you will provide system analysis, development, and production support
The C├║ram Business Analyst will design functional approaches to customize functionality using the C├║ram Business Application Suite
The Business Analyst is also a lead team member in the planningand execution of testing, training, support of user testing and customer support post implementation┬á
Lead requirement gathering sessions, according to agree upon project scope for various areas of the application
Participate in/lead systems analysis and gap analysis
Produce client-approved deliverables required in standard project development including functional requirements, training content, job aids, use cases, requirements traceability matrix, test cases and plans
Support team members through the development and testing of your functional designs

CONTRACT JOB DESCRIPTIONResponsibilities:1. Coordinates IT project management, engineering, maintenance, QA, and risk management.2. Plans, coordinates, and monitors project activities.3. Develops technical applications to support users.4. Develops, implements, maintains and enforces documented standards and procedures for the design, development, installation, modification, and documentation of assigned systems.5. Provides training for system products and procedures.6. Performs application upgrades.7. Performs, monitoring, maintenance, or reporting on real- time databases, real-time network and serial data communications, and real-time graphics and logic applications.8. Troubleshoots problems.9. Ensures project life-cycle is in compliance with District standards and procedures.

This is a remote position.

          Compensation: $65.00 - $70.00 per hour
        
 
About Us AHU Technologies INC. is an IT consulting and permanent staffing firm that meets and exceeds the evolving IT service needs of leading corporations within the United States. We have been providing IT solutions to customers from different industry sectors, helping them control costs and release internal resources to focus on strategic issues.┬á AHU Technologies INC. was co-founded by visionary young techno-commercial entrepreneurs who remain as our principal consultants. Maintaining working relationships with a cadre of other highly skilled independent consultants, we have a growing number of resources available for development projects. We are currently working on Various projects such as media entertainment, ERP Solutions, data warehousing, Web Applications, Telecommunications and medical to our clients all over the world.



To apply: https://weworkremotely.com/remote-jobs/ahu-technologies-curam-business-analyst

fields.raw_text:
SuperPlane Inc.: Senior Software Engineer

Headquarters: USA
    URL: https://superplane.com/


About SuperPlane
SuperPlane is an AI-native DevOps control plane. Our mission is to build the platform teams use to ship and manage software in the AI era.
Agents are helping us write an order of magnitude more code, while systems have become too complex for human-driven ops alone. We're rethinking DevOps from first principles for the AI era: a single control layer where engineers and agents safely collaborate.
We move fast. We aim high. If that sounds like the kind of problem you want to work on, weΓÇÖd love to talk.
About the Role
At SuperPlane, youΓÇÖll shape the future of DevOps, creating features that bring intelligence, automation, and simplicity to complex infrastructure workflows. Collaborating with Product, AI, and Design, youΓÇÖll build systems that developers love to rely on for every release and deployment.
This is a remote position open to candidates based in Europe and Latin America.
What YouΓÇÖll Do


Develop core features of SuperPlane from conception to deployment.


Develop APIs, integrations, and scalable services for multi-cloud environments.


Collaborate with the AI and Product teams to implement intelligent automation features.


Review peersΓÇÖ work and contribute to engineering best practices.


Continuously improve performance, security, and developer experience.


Requirements


You are a full-stack developer


You have deep knowledge of Go, Typescript, and/or React. We will also accept applicants who have deep knowledge of comparable technologies, but we will expect you to move fast and master React and Go as you join the team.


You are proficient with AI-assisted development (e.g., Claude Code)


Solid understanding of cloud-native technologies (Docker, Kubernetes, CI/CD).


You have expertise in designing secure, high-performance APIs and distributed systems.




You push systems and yourself to world-class standards.


Communicate clearly and collaborate well across teams.


Why YouΓÇÖll Love Working at SuperPlane


Work on an open-source platform shaping the future of DevOps worldwide.


See your work used and relied on by engineers across the globe.


Competitive compensation & meaningful equity in a high-growth startup.


Fully remote and flexible environment that lets you focus and create.



To apply: https://weworkremotely.com/remote-jobs/superplane-inc-senior-software-engineer

Note:- Interested applicants are invited to send their non-returnable application with CV and copies of relevant documents through the following address within 7 consecutive days from the first date of announcement.

Incomplete application will not be considered

Address:- Addis Ababa,Megenanya to the Way of Gurd Sholla Road Near to Century Mall,on TS BG Building 4th Floor Human Resource Dep;t Tel: 0116 67 67 38/0116 67 67 39

fields.raw_text:
Job Opportunity: Multi-Country Project Manager ΓÇô Soil Values Project (SNV)

Location: Abuja, Nigeria
Contract: Full-time, 3-year national contract (with possibility of extension)
Deadline: 1 February 2026
SNV, a leading global development organisation, is seeking a highly skilled and mission-driven Multi-Country Project Manager to lead a core component of the landmark Soil Values ProjectΓÇöa 10-year initiative transforming soil health and resilience across the Sahel.
About SNV
SNV is a global development partner with 60 years of experience strengthening systems in agri-food, energy, and water sectors across Africa and Asia. Operating in more than 20 countries, SNV is recognised for its commitment to impact, contextual adaptability, respect for diversity, and technical excellence. With a team of 1,600 staff, SNV catalyses partnerships, accelerates equitable development, and drives climate-resilient solutions.
Learn more: snv.org

About the Soil Values Programme (2024ΓÇô2033)
Funded by the Dutch government (DGIS), the Soil Values programme aims to restore soil fertility and boost climate resilience across Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, and Mali. Led by IFDC in consortium with SNV and Wageningen University, the programme will support:

Adoption of proven soil health technologies
Improved fertility on 2 million hectares of arable land
Benefits for 1.5 million smallholder food producers
Strengthened agroecology, inclusive markets, and supportive policy environments

SNVΓÇÖs role focuses on integrating community-driven, landscape-level approaches that combine nature-based solutions, local knowledge, and participatory watershed management.

About the Position
As the Multi-Country Project Manager, you will lead the INTEGRATE component of the Soil Values programme across four countries. You will steer a multi-country team, ensure technical excellence, maintain compliance with consortium requirements, and drive innovative agroecological and landscape management solutions in complex, conflict-sensitive environments.
This is a senior leadership role requiring systems thinking, inclusive management, and the ability to navigate cross-country dynamics and high-stake stakeholder partnerships.
Reporting to: Director of Country Programmes
Key partnerships: IFDC (consortium lead), Wageningen University, government institutions, local implementers, civil society, private sector, knowledge partners.

Key Responsibilities
1. Project Leadership & Technical Oversight

Provide strategic and operational leadership for the INTEGRATE component.
Oversee multi-country planning, financial management, quality assurance, MEL processes, and contract compliance.
Ensure strong governance structures, accountability, and knowledge management.
Lead adaptive management grounded in data, learning, and evidence.
Offer technical advisory support and troubleshoot implementation challenges.

2. Team Leadership & Staff Development

Lead and mentor a diverse multi-country team of eight professionals.
Build collaborative, high-performing, and inclusive work cultures.
Ensure staff safety, well-being, and adherence to SNVΓÇÖs Code of Conduct.

3. Stakeholder Engagement & Partnership Management

Represent SNV in the IFDC project management team.
Strengthen partnerships with government, private sector, civil society, and academic institutions.
Foster cross-project collaboration for scaled impact.
Oversee partner procurement, grant agreements, and quality delivery.


Essential Qualifications

MasterΓÇÖs degree in Rural Development, Livestock Development, Pastoralism, Economics, Sociology, Geography, or related fields.
10+ years leading complex, multi-stakeholder development projects in the agri-food sectorΓÇöideally in the Sahel or conflict-sensitive settings.
Strong experience in agroecology, landscape management, climate-smart agriculture, or natural resource management.
Proven ability to lead multicultural, multidisciplinary teams across countries.
Strong donor coordination and partnership management experience.
Fluency in English and French, with excellent writing and presentation skills.

Preferred Qualifications

Experience integrating GESI, adaptive management, and good governance approaches.
Background in systems thinking and innovation in fragile environments.
Skills in GIS, digital tools, or spatial planning.
Experience with results-based management frameworks.
Prior professional experience in one or more Sahel countries.


Contract & Working Conditions

Type: National contract (open to nationals across the Sahel region)
Duration: Initial 3 years
Location: Abuja, Nigeria, with frequent travel to programme countries
Start Date: 1 April 2026

SNV offers a dynamic, multicultural work environment, opportunities for professional growth, international career development pathways, and a culture grounded in the CARE principles: Commitment to Impact, Adaptive to Context, Respecting Differences, and Expertise in Practice.

How to Apply
If you meet the essential requirements and are inspired by this opportunity, please submit your CV and motivation letter via SmartRecruiters by:
Deadline: 1 February 2026
Only candidates who meet the qualifications and are available to work in Abuja should apply.
Career page: Vacancies | SNV
Follow SNV on LinkedIn to stay updated on new opportunities.

Safeguarding & Vetting
SNV conducts reference checks and participates in the Inter-Agency Misconduct Disclosure Scheme (MDS). All shortlisted candidates will undergo safeguarding vetting, including a Statement of Conduct from previous employers, handled with strict confidentiality and care.
For more information: Click Here
The post Job Opportunity: Multi-Country Project Manager ΓÇô Soil Values Project (SNV) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
DAWN Rising Fellowship 2026: Opportunity for Young Women Feminists from the Global South

Development Alternatives with Women for a New Era (DAWN) has opened applications for the 2026 DAWN Rising Fellowship, a prestigious opportunity supporting young women feminists from the Global South. Launching its second cycle following a highly successful inaugural fellowship in 2025, this programme nurtures emerging feminist leaders who are committed to advancing gender justice in conflict-affected contexts.
About the Fellowship
As part of its 40th-anniversary initiatives, DAWN created this fellowship to strengthen feminist research, advocacy, mobilisation, resistance, and creative expression. Each year, the fellowship focuses on a core theme within DAWNΓÇÖs Political Economy of Gender framework.
The 2026 cycle continues to focus on:
The Political Economy of Gender-Based Violence and Conflict
The fellowship supports one young woman feminist to develop a project that deepens the understanding of how gender-based violence and conflict shape gendered power relations and influence womenΓÇÖs lives. The selected fellow will also contribute to amplifying feminist perspectives in local and international public discourse.
Geographic Focus for 2026
For this cycle, applications are accepted only for projects focused on conflict-affected contexts in:

Sudan
Palestine
Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC)

Projects focused on other regions will not be considered.

Objectives
The fellowship aims to:

Support innovative feminist projects related to gender-based violence and conflict.
Increase visibility and impact of feminist perspectives on political economy issues.
Provide platforms for young women feminists to share their work globally.


Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must:

Be women feminists under 40 years old.
Be from the Global South.
Demonstrate a strong commitment to feminist principles and methodologies.
Submit a project aligned with The Political Economy of Gender-Based Violence and Conflict.
Propose work focused on Sudan, Palestine, or the DRC.
Apply as individuals (organisations or collectives are not eligible).


Fellowship Benefits
Financial Support

A stipend of USD 1,200/month for 10 months
Can be used toward research, materials, travel, or living costs
Applicants must declare other sources of funding if applicable

Mentorship & Network

Access to DAWNΓÇÖs network of feminist activists, researchers, and advocates

Visibility & Publications

Opportunities to share findings via DAWN platforms and events
Publication under Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND 4.0


Fellow Expectations
Fellows are expected to:

Produce agreed-upon project outputs
Meet project deadlines
Present work at DAWN events
Submit mid-term and final reports


Application Process
Applications must be submitted exclusively through the official online form. Email submissions will not be accepted.
Three Required Components:

Online Application Form
Official Fillable Application Document (PDF)

Must include project objectives, methodology, outcomes, and timeline
Upload through the online form


Supporting Documents

Curriculum Vitae (CV)
Statement of Motivation
One letter of recommendation from a non-related referee



Language Requirements

All materials must be submitted in English
AI translation tools allowed, but fellows must be able to participate in English


Timeline



Stage
Date




Call for Applications
19 January 2026


Application Deadline
1 March 2026


Selection Completed
30 April 2026 (only shortlisted applicants will be notified)


Fellowship Start
Between 1 May and 30 June 2026




Learn more: Click Here

┬á
The post DAWN Rising Fellowship 2026: Opportunity for Young Women Feminists from the Global South appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
2026 Sakharov Fellowship Programme for Human Rights Defenders: Fully Funded Training in Brussels and an EU Member State

The European Parliament has opened applications for the 2026 Sakharov Fellowship Programme, a fully funded, two-week intensive training designed for human rights defenders from non-EU countries.
Organised annually since 2016 by the Sakharov Prize Community, the Sakharov Fellowship is a capacity-building programme┬áthat equips human rights defenders with practical skills, policy knowledge, and international networks to strengthen their advocacy and impact.
About the Sakharov Fellowship Programme
The programme offers selected fellows the opportunity to participate in an immersive training experience in Brussels and another EU Member State, engaging directly with EU institutions, policymakers, and the international human rights community.
Fellows receive in-depth exposure to:


EU policies and mechanisms supporting human rights defenders


The human rights work of the European Parliament and EU institutions


Practical tools for advocacy, security, resilience, and documentation


Participants become members of the Sakharov Community of Human Rights Defenders, maintaining long-term engagement with the European Parliament and EU Delegations in their countries.
What the Fellowship Covers
The Sakharov Fellowship is fully funded and includes:


Return international travel from the country of residence


Accommodation during the full programme


A daily living allowance


Access to all training sessions, workshops, and networking events


Programme Content
The two-week programme includes:


Meetings with Members of the European Parliament (MEPs)


Engagement with EU officials and Brussels-based human rights organisations


Workshops on communication, advocacy, security, disinformation, resilience, and well-being


Training on documenting human rights violations


Dedicated time for individual advocacy, networking, and communication activities


Who Can Apply
Applicants must:


Be human rights defenders from non-EU countries


Have a proven record of campaigning for human rights, either through an organisation or independently


Demonstrate a high level of English, sufficient to actively participate in the programme


Selection also considers:


Gender balance


A wide range of human rights themes


Geographic diversity aligned with the European ParliamentΓÇÖs political priorities


Selection Process and Notification
Applications close on 15 February 2026 at midnight (CET).
Successful applicants will be notified by 9 March 2026 via email.
Programme Dates: 7ΓÇô20 June 2026
Due to the high volume of applications, unsuccessful candidates will not receive individual feedback.
How to Apply
Interested candidates must complete the official application form:
APPLY HERE
For more information about this opportunity,┬áclick here. 
For more other fellowship opportunities, click here.
The post 2026 Sakharov Fellowship Programme for Human Rights Defenders: Fully Funded Training in Brussels and an EU Member State appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Fully Funded Short Course ΓÇö The Economics of Artificial Intelligence in Africa

As Artificial Intelligence (AI) reshapes markets, labor systems, and power structures across Africa, understanding its economic implications has never been more critical. To meet this growing need, the Global Center on AI Governance, in partnership with the University of the Witwatersrand, is offering a fully funded short course: The Economics of Artificial Intelligence in Africa.
This prestigious program empowers professionals, researchers, and policymakers to assess how AI is transforming African economiesΓÇöand how strategic policies, regulation, and investment can shape the continentΓÇÖs AI future.

About the Course
Designed for public officials, regional and international development practitioners, private-sector professionals, researchers, and academics, this five-week online program provides:

A deep understanding of how AI impacts economic development across Africa
Tools to analyse economic, political, and regulatory dynamics of AI
Skills to assess policy options, investment strategies, and governance pathways
Engagement with leading African and global AI scholars
Practical insights through case studies, discussions, and reflective assessments

Participants who successfully complete the course will receive a Certificate of Competence from the University of the Witwatersrand.

Entry Requirements
Applicants should demonstrate:
Academic Background
A bachelorΓÇÖs degree or equivalent in fields such as public policy, economics, AI, development studies, African studies, or related disciplines.
Professional Experience
Experience in governance, policymaking, public service, economic development, or international development is strongly encouraged.
Geographic & Institutional Diversity
Applicants should note their location, scope of work, and institutional affiliation to support the courseΓÇÖs continental diversity.

Course Modules
Topics include:

AI and Economic Development Pathways in Africa
Financing and Investing in AfricaΓÇÖs AI Economy
AI, Regional Trade, and Market Integration
Competition, Fairness, and Market Power
African Data Economies & Digital Infrastructure
AI and Sustainable Entrepreneurship
Sectoral Transformation through AI
Governance, Ethics, and the Political Economy of AI
AI and Intellectual Property
AI, Labor Markets, Skills, and the Future of Work

A policy-focused hackathon and applied case studies enhance practical learning.

Course Details

Application Deadline: 9 February 2026
Course Dates: 2 March ΓÇô 9 April 2026
Duration: 5 weeks (online)
Format: Live virtual seminars + interactive sessions
Available Seats: 25
Cost: Fully funded scholarships
Course Coordinator: Maria Matsoso


Why Apply?

Gain leading-edge knowledge on AIΓÇÖs economic impact in Africa
Learn from top scholars and practitioners
Build a continent-wide professional network
Strengthen your capacity to influence AI policy, innovation, and regulation
Earn a respected certificate from a top African university


Apply Now
Secure your spot in this competitive, fully funded course:
Applications close 9 February 2026

For more information: Click Here
Apply Now!
The post Fully Funded Short Course ΓÇö The Economics of Artificial Intelligence in Africa appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Volunteer Opportunity: Become a Mentor with UN Women and Empower Women Entrepreneurs Across Europe & Central Asia

UN Women is inviting passionate professionals, business leaders, and industry experts to join its Mentor Network for the Regional WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPOΓÇöa transformative initiative shaping the future of women-led businesses across Europe and Central Asia.
If youΓÇÖre committed to womenΓÇÖs empowerment and eager to support the next generation of entrepreneurs, this is your chance to make a meaningful impact.

About the WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPO
Launched in 2021 by the UN Women Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia (UN Women ECARO), the WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPO is a pioneering platform designed to strengthen the ecosystem for women entrepreneurs.
The program is implemented across 14 countries: Albania, Armenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kosovo (under UNSCR 1244), Kyrgyzstan, Montenegro, Moldova, North Macedonia, Serbia, Tajikistan, T├╝rkiye, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan.
Starting February 2026, UN Women will work closely with 65 scalable women-led companies (five from each participating country) over a three-month intensive growth journey. Selected businesses will engage in group sessions, receive personalized mentorship, and ultimately pitch their ideas at the EXPO Capital QuestΓÇöan event designed to catalyze investment and expansion.
To ensure each entrepreneur receives the right support, mentors will be matched based on their expertise and the specific needs of the businesses.

Why Become a Mentor?
As part of the Mentor Network, you will:
Share Your Expertise

Your guidance doesnΓÇÖt just benefit one companyΓÇöit strengthens communities, boosts economic growth, and promotes gender equality.
This mentorship initiative is more than a program. It is a movementΓÇöa collective effort to ensure women entrepreneurs thrive and contribute their full potential to society.

UN Women is inviting passionate professionals, business leaders, and industry experts to join its Mentor Network for the Regional WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPOΓÇöa transformative initiative shaping the future of women-led businesses across Europe and Central Asia.
If youΓÇÖre committed to womenΓÇÖs empowerment and eager to support the next generation of entrepreneurs, this is your chance to make a meaningful impact.

About the WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPO
Launched in 2021 by the UN Women Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia (UN Women ECARO), the WomenΓÇÖs Entrepreneurship EXPO is a pioneering platform designed to strengthen the ecosystem for women entrepreneurs.
The program is implemented across 14 countries: Albania, Armenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kosovo (under UNSCR 1244), Kyrgyzstan, Montenegro, Moldova, North Macedonia, Serbia, Tajikistan, T├╝rkiye, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan.
Starting February 2026, UN Women will work closely with 65 scalable women-led companies (five from each participating country) over a three-month intensive growth journey. Selected businesses will engage in group sessions, receive personalized mentorship, and ultimately pitch their ideas at the EXPO Capital QuestΓÇöan event designed to catalyze investment and expansion.
To ensure each entrepreneur receives the right support, mentors will be matched based on their expertise and the specific needs of the businesses.

fields.raw_text:
Call for Applications: IP Youth Workshop Coordinator (Contract Role, 2026ΓÇô2027)

Applications are now open for the position of IP Youth Workshop Coordinator, a strategic coordination role supporting an international, Indigenous-led youth workshop focused on inclusive participation, cultural integrity, and community-driven outcomes.
This role is ideal for professionals with strong project coordination, partnership management, and youth or Indigenous engagement experience, who are motivated to support ethical, values-driven, and intercultural collaboration processes.
Key Responsibilities
1. Coordination and Partnership Management
The Coordinator will support the core organizing teamΓÇöincluding Indigenous Youth Leads, GYBN, FAR, and partner organizationsΓÇöby facilitating coordination across stakeholders. Responsibilities include organizing regular coordination calls, tracking timelines and deliverables, documenting decisions, and maintaining effective communication among partners, facilitators, and logistics teams.
2. Fundraising Support
The role includes supporting ongoing fundraising efforts by drafting or co-drafting fundraising materials, assisting donor outreach and follow-ups, coordinating reporting linked to new grants, and maintaining a transparent and updated fundraising tracker.
3. Program Design and Content Preparation
The Coordinator will support the design of the workshop agenda and learning journey, ensuring alignment with Indigenous worldviews, intersectionality, and local community realities. This includes coordinating inputs from Indigenous designers and cultural knowledge holders, as well as organizing preparatory materials and participant resource packs.
4. Application and Selection Process
The Coordinator will manage the full application process, including launching the call for applications, overseeing dissemination strategies, managing the application system (e.g., Google Forms), responding to inquiries, coordinating the selection committee, scheduling interviews, documenting outcomes, and communicating final decisions to applicants.
5. Participant Coordination and Logistics
Following participant selection, the Coordinator will work closely with the logistics team to support visa processes, travel arrangements, accommodation planning aligned with cultural and safety considerations, and clear communication with participants before the workshop.
6. Workshop Delivery Support
Depending on final planning, the Coordinator may provide on-the-ground support during the workshop, coordinating facilitatorsΓÇÖ needs, session flow, daily adjustments, documentation, and communication with youth participants, elders, partners, and support staff.
7. Documentation and Reporting
The role includes maintaining organized records, supporting narrative and financial reporting, preparing a final internal report capturing learnings and recommendations, and leading internal debrief or reflection sessions.
Key Deliverables


Updated fundraising tracker and coordinated fundraising actions


Workshop design plan (agenda, structure, and timeline)


Application call package and dissemination plan


Completed application and selection workflow


Participant list and pre-workshop briefing materials


Logistics coordination support


Workshop delivery support


Final internal summary report with recommendations


Qualifications
Required


Proven experience coordinating multi-stakeholder workshops, preferably international or intercultural


Strong organizational, project management, and documentation skills


Experience working with Indigenous communities and/or youth-led spaces


Cultural sensitivity and ability to engage respectfully across diverse contexts


Fluency in English (written and spoken)


Familiarity with Google Workspace tools


Ability to work independently and within distributed teams


Preferred


Indigenous candidates are strongly encouraged to apply


Experience in fundraising or grant writing


Background in youth programming, social movements, policy, or capacity-building


Familiarity with biodiversity, climate justice, rights-based conservation, or UN processes


Fluency in additional UN languages


Values and Working Principles
This role requires strong alignment with:


Respect for Indigenous sovereignty and knowledge systems


Youth leadership and agency


Cultural humility and ethics of care


Solidarity, collaboration, and transparency


Application Process
Applicants must submit:


A completed Google Form application


A resume/CV uploaded via the form


Contact details of one referee


The selection process includes application review, shortlisting, online interviews, and final notification by email.
Compensation details will be shared with shortlisted and interview-confirmed candidates.
Application Deadline: 2 February 2026, 11:59 PM (UTC)Contract Period: 1 March 2026 ΓÇô 31 January 2027
For more information about this job opportunity, click here.
Click here to start your application.
For more other job opportunities,┬áclick here.

fields.raw_text:
WIPO Global Awards 2026 Open for Innovative Startups and SMEs Worldwide

The World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) is the United Nations agency dedicated to supporting innovators and creators worldwide. WIPO helps enterprises protect and commercialize intellectual property across borders, promotes fair access to IP systems, and ensures innovation contributes to global development.
The WIPO Global Awards 2026 are now open, inviting innovative startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from around the world to apply for one of the most prestigious international recognitions for intellectual propertyΓÇôdriven businesses. Now in its 5th edition, the WIPO Global Awards celebrate enterprises that strategically use intellectual property (IP) to grow their businesses, enter new markets, and deliver meaningful social, economic, and environmental impact aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
Applications are open to eligible startups and SMEs from all 194 WIPO Member States and across all economic sectors.
Award Categories and Recognition
In 2026, 11 enterprises will be recognized:


10 Global Awards across all sectors (including health, agrifood, environment, ICT, and creative industries)


1 Thematic Prize for SMEs in Sports, aligned with World IP Day 2026


2 Special Mentions:


Best Woman Entrepreneur


Best Youth Entrepreneur




Benefits for Award Winners
Selected enterprises will receive:


Global visibility through the WIPOΓÇôUnited Nations system


A tailored 6-month mentorship programme on IP commercialization and business strategy


Access to investors, corporates, institutions, and IP service providers


Exclusive benefits and strategic business connections


An invitation to Geneva, Switzerland, to attend the Awards Ceremony during the WIPO Assemblies


The WIPO Assemblies bring together over 1,600 global leaders, including ministers, heads of IP offices, and senior government representatives shaping the international IP ecosystem.
Evaluation Criteria
Applications are assessed based on:


Strength of the business model and IP protection strategy


Clarity and feasibility of the IP commercialization plan


Internal IP culture within the enterprise


Contribution to sustainable development and societal impact


Why Apply
Past winners have reported tangible outcomes, including:


Successful fundraising rounds


Expansion into new international markets


New patent filings


Stronger and more strategic IP portfolios


In 2025 alone, the competition received over 780 applications from 95 countries, representing a 20% increase from the previous year.
Eligibility


Open to startups and SMEs from all economic sectors


Applicants must be based in one of WIPOΓÇÖs 194 Member States


Applications accepted in English, French, Spanish, Arabic, Chinese, and Russian


How to Apply
Applications are submitted online via the official WIPO platform.
Application Deadline: 31 March 2026 (23:59 CET)
APPLY HERE
For more information about this opportunity,┬áclick here.
Click here for more other opportunities.

fields.raw_text:
UNESCOΓÇôEquatorial Guinea Fellowship Programme 2026 for Young Women Scientists in Africa

The UNESCOΓÇôEquatorial Guinea Fellowship Programme for Young Women Scientists in Africa (2nd Edition) is now open for applications, offering a prestigious and fully funded opportunity for outstanding African women researchers in the life sciences.
Globally, women account for only 33% of researchers, and in Sub-Saharan Africa, this figure drops to 32%, according to UNESCO. These disparities are further intensified by limited access to research funding, infrastructure, and international scientific networks. In response, UNESCO launched a Call to Action to Close the Gender Gap in Science, emphasizing the need to expand funding opportunities and strengthen global research networks for women scientists.
Established in 2024 by UNESCOΓÇÖs Executive Board and funded by the Republic of Equatorial Guinea, this fellowship programme is designed to bridge persistent gender and regional gaps in scientific research across Africa. Each year, two exceptional young African women scientists are awarded USD 25,000 each to advance innovative research projects in the life sciences and contribute to sustainable development in their home countries.
Fellowship Objectives
The programme aims to:


Promote innovation and excellence in life sciences research


Support the production of high-quality scientific outputs, including publications and patents


Strengthen leadership and mentorship capacity among young women scientists


Encourage contributions to sustainable development goals (SDGs) through science


Foster regional and international scientific collaboration


Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must:


Be of African nationality


Be under 45 years of age at the time of application


Hold a PhD in a life sciencesΓÇôrelated field


Conduct research at a recognized laboratory in Africa


Be actively engaged in scientific research contributing to sustainable development


Selection Criteria
Applications will be assessed based on:


Scientific innovation and research impact


Academic and professional achievements in the life sciences


Publications, patents, or other scientific outputs


Recognition through awards, grants, or fellowships


Alignment with UNESCOΓÇÖs vision for science and sustainable development


Grant Value and Disbursement


USD 25,000 per fellow


USD 23,000 disbursed at the start of the project


USD 2,000 released upon submission of a final technical and financial report


Eligible Scientific Fields


Medical and Health Sciences


Neuroscience


Molecular, Cellular, and Structural Biology


Environmental and Ecological Sciences


Agricultural Sciences


Bioinformatics and Computational Biology


Biomedical Engineering


Chemical and Physical Sciences


Astronomy, Space and Earth Sciences


Mathematical Sciences (where applicable to life sciences research)


Application Process
Applications must be submitted online in English or French and should include:


A one-year research proposal


A detailed work plan and timeline


A comprehensive budget breakdown


Summary of past research and key publications


A detailed academic CV


Two recommendation letters from senior academics or peers


Who Can Submit Nominations


Governments of African Member States, in consultation with National Commissions


Self-nominations are not accepted


Late or incomplete applications will not be considered.
Deadline: 31 March 2026
Applications must be submitted through the official portal:https://www.unesco.org/egip/account-request
For more information about this opportunity,┬áclick here.
For more other fellowship opportunities, click here.
The post UNESCOΓÇôEquatorial Guinea Fellowship Programme 2026 for Young Women Scientists in Africa appeared first on Opportunities for Youth.

fields.raw_text:
Productive Shop: Web graphic designer

Headquarters: Sao Paulo, Brazil
    URL: http://productiveshop.com


Ready to design websites that do more than just look good? At Productive Shop, we believe great design is the engine of growth, translating a brandΓÇÖs unique essence into a powerful, high-converting digital experience.
Productive Shop is a growth partner for ambitious B2B SaaS companies. We donΓÇÖt just build websites; we build strategic assets that become a core part of our clients' growth. WeΓÇÖre looking for a passionate designer who is excited by the challenge of turning business goals into beautiful, intuitive, and effective user experiences.
We are builders at heart and we value quality, integrity, and collaboration. If you find deep satisfaction in creating designs that have a measurable impact on a company's success, this is the place for you.

About the role

This is a role for a strategic visual storyteller. As a Senior UI/UX Designer, you will be the visual heart of our projects, relied upon to grasp the core essence of our B2B SaaS clients' brands and communicate it compellingly through the web.

You will be responsible for turning complex business challenges into clear, engaging, and high-performing web experiences. Working directly with our founders and strategists, youΓÇÖll translate client goals and brand identity into powerful visual systems that guide users to action. You will live in Figma, but your impact will be seen directly in our clients' growth and pipeline.

What youΓÇÖll do


Lead the design of new website concepts and guide the strategic redesign of key pages to drive user action.
Craft high-impact, conversion-focused landing pages that turn website traffic into qualified leads.
Develop mood boards and create comprehensive UX/UI kits in Figma that establish a clear, compelling visual direction for every project.
Build and maintain scalable design systems that ensure brand consistency and efficiency across all digital touchpoints.
Collaborate closely with our development and SEO teams to ensure your designs are not only beautiful but also technically sound and optimized for performance.


What you bring

A minimum of 5 years of professional UI/UX design experience, with a portfolio that showcases your expertise in a B2B agency or in-house at a SaaS company.
Complete mastery of Figma. You live and breathe its components, auto-layout, and prototyping features.
A deep understanding that for a B2B SaaS audience, clarity, trust, and function are the foundation of beautiful design.
You are a designer who thinks about the entire business pipeline and gets immense satisfaction from seeing your work solve real-world problems.
Strong communication skills and the ability to articulate the strategic thinking and brand considerations behind your design decisions.
Your portfolio clearly demonstrates your ability to create exceptional web experiences that drive user action and deliver on business objectives.


To apply: https://weworkremotely.com/remote-jobs/productive-shop-web-graphic-designer

fields.raw_text:
McCain Global Leaders Program 2026: Fully Funded Global Leadership Program Advancing Democracy & Human Rights

The McCain Global Leaders Program (MGL) 2026 is now open for applications. This prestigious, fully funded global leadership program is designed for mid- to senior-career professionals committed to advancing democracy, defending human rights, and creating opportunity in their countries and regions.
Delivered by the McCain Institute, the program brings together a diverse global cohort of leaders working across civil society, government, media, policy, business, and social impact sectors. Over 12 months, participants engage in intensive leadership development, global peer learning, and in-person international experiences inspired by the legacy and values of Senator John McCain.
Application deadline: 15 March 2026 (11:59 PM Eastern Standard Time)

Overview of the McCain Global Leaders Program
The McCain Global Leaders Program is a non-residential, 12-month leadership fellowship that combines global and regional learning to help leaders respond to todayΓÇÖs most pressing challenges, including democratic backsliding, authoritarianism, disinformation, shrinking civic space, and human rights violations.
Participants take part in a carefully designed curriculum that integrates:

Global and regional peer networks
Leadership development grounded in democratic values
Practical skills training and policy engagement
Peer mentorship and collaborative problem-solving

The program connects leaders to both regional cohorts and a global community of peers, strengthening cross-border collaboration and long-term impact.
2026 Global Theme: Advancing Freedom, Defending Rights, Creating Opportunity
Across the world, democratic norms and fundamental freedoms are under increasing threat. Authoritarian actors are exploiting technology, polarization, and global instability to weaken democratic institutions and restrict civic participation. At the same time, younger generations face declining opportunities to shape their futures.
The 2026 McCain Global Leaders cohort will focus on identifying and advancing solutions that:

Strengthen democratic governance and institutions
Defend human rights and the rule of law
Counter authoritarian and malign influence
Expand civic, political, and economic opportunity

The program is built on the belief that while global challenges are growing more complex, a new generation of principled leaders can expand freedom and democracy in every region of the world.
2026 Regional Themes
Applicants apply under one regional focus area while participating in global-level programming and collaboration.
Western Hemisphere: Building Partnerships, Advancing Migration Solutions
This regional cohort brings together leaders addressing the root causes of migration as well as those working on migration policy and frontline responses. The focus is on regional cooperation, humane migration systems, and solutions that uphold dignity while respecting national sovereignty and public safety.
Europe and Eurasia: Countering Authoritarians through Freedom, Democracy, and Human Rights
The Europe and Eurasia cohort addresses democratic backsliding, disinformation, foreign interference, rising nationalism, and extremism. Participants examine both internal and external threats to democracy and develop strategies to strengthen democratic resilience across the region.
Africa and the Middle East: From Protest to Policy ΓÇô Growing Democracy for All
This cohort explores political transitions, inclusive governance, and citizen engagement in contexts marked by political and security instability. Leaders focus on translating civic activism and protest movements into sustainable policy reform, democratic institutions, and accountable governance.
Asia and Oceania: Creating Stability by Advancing Democracy and Freedom
Participants examine youth-led democratic transitions, authoritarian pressures, and great-power competition shaping the region. The cohort focuses on how advancing democracy and human rights can foster long-term political and economic stability.

Program Structure and Timeline (June 2026 ΓÇô May 2027)
The McCain Global Leaders Program runs for 12 months and includes approximately 25 days of in-person programming, complemented by regular virtual engagement.
Leadership Curriculum (Throughout the Program)
Participants complete a leadership curriculum delivered online and in person. The curriculum draws on lessons from Senator John McCainΓÇÖs life and leadership, emphasizing integrity, service, courage, and collaboration. A central component is a peer-mentorship model that supports leadership growth and collective problem-solving.
Fall 2026: Leadership Experience ΓÇô Athens, Greece
The first in-person convening brings the full cohort together for a seven-day leadership experience in Athens, the birthplace of democracy. Participants engage with global experts and decision-makers, develop leadership philosophies, set career goals, and design impact projects to implement during the program year.
Winter 2026/2027: Changemaker Tours ΓÇô Regional Host Countries
Each regional cohort participates in a five-day study tour focused on defending democracy in practice. These tours build regional networks, expose participants to policy environments, and encourage professional collaboration. Previous host countries have included Colombia, Guatemala, Estonia, Finland, Kenya, Poland, Singapore, Taiwan, and South Africa.
Spring 2027: Legacy Experience ΓÇô Vietnam
The program concludes with a global capstone experience in Vietnam, a country central to Senator McCainΓÇÖs personal leadership journey. Leaders reflect on their growth, share lessons learned, explore future collaborations, and transition into the McCain Global Leaders Alumni Network.
┬á
Funding, Stipend, and Cost Coverage
The McCain Global Leaders Program is fully funded. There is no participation fee.
The McCain Institute covers:

Economy-class international travel
Accommodation during program convenings
Program-related visas and logistics

Participants also receive a stipend to offset incidental expenses incurred during the program. The primary cost to participants is the time and commitment required to fully engage.
┬á
Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must meet the following requirements:

Mid- to senior-career professionals
Minimum of five years of professional experience
Strong working proficiency in English
Demonstrated leadership roles or leadership potential
Active engagement in issues aligned with the programΓÇÖs global and regional themes

There is no age limit and no minimum educational requirement. Applicants from all countries and professional backgrounds are encouraged to apply. Selection is based on leadership capacity, vision, service orientation, and alignment with program themes.
┬á
Time Commitment and Expectations
Participants are expected to:

Take part in all required in-person and virtual program activities
Commit approximately 6ΓÇô8 hours per month to virtual engagement
Adhere to a professional code of conduct
Secure required travel documents and visas

Completion of the program grants lifelong membership in the McCain Global Leaders Alumni Network, offering continued access to mentorship, collaboration opportunities, and global leadership support

Application Process and Deadline

Application window: 26 January ΓÇô 15 March 2026
Deadline: 15 March 2026 at 11:59 PM Eastern Standard Time
Applications must be submitted through the official online portal
The review process may take up to three months

Applicants who are not selected are encouraged to apply again in future cycles.
Click┬áHERE┬áto apply
┬á
Frequently Asked Questions






Have a question about the McCain Global Leaders program? Please take a look at these commonly asked questions and our responses.┬á If you canΓÇÖt find your answer here, please email┬áleadershipinitiatives@mccaininstitute.org┬áand we will get you a response as soon as possible.














Who is eligible to apply?

Applicants should be mid- to senior-career professionals with strong workingΓÇ»proficiencyΓÇ»in English who are actively engaged in issue areas related to the programΓÇÖs global and regional themes. Candidates should hold leadership roles, be actively working to create positive change in theirΓÇ»communities, andΓÇ»demonstrate a commitment to serving a cause greater than themselves.ΓÇ»┬á
Applicants should have at least five years of professional experience. ThereΓÇ»isΓÇ»no age requirement and noΓÇ»minimumΓÇ»educational requirement. Individuals from all countries and professional backgrounds are encouraged to apply.ΓÇ»SelectionΓÇ»is┬ábased on leadership capacity, vision, service orientation, and fulfillment of eligibility requirements.ΓÇ»┬á



Are there regional or thematic tracks?

Yes. Each cohort is organized around a globalΓÇ»theme,ΓÇ»and each region is organized around a regional specific theme.ΓÇ»Applicants shouldΓÇ»demonstrateΓÇ»experience or interest in both the global and regional themes, as study tours and impact projects are designed with these themes in mind. The 2026 global and regional themes are available on the McCain Global Leaders program page.ΓÇ»┬á



What is the application deadline?

The application periodΓÇ»runs from January 26, 2026,ΓÇ»through March 15,ΓÇ»2026,ΓÇ»atΓÇ»11:59ΓÇ»PM.ΓÇ»Eastern Standard Time. All applications must beΓÇ»submittedΓÇ»through theΓÇ»onlineΓÇ»portal;ΓÇ»emailedΓÇ»materialsΓÇ»will not be considered.ΓÇ»



What are the expectations of a McCain Global Leader for the program year?

ΓÇ»MGLsΓÇ»are required toΓÇ»participateΓÇ»in all in-person and virtual program components. The program includes approximatelyΓÇ»25 daysΓÇ»of in-person programming across three travel experiences and an estimated 6ΓÇô8 hours per month of virtual engagement.ΓÇ»ΓÇ»SomeΓÇ»additionalΓÇ»work and reflectionΓÇ»areΓÇ»expected outside of scheduled sessions, with consideration given to participantsΓÇÖ professional and personal responsibilities.ΓÇ»┬á
All participants must sign and adhere to a code of conduct emphasizing respect, professionalism, and integrity. MGLsΓÇ»are responsible forΓÇ»understanding entry requirements for host countries and securing any required visas. Failure to meet program expectations or uphold the code of conduct may result in removal from the program.ΓÇ»┬á
Participation in individual or collaborative projects inspired by the program is encouraged but notΓÇ»required. Graduates join an active alumni community upon completion of the program.ΓÇ»┬á



What is the program timeline and format?

The program runs for 12 months and runs from June 2026 through May 2027. Participants are expected to fully engage throughout the program year. A detailed calendar will be shared with applicants who advance to the second round of interviews.ΓÇ»Travel locations and datesΓÇ»areΓÇ»not shared publicly before then.ΓÇ»Virtual sessions are held on Zoom during Eastern Standard Time and most often take place at 9:00 AM Eastern Standard Time.ΓÇ»┬á



Will I receive a stipend?

Yes, participants will receive a stipend meant to cover incidental expenses incurred throughout the program.ΓÇ»However,ΓÇ»the direct costs of participation in the program┬á(economyΓÇ»class travel, hotels, visas) will be fully covered by the McCain Institute.ΓÇ»ΓÇ»There will be no cost of participation other than the time commitment that MGLs make toΓÇ»participateΓÇ»in programming.ΓÇ»┬á



How long is the review process?

The review process may take up to 3 months from the close of the application window.ΓÇ»┬á



Can I apply again if I am not selected?

Yes. Many selected leaders are repeat applicants. You are encouraged to reapply if your leadership experience, impact, or project vision has grown since your last application.ΓÇ»┬á



What happens after the program year ends?

Graduates join the McCain Global Leaders Alumni Network, gaining ongoing access to global peers, collaboration opportunities, alumni events, mentorship, and continued leadership support.ΓÇ»









Contact Information
For additional questions about the McCain Global Leaders Program, contact:
leadershipinitiatives@mccaininstitute.org
┬á

ΓÇö Senator John McCain

FAO Schwarz Fellowship at 826 Boston

826 Boston, a nationally recognized nonprofit dedicated to youth writing, tutoring, and publishing, is proud to host two FAO Schwarz Fellows for the 2026ΓÇô2028 Fellowship cycle. This transformative, two-year opportunity is designed for recent college graduates passionate about social equity, education, storytelling, and community impact.
Through individualized student support and organization-wide strategic projects, Fellows will play a key role in amplifying young voices across Boston while developing leadership, professional, and programmatic expertise.
Boston, Massachusetts | Fellowship Start: Summer 2026

About 826 Boston
Founded in 2007, 826 Boston is a nonprofit writing, tutoring, and publishing organization serving students in grades KΓÇô12 and beyond. Our mission is rooted in the belief that strong writing skills unlock academic success, creative confidence, and lifelong leadership.
We provide free, high-impact programs including:


After-school tutoring


In-school WritersΓÇÖ Rooms


Creative writing workshops


Publishing projects


College essay support


Field trips and literacy experiences


Support for English Language Learners


Each program centers student voice, creativity, and individualized attentionΓÇöhelping young people express their ideas effectively, confidently, and authentically.

Fellowship Overview
The FAO Schwarz Fellowship is an intensive, paid, two-year experience for recent graduates seeking to deepen their understanding of social impact work and pursue careers in education, youth development, publishing, research, and nonprofit leadership.
For the 2026ΓÇô2028 cycle, 826 Boston will host two Fellows, each in a distinct role:


FAO Schwarz Fellow (Publishing)


FAO Schwarz Fellow (Data & Evaluation)


Applicants may apply to one or both positions.

Fellowship Position: FAO Schwarz Fellow (Publishing)
The Publishing Fellow supports student writers across 826 BostonΓÇÖs programs while expanding access to publishing opportunities and developing new print and digital publications that showcase student work.
Direct Service Responsibilities
The Publishing Fellow will:


Work directly with KΓÇô12 students to brainstorm, draft, revise, and publish writing across genres such as personal narrative, poetry, short fiction, and identity-based writing.


Ensure student voices remain centered throughout the creative process.


Facilitate a paid student editorial board, empowering youth leaders to guide the creative direction of publications.


Support (year one) and lead (year two) a program-based publishing project, including writing workshops, editorial processes, book production, and public showcases of student work.


Strategic Project Responsibilities
The Publishing Fellow will also:


Expand opportunities for students to share their stories citywide through live events, digital platforms, and multimedia collaborations.


Explore partnerships with community organizations to elevate student voices.


Collaborate with the Publishing Manager on the Young AuthorsΓÇÖ Book Project, coordinating designers, photographers, editors, and community partners.


Maintain and grow a multimedia catalog of publishing tools and resources to support deeper student engagement across 826 Boston programs.



Fellowship Position: FAO Schwarz Fellow (Data & Evaluation)
The Data & Evaluation Fellow combines direct student support with organizational learning, assessment, and impact measurementΓÇöstrengthening how 826 Boston tracks growth, outcomes, and long-term impact.
Direct Service Responsibilities
The Data & Evaluation Fellow will:


Provide one-on-one and small-group tutoring across 826 Boston programs.


Support KΓÇô12 students with academic writing assignments across all subject areas, including humanities and STEM.


Coach students through creative writing and publishing projects while centering authentic student voice.


Develop (year one) and lead (year two) workshops aligned with competencies measured in the 826 National Writing Assessment.


Strategic Project Responsibilities
The Fellow will:


Manage all program engagement data using Salesforce, ensuring accuracy and accessibility.


Implement the annual 826 National Writing Assessment across in-school and out-of-school programs, reaching over 500 students.


Collaborate with the Senior Director of Impact on a multi-year alumni-focused outcome study measuring long-term educational and leadership outcomes.


Develop and lead staff training modules in year two to strengthen data collection practices, assessment fidelity, and data-informed decision-making across program sites.



Organizational Leadership & Vision
826 Boston is led by Executive Director Corey Yarbrough, a seasoned education and social justice leader, and supported by a senior management team and a 16-member board of directors.
Over the next three years, 826 Boston aims to:


Double the number of WritersΓÇÖ Rooms in Boston Public Schools


Grow programming by more than 30%, serving over 5,000 students by FY29



Impact & Results
826 BostonΓÇÖs work is grounded in rigorous research and continuous learning.
2024ΓÇô2025 Highlights:


Served over 3,800 students


Delivered 24,000+ hours of tutoring and writing support


94% of students felt their ideas were valued


95% of teachers observed increased student writing confidence


93% of assessed students demonstrated growth in one or more writing competencies


Longitudinal research conducted with Northeastern University shows significant gains in student confidence and writing identityΓÇöby 12th grade, more than half of participating students identify as writers.

Compensation, Benefits & Schedule
Total Compensation (Two Years): Approximately $110,000


Year 1: $52,000 (includes $2,000 start bonus)


Year 2: $58,000 (includes $3,000 completion bonus)


Benefits Include:


Health, dental, and vision insurance


Paid time off and sick leave


Retirement plan


Professional development and leadership training


Work Schedule:


MondayΓÇôFriday, one of three 8-hour schedules


Hybrid work model with at least two in-person days per week (increasing as program needs require)



Eligibility & Application Process
Applicants must:


Be college seniors at accredited four-year institutions at the time of application


Be eligible to work in the U.S. for the full two-year Fellowship


Application Timeline


Applications open: November 1, 2025


Deadline: February 1, 2026 (9:00 PM ET)


Interviews & decisions: By late April 2026


Fellowship begins: Summer 2026


826 Boston is an equal opportunity organization and provides reasonable accommodations throughout the application process.

Join Us
ΓÇ£At the heart of 826 BostonΓÇÖs mission is amplifying the voices of young leaders and sharing their incredible stories. With the addition of two FAO Schwarz Fellows, weΓÇÖre eager to deepen our impact.ΓÇ¥ΓÇö Corey Yarbrough, Executive Director
If youΓÇÖre passionate about youth voice, writing, education, and social change, we invite you to apply and help shape the next chapter of student storytelling in Boston.

Call for Applications: UN Global Pulse Accelerator Programme (Cohort 4 ΓÇô 2026)

As the United Nations marks its 80th anniversary, the need for an agile, forward-looking, and innovation-driven UN has never been more urgent. To rise to todayΓÇÖs global challenges, the UN Global Pulse Accelerator Programme is launching a new call for applicationsΓÇöinviting UN teams to scale innovative solutions that deliver real impact for people and planet.
The UN Global Pulse Accelerator is the UNΓÇÖs flagship programme for helping promising, UN-led pilots break out of ΓÇ£pilot modeΓÇ¥ and achieve sustainable, scalable impact globally. UN teams with innovative solutions that have already been piloted and can demonstrate positive outcomes are encouraged to apply.

What is the UN Global Pulse Accelerator?
The Accelerator supports UN-led teams to develop realistic, evidence-based, and actionable scaling strategies for their innovations. Selected teams join a strategic learning journey, culminating in an in-person workshop in Finland, 8ΓÇô12 June 2026, where they will refine their scaling strategies with expert guidance.
Based on lessons from a UN-wide study, the programme is designed to help teams:

Transition promising solutions from pilot to scale
Define a clear, context-appropriate scaling pathway
Strengthen leadership, partnerships, and organisational readiness
Build sustainable models aligned with UN80 priorities and the SDGs

The most compelling strategies will receive a Scale Catalyst Grant of USD 60,000 and tailored mentoring to implement their scaling roadmap.

Who Can Apply?
The Accelerator is open to UN-led or UN co-led teams with innovative solutions that:

Have been piloted at least once in the local context
Show evidence of positive outcomes
Apply data, digital technology and/or AI as enabling components
Address one or more Sustainable Development Goals
Embed human rights, gender equality, diversity and inclusion
Use human-centred design and co-creation
Are ready to transition to scale

Projects run solely by non-UN entities, or those only endorsed or supported by the UN, are not eligible.
Applications that address challenges in least developed countries and show strong leadership backing and stakeholder partnerships are especially encouraged.

What YouΓÇÖll Gain
1. Strategic Pathway to Scale
A structured, expert-guided journey to help your team define a credible, sustainable scaling strategy tailored to your context.
2. In-Person Workshop in Finland (8ΓÇô12 June 2026)
Three members from each selected team will attend an immersive workshop week featuring:

Expert-led sessions
Scaling strategy development
Partnership & networking events with FinlandΓÇÖs innovation ecosystem

UN Global Pulse covers flights for all selected participants (economy-class, in line with UNOPS policies). DSA and other expenses are not covered.
3. Tailored Scale Strategy
Support to develop a robust strategy including:

Scaling vision and milestones
Strengthening value propositions
Ecosystem mapping
Operational and financial sustainability models
A compelling pitch deck for partners and funders

4. Scale Catalyst Grant
Two teams will receive:

USD 60,000 grant
6ΓÇô8 months of tailored technical support and mentoring


Team Requirements
Each applying team must:

Include 3 team members directly working on the project
Commit to the full workshop week in Finland (no remote option)
Ensure organisational readiness and leadership support
Be ready to enter a UN-to-UN agreement if selected for a grant

Multiple applications per UN entity are allowed (one form per project).

Application Details

Application period: 21 January ΓÇô 11 February 2026 (midnight EST)
Workshop: 8ΓÇô12 June 2026, Finland
Format: UN-led teams only

No additional documents are required, but teams may upload up to three optional supporting materials (pilot reports, evaluations, results, etc.).
Shortlisted teams will be contacted in mid-March for a 30-minute interview. Final selections confirmed by the end of March.

Information Sessions (Q&A;)
Applicants are encouraged to attend a live Q&A; with Accelerator Programme staff:

28 January 2026 ΓÇô 8 AM CET / 2 PM ICT
28 January 2026 ΓÇô 9 AM EST / 3 PM CET / 9 PM ICT
4 February 2026 ΓÇô 8 AM CET / 2 PM ICT
4 February 2026 ΓÇô 9 AM EST / 3 PM CET / 9 PM ICT

Registration links available on the programme webpage.
For questions: events@unglobalpulse.org

About the ProgrammeΓÇÖs Supporter
The Accelerator is generously funded by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland, a longstanding champion of innovation, human-centred design, and responsible use of AI and digital technologies in UN operations.

For more information: Click Here
