Rural Public Health Training Plan: Strengthening Skills for Health Professionals in Rural Communities

The Rural Public Health Training Plan is designed to equip public health professionals with the knowledge, tools, and strategies needed to serve rural communities more effectively. Developed to address the distinct challenges and opportunities that define rural public health, this training plan emphasizes strong leadership, clear communication, and meaningful collaboration with local partners. All courses are self-paced, web-based, and offer free continuing education (CE) credits, allowing participants to advance their professional skills while supporting stronger public health systems.
Participants who complete the full training sequence receive a certificate of completion, further enhancing their professional development. The initiative aligns with the commitment of the CDCΓÇÖs Office of Rural Health to strengthen the rural public health workforce through accessible, high-quality training resources.

What the Rural Public Health Training Plan Covers
The training plan provides a broad foundation in rural public health and includes five major topic areas:

Introduction to Rural Public Health
Partnering with Rural Communities for Public Health Communications
Risk Management in Rural Communities
Leadership Skills
Conflict Resolution

Each course explores critical factors that shape health outcomes in rural areas, highlighting both longstanding challenges and community strengths that support effective health interventions.

Course 1: Introduction to Rural Public Health (WB4981)
Format: Web-based, self-study (2 hours)
Skill Level: Introductory
This foundational course offers a comprehensive overview of rural public health in the United States. Participants learn how ΓÇ£ruralΓÇ¥ is defined, examine the unique strengths and vulnerabilities of rural communities, and explore the systems, structures, and partnerships that influence health service delivery.
Learning objectives include:

Understanding definitions and classifications of rural communities
Recognizing how community strengths can inform rural health solutions
Identifying public health systems that support service delivery
Understanding the importance of interprofessional collaboration

The course features presentations by experienced researchers and public health professionals from NORC at the University of Chicago, East Tennessee State University, and other leading institutions. Participants must complete the course, pass a post-assessment, and submit an evaluation to earn CE credits.

Courses on Partnering With Rural Communities (WD4995, WD4996, WD4997, WD4998)
A four-lesson series helps learners strengthen communication and partnership skills essential to rural public health work.
Lesson 1: Building Relationships (WD4995)
This course focuses on why collaboration with rural communities is essential for effective public health communication. Participants learn strategies for active listening, building trust, and forming sustainable partnerships. A companion workbook supports engagement with course content.
Lesson 2: Building an Initial Communications Strategy (WD4996)
Building on Lesson 1, this course guides participants through designing an initial communications strategy tailored to rural needs. The training emphasizes collaborative planning, community input, and practical strategy development.
Lesson 3: Developing Messaging (WD4997)
This lesson strengthens competencies in determining communication priorities, engaging diverse audiences, and refining messages in partnership with community members. It supports professionals in adapting communication approaches to diverse rural contexts.
Lesson 4: Disseminating Messaging (WD4998)
The final lesson explores methods for disseminating messages collaboratively and transparently. Participants learn how to share ownership with communities, build trust, and support informed decision-making that enhances health outcomes.
All four lessons offer CE credits and require completion of assessments and evaluations.

Course 5: Rural Communities Responding to Public Health Emergencies (WB4979)
Format: Web-based, self-study (3 hours)
Skill Level: Introductory
This course addresses the gap in formal rural public health training across the U.S. It focuses on risk management, emergency preparedness, and crisis communication in rural settings. Participants learn how to assess local hazards, apply risk-management tools, strengthen their networks, and practice shared leadership to build resilient communities.
Key learning outcomes include:

Identifying risks faced by rural communities
Applying risk assessments to prioritize hazards
Expanding local emergency networks
Strengthening crisis communication skills
Recognizing shared leadership as a tool for community resilience

CE credits are provided jointly by the CDC, Cornell University, and Health Impacts Core.

Building a Stronger Rural Public Health Workforce
Through a combination of foundational knowledge, practical strategies, and leadership-focused learning, the Rural Public Health Training Plan offers a comprehensive pathway for public health professionals committed to serving rural communities. With accessible, no-cost training and continuing education opportunities, the program helps build a more prepared, skilled, and collaborative public health workforce across the United States.

Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies: Applications Open for the 2026ΓÇô2028 David E. Bell Postdoctoral Fellowship

Applications for the 2026ΓÇô2028 cohort of the David E. Bell Postdoctoral Fellowship has been opened by The Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies (HCPDS), a prestigious, interdisciplinary program designed to train the next generation of population health leaders. For more than three decades, HCPDS has welcomed scholars from fields such as sociology, medicine, public policy, economics, and demography, offering a rigorous environment where innovative research in population science thrives.
Since 1990, the Center has hosted annual cohorts of fellows who examine critical issues in population and development. While the Mortimer Spiegelman Postdoctoral Fellowship will not be recruiting for the 2026ΓÇô2027 cycle, the Bell Fellowship remains an exceptional opportunity for early-career researchers. The deadline to apply is Tuesday, March 3, 2026, at 12:00 PM ET.

David E. Bell Postdoctoral Fellowship Goals
The Bell Fellowship is designed to deepen scholarsΓÇÖ expertise in population and development through training, mentorship, and research support. The program aims to:

Train effective leaders equipped to advance population and development research
Strengthen fellowsΓÇÖ analytical and research skills
Develop ethical awareness essential to population science
Challenge fellowsΓÇÖ thinking on contemporary issues in global population and development
Expand their professional networks through Center activities, courses, and working groups
Enhance their leadership prospects through professional development opportunities

Fellows also receive individualized coaching on long-term career planning, research management, and publication strategies. A custom two-day media training equips fellows to engage effectively with journalists, promote their work, and craft impactful op-eds.

Mentorship and Research Resources
Each Bell Fellow is matched with at least one mentor from their primary discipline and another from an outside field. Fellows who already have potential collaborators in mind may request them; alternatively, the Center Director helps identify an appropriate mentoring team during the interview phase.
HCPDS provides access to a wealth of research resources, including population science datasets, a Restricted Data Enclave certified for level-4 sensitive data, and support from in-house data managers and analysts. Fellows may also use high-performance computing environments such as the FASSE and Cannon clusters, enabling sophisticated computational analyses through secure VPN access.
As Harvard employees, fellows also enjoy full access to HarvardΓÇÖs extensive library network, which includes more than 70 libraries. Of particular relevance is the Francis A. Countway Library, the largest academic medical library in the U.S.
Fellows may attend seminars and workshops across the university, including events at the Institute for Quantitative Social Science, the Center for Geographic Analysis, the Malcolm Wiener Center for Inequality & Social Policy, and the Harvard Global Health Institute.

Expectations and Program Structure
Bell Fellows are expected to engage deeply with the intellectual life of the Center. Requirements include:

Developing a detailed research work plan in collaboration with mentors
Attending weekly Social Demography Seminars and presenting at least once during their tenure
Participating in monthly FellowsΓÇÖ meetings with the Center Director and faculty
Being present on-site for the majority of the fellowship period
Actively joining or establishing working groups

The fellowship is a full-time, residential program. Teaching and consulting are not permitted unless pre-approved, and fellows who hold positions at other institutions must take unpaid leave or resign for the duration of their fellowship.

Terms and Funding
For the 2026ΓÇô2028 cycle, Bell Fellows receive:

A $75,000 annual salary, plus fringe benefits and subsidized health insurance
Up to $4,000 in relocation funds for travel and shipment of personal items
An $11,000 research, travel, and computer fund to be used over two years

These funds may support research assistance, data purchases, software, publication fees, conference travel, and other eligible expenses.

How to Apply
Applications consist of two components:

An online application form (including uploads of all required materials)
Three letters of recommendation

Applicants must complete all doctoral requirements by August 15, 2026, and provide either a diploma or a registrarΓÇÖs letter as proof.
The application is open to both U.S. and international scholars.

New Profit Launches 2026 Grantmaking Cycle for Unlocked Futures Catalyze Cohort

New Profit has opened its 2026 grantmaking cycle for the Unlocked Futures Catalyze Cohort, inviting innovative social impact organizations to submit Discovery Forms for consideration. The Catalyze model is designed to strengthen organizations expanding access and opportunity across the United States, offering a combination of unrestricted funding, leadership development, and strategic advisory support. This yearΓÇÖs Unlocked Futures cohort focuses specifically on organizations led by formerly incarcerated or directly impacted Social Entrepreneurs, aiming to increase visibility, remove barriers to capital, and strengthen economic mobility for communities historically marginalized by the criminal legal system.
About the Catalyze Cohort
Catalyze cohorts are built to support mission-driven organizations through a powerful blend of capital, capacity building, and community. Selected organizations receive:

A $100,000 unrestricted grant
A $10,000 unrestricted leadership development grant for the Social Entrepreneur
Tailored strategic advisory support
A full year of cohort-based learning, peer support, and professional development

Throughout the year, Social Entrepreneurs participate in workshops on fundraising, board development, storytelling, scenario planning, and other areas essential to organizational strength. Cohort members build connections with peers addressing similar systemic challenges, forming a lasting network of collaboration and support.
New Profit has invested in 240 organizations through Catalyze, with 86% of leaders reporting that participation significantly amplified their impact.
About the Unlocked Futures Cohort
Unlocked Futures is dedicated to supporting entrepreneurs who are directly impacted by the criminal legal system, including those who have been arrested, charged, convicted, detained, or incarcerated in any setting. These leaders often face numerous structural barriersΓÇöfrom employment restrictions to limited access to capitalΓÇödespite being uniquely positioned to improve reentry systems, economic mobility, and community safety.
By centering formerly incarcerated leadership, Unlocked Futures works to shift narratives, drive systems change, and support organizations advancing equitable pathways into income generation, entrepreneurship, and long-term stability.
To be considered for the 2026 cycle, organizations must submit the New Profit Discovery Form by February 11, 2026, at 11:59pm ET.
Submitting the Discovery Form
The Discovery Form signals an organizationΓÇÖs interest in New Profit funding and provides foundational information to assess alignment with the cohortΓÇÖs strategic priorities. Submitting the form is not a full application; only selected organizations will be invited to submit a complete application in March.
Applicants who have submitted a Discovery Form within the past yearΓÇöor previously applied to Unlocked FuturesΓÇömay request an editable link to update their prior submission. All new applicants must complete a fresh form.
Catalyze Cohort Participation Requirements
Social Entrepreneurs leading selected organizations must commit to the full 12-month program, which includes:

Three in-person convenings (3ΓÇô4 days each, travel covered)
Three virtual learning sessions (2ΓÇô3 hours each)
Regular strategic advising sessions with New Profit staff
Approximately 6ΓÇô8 hours per month of cohort engagement
A $10,000 leadership development stipend for personal growth

This structure ensures a deep, collaborative experience rooted in shared learning and sustained professional growth.
Eligibility Criteria
To qualify for the Unlocked Futures Catalyze Cohort, organizations must:

Operate in and primarily serve communities in the United States
Hold 501(c)(3) status (or fiscal sponsorship)
Have annual expenses between $250,000 and $2 million
Be led by at least one full-time Social Entrepreneur (~30 hours/week)
Have operated their core program for at least two years
Not be previous New Profit grantees
Align with New ProfitΓÇÖs strategic priorities in education, economic mobility, and democracy
Be led by a Social Entrepreneur who is formerly incarcerated or directly impacted

New Profit especially seeks organizations addressing economic opportunity through pathways to income, reentry supports, financial stability, and entrepreneurship for directly impacted individuals.
About New Profit
New Profit is a national venture philanthropy organization advancing access and opportunity across America. Since 1998, it has invested over $350 million into 275+ high-impact organizations serving more than 35 million people. Through capital, strategic support, and a powerful network, New Profit works alongside leaders transforming education, economic mobility, and democracy.

Research Ireland Public Service Fellowship 2026: Call for Proposals Now Open

The Research Ireland Public Service Fellowship 2026 is now open for applications, offering researchers the opportunity to work directly with Government Departments and Agencies across Ireland. With a deadline of 16 April 2026, this competitive programme provides a unique pathway for researchers to apply their expertise to real-world policy challenges while gaining valuable experience within the Irish public sector.
The fellowship is designed as a temporary secondment, enabling researchers to contribute to specific, high-impact projects identified by host organisations. For 2026, Research Ireland is partnering with 26 Government Departments and Agencies, offering 71 project opportunities for applicants. Fellowships may run for 6 to 12 months full-time, or 12 to 24 months part-time, with a maximum award amount of Γé¼130,000 in direct costs. Many of the roles offer hybrid working models across multiple locations including Dublin, Cork, Kildare, Wexford, Kerry, Cavan, Westmeath, Offaly, Mayo, Galway, Sligo, and Meath.

Research Ireland Public Service Fellowship Objectives
The fellowship aims to strengthen the relationship between IrelandΓÇÖs research community and the public service by advancing evidence-based, data-driven, and innovative approaches to national challenges. Its core objectives include:

Enhancing collaboration between researchers and Government bodies
Fostering innovation within the public sector through research, knowledge exchange, and evidence-based practice
Providing technical expertise in specific areas to inform policymaking and improve service delivery
Supporting the strategic goals outlined by host organisations in their project briefs
Expanding researchersΓÇÖ understanding of public sector systems, operations, and needs


Host Organisations
The 2026 Fellowship brings together a wide range of Irish public bodies offering structured project briefs. Participating host organisations include:
Central Statistics Office; Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine; Department of Culture, Communication and Sport; Department of Children, Disability and Equality; Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment; Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment; Department of Education and Youth; Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science; Department of Health; Department of Justice, Home Affairs and Migration; Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht; Environmental Protection Agency; Food Safety Authority of Ireland; Forensic Science Ireland; Health Service Executive; Irish Prison Service; National Cyber Security Centre; National Council for Special Education; National Disability Authority; National Poisons Information Centre; National Standards Authority of Ireland; Office of Public Works; Parliamentary Research Services (House of the Oireachtas); Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland; State Laboratory; and The Electoral Commission.
Each of these organisations has provided detailed project outlines including background context, required researcher expertise, expected outputs, and proposed timelines.
Co-funding partners for the 2026 call include: the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine; the Department of Children, Disability and Equality; the Department of Health; the Environmental Protection Agency; the Health Service Executive; the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland; and The Electoral Commission.

Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must meet the following eligibility requirements:

PhD qualification (or equivalent) at the time of application
Employment as a permanent academic staff member or a current contract postdoctoral researcher at an Eligible Research Body
Not currently under review for other Research Ireland programmes
Additional conditions apply for individuals currently holding, or who have previously held, Public Service Fellowship awards

Full eligibility conditions are outlined in the call document.

Key Dates

Call Launch: 14 January 2026
Information Webinar: 4 February 2026 at 2:30pm (Irish local time)
Application Deadline: 16 April 2026 at 13:00 (Irish local time)
Funding Decision: July 2026


How to Apply
Applications must be submitted through SESAME, Research IrelandΓÇÖs online grants and awards management system, before the deadline. Researchers accessing SESAME for the first time should request access through their institutionΓÇÖs Research Office. Queries should be directed initially to the local Research Office, and unresolved issues may be emailed to the SESAME support team.
Applicants should consult the June 2025 Research Ireland Grant Applications Budget Policy when preparing their budgets. A thorough review of the call document is essential before beginning the application.

Explore the LawAI Summer Research Fellowship: Opportunities for Aspiring Legal Scholars in AI

Are you a law student, legal professional, or academic with a keen interest in artificial intelligence and its impact on law and policy? The Institute for Law & AI (LawAI) is offering a unique opportunity to dive deep into the cutting-edge intersection of AI, law, and policy through their Summer Research Fellowship (SRF) programs. With tracks tailored for the United States, the European Union, and global legal frontiers, these fellowships provide a platform for ambitious individuals to contribute to pioneering legal research while building professional connections in the rapidly evolving field of AI law.

What Is the LawAI Summer Research Fellowship?
The LawAI Summer Research Fellowship is a 10-week paid program designed to empower participants to engage in meaningful research at the nexus of artificial intelligence(AI) and law. Fellows are paired with experienced mentors, provided access to rich resources, and given the chance to develop their analytical and research skills while exploring contemporary legal challenges posed by AI technologies. The program is structured to offer not only research experience but also professional development opportunities, networking with leading experts, and a practical understanding of legal policy-making in AI governance.
The fellowship is divided into three distinct tracks, each tailored to a specific region or thematic focus:
1. SRF-US: Focus on AI Law and Policy in the United States
The US-focused track is ideal for individuals interested in exploring AI law, policy, and regulation in the United States. Participants work on research projects designed to examine contemporary legal questions related to AI technologies, from algorithmic accountability to privacy and cybersecurity.
Fellows in this track benefit from a remote-first structure with one in-person week in Washington, D.C. or Berkeley, California, allowing them to gain exposure to key legal institutions and policy hubs. Beyond research, participants engage in weekly mentorship sessions, collaborative workshops, and networking events with AI law professionals and scholars.
This track is perfect for those looking to strengthen their understanding of US AI regulatory frameworks, develop publishable research, and gain insights into how AI is shaping the legal landscape in the United States.
Apply HERE
Application deadline: January 30, 2026 (by 11:59 PM ET).
Learn more about SRF-US

2. SRF-EU: Exploring AI Regulation in the European Union
The EU-focused track caters to applicants with an interest in European Union AI regulation and policy. With AI regulations in the EU leading the world in terms of comprehensiveness and enforcement, this fellowship provides participants with the opportunity to explore the nuances of the EU AI Act, data protection laws, and ethical AI standards.
The program offers a hybrid experience, typically including in-person engagement in Cambridge, UK, combined with remote work, enabling fellows to immerse themselves in the European legal environment. Participants work closely with mentors to analyze EU-specific legal frameworks, comparative law issues, and cross-border AI regulatory challenges.
Fellows in this track gain not only legal expertise but also a broader understanding of how international and regional regulations interact to shape AI governance globally.
Apply HERE
Application deadline: February 7, 2026
Learn more about SRF-EU

3. SRF-LF: Legal Frontiers in AI
The Legal Frontiers track is designed for those interested in interdisciplinary or global perspectives on AI law. Unlike the US or EU tracks, SRF-LF emphasizes research on emerging and cross-jurisdictional legal challenges, including international AI governance, novel legal frameworks, and global ethical considerations.
Fellows in this track tackle innovative research questions that may not fit within a single jurisdiction, making it ideal for participants who are passionate about policy development, AI ethics, and global legal strategy. Like the other tracks, this program provides mentorship, networking opportunities, and professional development aimed at helping fellows contribute original insights to the field.
Apply HERE
Application deadline: February 7, 2026
Learn more about SRF-LF

Why Apply to the LawAI Summer Research Fellowship?
The LawAI SRF programs are more than just research opportunitiesΓÇöthey are a gateway to a career in AI law and policy. Participants leave the program with:

Enhanced research and analytical skills relevant to AI law.
Mentorship from leading legal scholars and AI policy experts.
Professional networking opportunities that can open doors to future internships, jobs, and collaborations.
Hands-on experience with real-world legal challenges posed by emerging AI technologies.
Compensation for their contributions, making it a viable and rewarding professional experience.

Whether your interest lies in understanding how AI impacts legal systems in the US, decoding the regulatory frameworks of the EU, or pioneering research on global legal frontiers, the LawAI Summer Research Fellowship offers a platform to make meaningful contributions and gain invaluable professional exposure.

How to Apply
Applications for the LawAI Summer Research Fellowship are now open, with separate pages for each track detailing eligibility requirements, deadlines, and application procedures. Candidates from diverse academic and professional backgrounds are encouraged to apply, including law students, legal practitioners, researchers, and academics with an interest in AI governance and policy.
DonΓÇÖt miss the chance to advance your career, contribute to the future of AI law, and join a vibrant community of legal researchers and AI policy innovators.

Apply to the Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy Fellowship (2026 Cohort)

The Asia-Pacific region is home to some of the worldΓÇÖs fastest-growing cities, facing urgent challenges related to climate change, urbanization, inequality, and sustainable development. To support visionary local leaders in addressing these challenges, the Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy Fellowship is now open for applications.
This prestigious Fellowship is a leadership development programme designed specifically for newly elected or newly appointed Mayors and Governors across the Asia-Pacific region. It aims to strengthen local leadership, promote sustainable urban development, and accelerate the localization of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and local climate action.
About the Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy
The Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy is a collaborative initiative supported by leading regional and global institutions, including:


United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP)


UN-Habitat


United Cities and Local Governments Asia-Pacific (UCLG-ASPAC)


United Nations University ΓÇô Institute for the Advanced Study of Sustainability (UNU-IAS)


Association of Pacific Rim Universities (APRU)


Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES)


Through a carefully designed curriculum, the Academy provides participating mayors with knowledge, peer learning opportunities, mentorship, and practical tools to strengthen urban governance and sustainable city leadership.
Who Is Eligible to Apply?
The Fellowship is exclusively designed for city leaders and targets those who are early in their leadership journey. To be eligible, applicants must meet the following criteria:


Be a newly elected or appointed Mayor or Governor, typically within the first third of their term (special circumstances may be considered).


Demonstrate a strong commitment to sustainable urban development, including the localization of the SDGs and the implementation of local climate action initiatives.


Be based in an ESCAP Member or Associate Member State.


Have access to a stable and reliable internet connection to participate in online sessions.


Be fluent in English or possess a high level of English proficiency, as the programme will be conducted in English.


The selection process also places emphasis on regional balance and gender inclusion, and applications from women mayors are strongly encouraged.
Fellowship Structure and Curriculum
The Academy Fellowship is delivered through a blended learning approach, combining virtual learning with an in-person graduation event.
Key programme features include:


Online sessions held every other week, running from April to October 2026 (dates subject to change).


Interactive learning modules focused on sustainable urban development, climate resilience, inclusive governance, and SDG localization.


Peer-to-peer exchange with fellow mayors from across the Asia-Pacific region.


Engagement with experts, mentors, and partner institutions to support leadership development.


The Fellowship will conclude with an in-person Graduation Ceremony in November 2026. Financial support for travel may be available, although in-kind contributions and co-funding from participating cities are welcomed.
Selection Process
Fellows will be selected through a competitive process overseen by a Selection Committee composed of representatives from ESCAP, UN-Habitat, UCLG-ASPAC, UNU-IAS, APRU, and IGES.
Mentors may also be identified to support both the selection process and the preparatory phase of successful candidates, ensuring that Fellows are well-positioned to benefit fully from the Academy.
How to Apply
Interested and eligible candidates are required to complete and submit the official online application form.


Click the ΓÇ£ApplyΓÇ¥ button on the official Academy webpage to access the application form.


A Word version of the application form is available for reference purposes only. Applicants must submit the online form to be considered.


Apply HERE
Application Deadline: 15 February 2026
Late or incomplete applications will not be considered, so early submission is strongly encouraged.
Additional Information and Enquiries
For further details about the Academy or the application process, applicants may contact:
≡ƒôº escap-edd-suds@un.org≡ƒôº habitatbkk@un.org
Why Apply?
Participation in the Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy offers a unique opportunity to:


Strengthen leadership skills at the city level


Gain practical tools to implement sustainable urban policies


Build lasting networks with fellow mayors and global institutions


Advance climate action and SDG localization in your city


If you are a newly elected or appointed Mayor or Governor committed to shaping a sustainable future for your city, this Fellowship offers an exceptional platform to learn, connect, and lead.
Apply now and be part of the 2026 Asia-Pacific Mayors Academy Fellowship.

AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship ΓÇô Call for Applications

About the International AIDS Society (IAS)
The International AIDS Society (IAS) is the worldΓÇÖs largest association of HIV professionals. Since its creation, the IAS has worked tirelessly to convene, educate, and advocate for a world where HIV is no longer a threat to public health or individual well-being.

Founded by concerned scientists after the emergence of HIV and AIDS.
Brings together experts from across disciplines to promote a unified global HIV response.
Hosts the worldΓÇÖs most prestigious HIV conferences:

The International AIDS Conference
The IAS Conference on HIV Science
The HIV Research for Prevention Conference



Through these efforts, the IAS unites scientists, policymakers, and activists to galvanize the scientific response, build solidarity, and enhance human dignity for all those living with and affected by HIV.

Purpose of the Fellowship
The AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship is designed to support individuals working to advance knowledge and access to HIV prevention. The fellowship aims to:

Amplify the reach of HIV prevention advocates.
Strengthen networks and collaborations.
Engage fellows with the latest prevention science and policy developments at AIDS 2026, the 26th International AIDS Conference.

Conference details:

Dates: 26ΓÇô31 July 2026
Location: Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Format: In-person and virtual participation


Fellowship Benefits
Successful applicants will receive support to:

Implement a digital content project on HIV prevention ahead of AIDS 2026, contributing to the IAS Rethink. Rebuild. Rise. campaign (up to USD 500 in project costs).
Design and create digital content during AIDS 2026, translating the latest scientific, policy, and activism updates for target audiences (up to USD 500 in project costs).
Attend AIDS 2026 in person, with support for travel, accommodation, per diem, ground transport, and visa costs (if applicable).
Connect with researchers, policymakers, and activists working in HIV prevention.
Participate in networking and professional development opportunities during the conference.


Duration

Fellowship begins after a competitive review and selection process.
Notification of selection: March 2026
Fellowship ends: 14 August 2026
Application deadline: 15 February 2026, 23:00 CET


Eligibility Criteria
Applicants must demonstrate the following:

Proven track record in advancing knowledge and access to HIV prevention (e.g., PrEP/PEP, U=U, harm reduction, long-acting prevention, combination prevention, and policy).
Experience in content creation on HIV prevention across digital or social media platforms.

Minimum of 5,000 total followers/subscribers across platforms such as TikTok, Instagram, LinkedIn, YouTube, Facebook, X, Bluesky, podcasts, blogs, newsletters, or community radio with digital presence.
Applicants without these metrics may qualify through documented community engagement or consistent content with measurable impact.


Commitment to ethical reporting standards, evidence-based communication, and rights-based language (aligned with IAS guidelines).
Proficiency in English (multilingual creators encouraged).
Commitment to participate in pre-event onboarding (virtual) and full AIDS 2026 dates.
Minimum age: 18 years or older at the time of application.


Priority Considerations
Preference will be given to applicants who:

Represent or work closely with key and priority populations, including:

People living with and affected by HIV
Men who have sex with men
Transgender people
Sex workers
People who inject drugs
Adolescent girls and young women
Migrants and other underserved communities


Are based in low- and middle-income countries and/or produce content for underserved audiences.
Demonstrate collaborations with community-led organizations, clinics, or advocacy coalitions.


Application Process
Interested candidates must complete the official application form available.
Applications should include:

Demographic information
Work history
Motivation statement
Descriptions of two digital prevention communication projects:

One project planned before AIDS 2026.
One project during AIDS 2026.
Each description should outline intended outcomes, themes, target audiences, platforms to be used, and two sample posts.


Curriculum Vitae (CV), including portfolio and/or links to recent prevention-related digital content (last 6ΓÇô12 months).
Evidence of reach (e.g., screenshots of engagement analytics, qualitative metrics).
Letter of support from employer (if applicable).
Letter of reference if self-employed.

Confidentiality: All application information will be treated confidentially. Only selected candidates will be contacted.
Questions: Applicants may submit inquiries via email.

Distinction from Media Scholarship
It is important to note that the AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship is distinct from the AIDS 2026 Media Scholarship. Qualified candidates may apply to both opportunities if eligible.

The AIDS 2026 Prevention Ambassador Fellowship is a unique opportunity for digital creators and advocates to amplify their impact in HIV prevention. By engaging with the latest science, policy, and activism, fellows will not only contribute to the Rethink. Rebuild. Rise. campaign but also strengthen their professional networks and visibility in the global HIV response. Learn more and apply here.

Fondation Centre Pompadour Grant 2026

The Fondation Centre Pompadour (FCP) is proud to announce its annual grant program, dedicated to advancing feminist agendas and promoting gender equality across all areas of life. This initiative reflects the foundationΓÇÖs mission to support projects that contribute to the public interest, stimulate debate, and foster critical engagement with feminist issues.
Each year, one grant of up to 30,000 euros is awarded to an individual or team whose project embodies the values and objectives of the foundation. Below, you will find all the essential details, eligibility criteria, deadlines, and expectations for applicants.

Grant Overview

Amount: Up to 30,000 euros
Distribution: Provided in two allotments over the course of one year
Purpose: To support projects that advance feminist agendas in line with the foundationΓÇÖs mission
Eligibility:

Open to applicants of any gender and background
Applications may be submitted by individuals or teams


Tax Responsibility: Grantees are responsible for handling tax obligations in their country or institution


Application Timeline
Applicants should carefully note the deadlines for the 2026 call:

First Round Deadline: February 28, 2026
Finalist Invitations: March 15, 2026
Second Round Deadline: March 31, 2026
Announcement of Winner: April 15, 2026 (via email and on the foundationΓÇÖs website)


Mission and Objectives of the Fondation Centre Pompadour
The foundation operates under the Austrian Federal Foundations and Funds Act and is committed to:

Research, development, and dissemination of feminist ideas
Promotion of comprehensive gender equality in all areas of life
Feminist communication and representation across diverse platforms
Support for projects that contribute to the public interest and common good

Projects funded by the grant are expected to go beyond personal or internal benefits. Instead, they should engage with broader societal contexts, public discourse, or collective reflection.

Types of Projects Welcomed
The foundation particularly encourages initiatives that:

Raise public awareness of feminist issues
Stimulate debate and foster critical engagement
Counteract sexist and discriminatory attacks on human dignity (both physical and digital)
Promote self-determination and empowerment for all persons
Contribute to collective reflection and societal transformation

Examples of suitable projects include:

Educational campaigns addressing gender inequality
Artistic or cultural initiatives that highlight feminist perspectives
Research projects exploring feminist theory and practice
Community-based programs promoting inclusivity and equality
Digital initiatives combating online harassment and discrimination


Important Notes for Applicants

AI-generated applications will not be considered. The foundation emphasizes originality and human-driven creativity.
Credit Requirement: The Fondation Centre Pompadour must be acknowledged in all publicity and communications related to the funded project.
Public Interest Orientation: Projects should aim to benefit society at large, not just the applicant or their institution.


Why Apply?
The Fondation Centre Pompadour Grant offers more than financial supportΓÇöit provides recognition, visibility, and the opportunity to contribute meaningfully to feminist discourse. Successful applicants will:

Gain resources to implement impactful projects
Receive institutional backing from a respected foundation
Contribute to shaping feminist agendas in Europe and beyond
Join a network of changemakers committed to equality and justice


Application Process
Interested applicants should prepare a detailed proposal that includes:

Project description outlining objectives, methods, and expected outcomes
Timeline for implementation over the one-year funding period
Budget breakdown showing how the grant will be utilized
Impact statement explaining how the project contributes to feminist agendas and public interest
Team or individual background highlighting relevant experience and commitment to feminist work


The Fondation Centre Pompadour Grant 2026 represents a unique opportunity for individuals and teams to bring forward innovative, socially impactful projects that advance feminist agendas. With up to 30,000 euros in funding, the grant empowers changemakers to challenge inequality, foster debate, and promote self-determination across diverse contexts. Apply here.

Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest by the United Nations ΓÇô International Youth Essay Competition with Prizes and Youth Advisory Panel Opportunity

The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest is a youth-focused international essay competition designed to amplify young peopleΓÇÖs voices in governance, policy engagement, and future-shaping conversations. Organized under the United Nations system, the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest invites eligible youth to submit original essays in English for the opportunity to win back-to-school stationery hampers, receive certificates, and potentially participate in a Youth Advisory Panel.
The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest runs from 15 January 2026 at 12:00 PM to 15 February 2026 at 11:59 PM (FJT) and is targeted at young people living in selected Pacific Island countries. Through this contest, the United Nations seeks to encourage meaningful youth engagement with government and decision-making processes that influence present and future generations.

Background and Overview of the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest
The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest centers on a single essay theme that challenges young people to reflect on governance, civic responsibility, and youth participation. The official essay topic is:

ΓÇ£The Pact for the Future calls on youth to engage with government and shape our futures. These are my recommendations for how that should look.ΓÇ¥

This theme encourages participants to think critically about how young people can contribute to government processes and policy discussions. The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest aims to promote thoughtful dialogue, creative expression, and structured arguments while highlighting the importance of youth perspectives in shaping inclusive and sustainable futures.
The contest forms part of a broader commitment by the United Nations to uphold youth participation, ethical engagement, and safeguarding standards across all its initiatives.

Eligibility Criteria for the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest
Participation in the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest is subject to clearly defined eligibility requirements. Applicants must meet all the conditions outlined below.
Age Requirements
Applicants must fall within one of the following age categories at the time of submission:


15 to 19 years


20 to 24 years


Each age category has a separate word limit, and submissions must strictly comply with the assigned range.
Nationality and Residency Eligibility
The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest is open only to individuals who are:


Citizens


Lawful refugees


Protection persons


of the following countries:


Fiji


Solomon Islands


Tonga


Tuvalu


Vanuatu


Applicants outside these countries are not eligible to participate.
Language and Originality Requirements


Essays must be written entirely in English


Submissions must be original work


A consistent referencing style must be used


AI-generated content is not permitted and will result in disqualification



Essay Structure and Word Limits
Participants in the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest must adhere to the following word limits:


Ages 15ΓÇô19: 750 to 1,000 words


Ages 20ΓÇô24: 1,000 to 1,250 words


Essays that fall outside these limits may be deemed ineligible.

Judging Criteria for the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest
All submissions will be evaluated by the UN Country Team using five equally weighted criteria. Each criterion accounts for 20% of the total score:


Impact and persuasiveness


Relevance and alignment with the theme


Creativity


Originality


Structure and clarity


While the top three essays per age category per country will be considered for prizes, all submissions must achieve a minimum score of 50% to qualify for awards.
All judging decisions made by the UN Country Team (Fiji Multi-Country Office) are final.

Prizes and Recognition
The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest offers multiple forms of recognition:


30 stationery packs (back-to-school hampers) will be awarded


Top three essays per age category per country will receive stationery packs


Selected winners may have the chance to participate in the Youth Advisory Panel


All participants will receive an official certificate of participation


These rewards are designed to recognize academic effort, creativity, and civic engagement.

Application Process and Submission Methods
Online Submission
All participants are encouraged to submit their essays through the official Essay Submission Portal provided by the United Nations.
Alternative Submission Formats
To promote inclusivity, alternative formats may be considered for persons with disabilities, including:


Braille submissions


Audio submissions


Visual submissions


Hard Copy Submissions
Youth with limited access to computers may request permission to submit hard copies of their essays. Requests must be sent for consideration to:


rco.fiji@un.org


Approval must be granted before submitting essays through alternative means.

Important Dates and Deadline


Contest Opens: 15 January 2026 at 12:00 PM


Submission Deadline: 15 February 2026 at 11:59 PM (FJT)


Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances.

United Nations Entities Involved
The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest is supported by the following UN entities:


International Labour Organization (ILO)


Resident CoordinatorΓÇÖs Office (RCO)


United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)


United Nations ChildrenΓÇÖs Fund (UNICEF)


The UN Fiji Multi-Country Office applies strict safeguarding measures, including moderation of entries to prevent cyberbullying and the sharing of sensitive personal information. Safeguarding inquiries can be directed to rco.fiji@un.org.

The Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest provides an important platform for youth from the Pacific region to express their ideas on governance, civic participation, and future development. By participating in the Pact for the Future Youth Essay Contest, eligible young people can gain recognition, receive prizes, and contribute their voices to discussions that shape the future.

Application Portal ΓÇô Click Here to Apply

Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026 by MESHA (Canada) ΓÇô Paid Action Research Fellowship for African Journalists

The Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026 is a one-year, action researchΓÇôbased fellowship offered by Media for Environment, Science, Health and Agriculture (MESHA) in partnership with the International Development Research Centre (IDRC). This Climate Change Media Fellowship targets professional journalists from Eastern and Southern Africa, supporting them to deepen, strengthen, and reframe climate change reporting from African perspectives, with a strong focus on gender equality and social inclusion.
This paid Climate Change Media Fellowship will select eight (8) journalists (at least 50% women) to participate in the Action Research to Enhance Effective Coverage of Climate Change Issues in Africa (ARECCCA) project for the 2026ΓÇô2027 cycle. Fellows will receive story grants, mentorship, structured engagement forums, and capacity-building opportunities while contributing to high-quality climate journalism across the region.

Introduction and Background: About the Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026
The Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026 is designed to respond to persistent gaps in climate change reporting in Africa, particularly the underrepresentation of African realities, vulnerable communities, and gendered impacts of climate change. Through the ARECCCA action research project, MESHA seeks to document lessons, enhance reporting depth, and strengthen collaboration between journalists, climate researchers, policymakers, and communities.
MESHA is a Canada-based organization dedicated to strengthening journalism at the intersection of environment, science, health, and agriculture. For this fellowship, MESHA is working with IDRCΓÇÖs Eastern and Southern Africa Regional Office in Nairobi, reinforcing the programmeΓÇÖs regional relevance and research grounding.
Unlike traditional fellowships, the Climate Change Media Fellowship emphasizes action research, where journalists actively reflect on their reporting practices, apply new approaches, and contribute to collective learning on effective climate communication from African perspectives.

Objectives of the Climate Change Media Fellowship
The Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026 pursues four core objectives:


Document and share lessons on covering climate change issues from African perspectives through action research


Deepen climate change coverage across Eastern and Southern Africa by addressing identified reporting gaps


Strengthen relationships among journalists, climate researchers, policymakers, and communities


Enhance MESHAΓÇÖs positioning in the climate reporting space and explore sustainable support mechanisms for climate journalism


These objectives guide all fellowship activities, story development processes, and engagement forums throughout the year.

Who Can Apply: Eligibility Criteria for the Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026
Eligible Countries and Region
Applicants must be professional journalists reporting from Eastern or Southern Africa. The fellowship is regionally focused, and only applicants based in or representing media houses in these regions are eligible.

Professional Background Requirements
To be eligible for the Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026, applicants must:


Be a professional journalist from or representing an established media house


Work with a media outlet that has urban or rural reach, including national, regional, or international coverage


Have previous experience reporting on climate change issues


Demonstrate experience reporting on climate change from a gender equality and social inclusion perspective


Possess media accreditation in their country (obtaining accreditation is the applicantΓÇÖs responsibility)


Both staff journalists and freelancers are eligible, provided they meet the documentation requirements.

Language and Availability
Applicants must:


Have a good command of English


Be available and willing to participate actively in the fellowship for one full year


Commit to participating in all fellowship activities, including mentorship sessions and engagement forums


Knowledge of African languages is considered an advantage but is not mandatory.

Programme Structure and Fellowship Activities
The Climate Change Media Fellowship runs for one year, beginning in April 2026, and includes a structured set of research, reporting, and engagement activities.
Core Fellowship Activities Include


1 Kick-Off Workshop


5 Science Caf├⌐s/Roundtables for journalists and researchers


3 Science Caf├⌐s with climate stakeholders and policymakers


1 mid-term engagement forum


Mentorship sessions and science caf├⌐s with climate experts


Debriefing session at the end of the fellowship


Contribution of stories to Sayansi Magazine


Participation in 1ΓÇô2 engagement forums beyond the year of participation


Fellows will also be required to identify and pitch two major reporting projects, each completed in phases over approximately five months per story.

Funding, Benefits, and Support Provided
The Climate Change Media Fellowship 2026 provides financial and professional support, including:


Two story grants per Fellow during the year


Mentorship from experienced climate and science journalism professionals


Access to climate researchers and policy experts


Structured learning through science caf├⌐s and engagement forums


Participation in the fellowship is voluntary and does not constitute employment.

Documents Required for Application
Applicants must submit the following documents:


A short application letter (approximately 400 words) describing experience in climate reporting and motivation to participate


Three (3) work samples published between January and December 2025, including at least one story demonstrating attention to gender equality and vulnerable groups


A media accreditation card


A letter from the editor confirming support and commitment to publish fellowship stories


Freelancers must submit a letter of support from a media outlet they intend to report for


Stories submitted in non-English languages must include a short English synopsis


Applicants must also be willing to complete an online training on gender, equality, and inclusion.

Selection and Evaluation Criteria
Applications will be evaluated based on:


Demonstrated experience in climate and environmental reporting


Understanding of gender equality and social inclusion


Insight into climate impacts on vulnerable groups

Australia Awards Africa Scholarship 2027: Fully Funded MasterΓÇÖs Degree Opportunities for Africans

The Australia Awards Africa Scholarship 2027 is now open for applications, offering a prestigious and fully funded opportunity for outstanding African professionals to pursue a MasterΓÇÖs degree at leading Australian universities. Funded by the Australian Government through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), the program aims to build AfricaΓÇÖs future leaders and strengthen partnerships between Australia and Africa.
This highly competitive scholarship is designed for mid-level to senior-level professionals who demonstrate strong academic merit, leadership potential, and a clear commitment to contributing to policy reform, institutional strengthening, and sustainable development in their home countries.
About the Australia Awards Africa Scholarship
The Australia Awards Africa program supports long-term capacity building across Africa by providing access to quality postgraduate education in Australia. Scholars gain advanced academic training, professional exposure, and global networks that empower them to drive change in critical sectors such as governance, education, health, climate action, economic development, and public policy.
Successful candidates will undertake a full-time MasterΓÇÖs degree in Australia beginning in 2027 and are expected to return home after completion to apply their knowledge and skills for national and regional development.
What the Scholarship Covers
The Australia Awards Africa Scholarship is fully funded and typically covers:


Full tuition fees for the duration of the MasterΓÇÖs program


Return economy airfare to and from Australia


Establishment allowance upon arrival


Contribution to living expenses


Overseas Student Health Cover


Academic and pastoral support throughout the study period


Eligibility Requirements
Applicants must:


Be citizens of an eligible African country and reside and work in their country of citizenship or another African country


Hold a BachelorΓÇÖs degree or equivalent qualification


Not already possess a MasterΓÇÖs degree


Be a mid-level to senior-level professional currently employed in a relevant field


Meet postgraduate work experience requirements


Demonstrate a clear plan to apply the skills and knowledge gained toward development, reform, or improved practice in their home country


Meet English language proficiency requirements


Satisfy Australian student visa (subclass 500) requirements


Applicants are also required to submit two referee reports using the official template.
How to Apply
Interested candidates should:


Review the full eligibility criteria for the 2027 intake


Read the Frequently Asked Questions carefully


Register for an official information session if needed


Prepare all required documents, including referee reports


Submit their application through the official Australia Awards Africa portal


Deadline
Applications are open now and close on 30 April 2026.
Additional Opportunities
Applicants interested in short-term professional training can also explore Australia Awards Short Courses, which provide targeted skills development without full degree study.
For official guidance, updates, and application links, applicants are encouraged to consult the Australia Awards Africa website. Please read through the┬áFrequently Asked Questions (FAQs) here┬ábefore submitting your application.

fields.title: WIPO Global Awards 2026
fields.description_en: The WIPO Global Awards 2026 celebrate enterprises that strategically use intellectual property (IP) to grow their businesses, enter new markets, and deliver meaningful social, economic, and environmental impact aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Applications are open to eligible startups and SMEs from all 194 WIPO Member States and across all economic sectors. Selected enterprises will receive global visibility, a tailored 6-month mentorship programme on IP commercialization and business strategy, access to investors, corporates, institutions, and IP service providers, and exclusive benefits and strategic business connections. An invitation to Geneva, Switzerland, to attend the Awards Ceremony during the WIPO Assemblies.

ai.notes: The award is for innovative startups and SMEs. There are 10 Global Awards across all sectors and 1 Thematic Prize for SMEs in Sports. Two Special Mentions are for Best Woman Entrepreneur and Best Youth Entrepreneur. The application deadline is March 31, 2026.
